TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek the indulgence of the Chair to add to an answer.
—The Minister may proceed.

—Yesterday I was asked a question by the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). I wish to add the following: my Department was not previously aware of the prospectus document compiled by Gregory Symons for a company called Unipac. It is in possession of a handout containing information on Unipac International—a university study centre. However, I am advised this morning that a copy of the prospectus is held in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the handout, it contains general information on the Marshall Islands, its history, et cetera and, in addition, it purports to be able to influence the entry of students to the USA via the Marshall Islands. The contents of the Unipac handout are specifically directed towards the entry of persons to the USA, and no mention is made of Australia or New Zealand. Preliminary inquiries in my Department's central, State and Suva offices reveal no record of any approaches or negotiations between Mr Symons, Unipac and the Department to facilitate student entry into Australia. I have requested that the Department continue its investigations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was also asked a question yesterday by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), and I add the following: the business migration application of Chang Jin-Tso was assessed and approved in the Hong Kong office. The approving officer was satisfied that Chang Yung Tsong met the definition of dependant as laid out in the migration regulations. Claims by Multiplex in letters to Suva supporting a visitor visa for Mr Chang Yung Tsong were considered in assessing that application. That application was rejected by the assessing officer.

PARA.TAB: The claims made in that letter did not alter the fact that Chang Jr was still dependent on his father. I had requested my Department to review all the decisions involved to assure itself that they all met migration law and policy. The preliminary report of my Department is that they complied with that law and policy. The relevant files are now being sent to central office for further examination. My Department is investigating whether any parties to the various applications may have manipulated migration laws or other laws. This investigation will include the role of Multiplex.

I am informed that Multiplex did not make representations in respect of the business migration application of Mr Chang Sr. The request for details of any reference or sponsorship by Multiplex of any migration application since 1985 is a request that will take some time and resources, if at all fully possible. I have requested my Department to provide as much detail as it can assemble as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Deputy Leader of the National Party, I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills concurrently with the Wool Tax (Administration) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a repeat of a very similar situation 12 months ago where, in the dying stages of Parliament, we had a guillotined debate, a very restricted time available for debate on one of the great Australian industries—the wool industry—at a time of particular difficulty for that industry. I accept that it is the greatest Australian industry in the history of this country and that a tax was to be imposed on it. It was also the baptism of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to primary industry. I think he had reason then to question some of the legislative and administrative problems that he had inherited from the industry.

PARA.TAB: In one of these Bills today I think there will be further questioning by the Minister when I refer to the concept, procedures or arrangements for the annual meeting that he has been bequeathed again on this occasion. When we looked at the wool industry at that time, we saw that there was a stockpile of over 4.6 million bales, basically a year's production, and a debt of $2.8 billion. There was a debate as to what level of tax would apply to the woolgrowers of Australia who were looking forward to a significant reduction in their income because of the removal of the reserve price. They were suffering because of the drought that was then covering much of the wool-growing area.

The Government was originally proposing a 15 per cent tax; the Opposition said that a 10 per cent tax was adequate to cover the situation. Finally, a 12 per cent compromise was reached in the Senate. At that time, in that compromise, some of the participants from the industry and the Australian Democrats were not aware that the Minister was going to reduce the promotion levy from 3 1/2 per cent, of that 12 per cent, to 2 1/2 per cent which, in turn, has now caused problems with finance for wool promotion.

At that time there was a very severe drought across much of Australia which, as was known at the time, has led to reduced production either directly because of the drought or indirectly because it was no longer of cost benefit to purchase the supplementary feed necessary to keep many of the sheep alive and producing. So for this financial year we now have a production of somewhere between 750 and 774 million kilograms of wool. That is well down from the record production of earlier times. There was also a situation where the wool textile pipeline—the wool going through the textile processing system—was basically empty because of the uncertainty that the wool textile industry was facing with regard to price and availability. Since that time there has been a better than anticipated clearance from the stockpile of about 100 million kilograms of wool. The debt reduction from the original $2.8 billion will certainly be under $2.4 billion by the end of this financial year.

The auction price has moved up and is very close to the 600c a kilogram. I commend the Australian Wool Realisation Commission for the way it has handled, with its policy, the disposal of the stockpile in that time. We now have the forecasts from the Australian Wool Corporation for the coming production year. It is saying that production will continue to fall to about 730 million kilograms and is anticipating that sales from the stockpile could be 50 per cent higher—that is, up to about 150 million kilograms of wool from about 100 million kilograms—for this current year. It is even estimating that the price will be slightly higher, at about 620c a kilogram clean.

All of this means that, basically, the operating costs of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission for storage, interest charges, and all other charges, of $374m, have been covered. The $20m initial debt repayment has been covered and there is about $300m left. In addition to that, in looking forward, the total costs will fall from $374m for this current year to about $260m next year. So if there is only a 2 per cent reduction in the total tax, which will cost about $54m, the Wool Realisation Commission already has enough to meet its costs for the coming year and it is already below the debt reduction requirement for 12 months time, which was $2.559 billion.

If we add to that situation the levy income that will come in—whether the levy is set at 10 per cent, or some other figure—plus the big increase estimated in stockpile sales, we see that the wool industry is well on the way to once again being a proud industry. Debt will come down, as will the stockpile that has been overhanging the market. This was obvious as early as December last year when the Wool Council and the coalition parties indicated that three factors had to be considered.

First, there had to be greater flexibility in the debt repayment schedule, so that the earlier than anticipated debt reduction could be credited against later years; otherwise, the industry would be faced with the second best proposition of investing its surplus at a lower interest rate than it had been forced to pay through the outstanding debt. There was already apparent an ability to reduce the tax level for this coming year. The dramatic reduction in promotion funds meant that even with the reduced level of activity by the IWS—and many would say that it was time that the IWS had a good hard look at the scale and the cost benefit of its operations—it was not sustainable.

The Minister's response came through the One Nation statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in which the Government indicated that it had agreed to flexibility in the debt repayment schedule. I commend the Minister and the Government for that. I believe that is a very sensible situation. It is one of the points in this legislation. But at the same time in that statement there was the proposal to have a refund arrangement to take account of the surplus that had already been generated.

Both the industry and the coalition were quick to point out that, at a cost of several million dollars, it would be costly to administer; it would be a clumsy system. Anybody who has been involved with these systems before—whether in the wool industry, the horticultural industry or any other industry—knows that it would not be a clean thing administratively. There would be a delay in the delivery, and it would not maximise the benefit to the woolgrowers of Australia. When one considers that every one per cent reduction in that wool tax is worth about $1,000 to an average woolgrower with about 5,000 sheep, one can see that it is a significant factor in survival. Woolgrowers this financial year, according to the Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics, will have a loss of $46,000—their worst year in the history of this country.

They are not unique in that sense, because all farmers are facing their worst year in the history of this country with every single category operating on a loss basis. But, unfortunately, woolgrowers are the worst affected with that mammoth figure. So anything that can be done to reduce their cost pressure is of value to their survival. Because of pressure and valid argument from the coalition parties and from the industry through the Wool Council, we now have a compromise in this legislation. We are having a refund when we are not having a refund, and we are having a tax reduction when we are not having a tax reduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still do not understand it.
—It's still the growers' money.
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will cease interjecting.

—I say again that at least the Minister has been prepared to listen to commonsense on this basis. On the same basis of listening to commonsense, I put it to the Minister that there is absolutely no reason why the tax for the forthcoming year has to be any higher than 9 per cent because of those figures that have already been indicated, and because all the costs necessary for this coming year have already been covered. When one takes into account the projections of the Wool Corporation for the forthcoming year, one realises that even 9 per cent is a very safe and conservative figure, and that an even lower figure would be responsible. Some of the views put forward by members of the wool industry have indicated that much.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the Minister will be making this decision and the necessary regulation when he hears from the Wool Realisation Commission in June. I have no doubt that the AWRC will be very conservative. But the Minister must take into account the overall position of the industry and the advice received from the various sectors of the industry, knowing that he is maintaining the actual legislative level at 12 per cent, and therefore there is an ability to move. I remind the Minister to think very carefully about the future of the industry. I repeat that anything more than 9 per cent is completely unnecessary. At this time of great economic difficulty for woolgrowers, it is an unnecessary burden on their survival.

I again point out to the Government and to the woolgrowers of Australia that if reducing costs is the most fundamental way of ensuring survival, the coalition's Fightback package is of value. Even the Minister has not disagreed with the Treasury calculation of a saving of over $1 billion a year to Australia's farmers. The figures we got from the Department are far more accurate than the Minister's off-the-cuff figures. There will be an average saving of over $8,000 per year per farmer, a tremendous saving to people who are hard pressed. The Treasury document, which is the Government's own document—it is not the Opposition's—shows that there would be further savings of $177m a year in the textile industry and $139m a year in the clothing and footwear industry.

The Minister is very keen on further processing, as is everybody else in primary industry, when it is sensible to do so and true value adding takes place. There is acknowledgment that early stage processing of wool is slowly but surely increasing with scouring and tops production. But there is only one way for it to develop, and that is to develop commercially, particularly when one considers that one of the newest investments in Western Australia is not operating at the present time. We look at the proposal by one of the biggest wool textile companies in the world, BWK, to invest in early stage processing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tops-making, not scouring. There's a difference.
—It is part of early stage processing.
—It's only one.
—If the Minister likes to make the point about tops, let us have a go at him about whether it is a tops proposal because—
—Order! The Minister will cease interjecting.

—He has $135m in his textile fund to encourage, we are told, what is a very commercial and very profitable company, to give it some special encouragement to start here. In the long run, that would retard a sensible development of early stage processing, including tops-making, because a number of other companies want to either increase or start production. If we are going to have special deals for some, there is no way that we can have a straight commercial basis for the overall development of that industry.

PARA.TAB: If the Government wants to do something to encourage companies to develop on a commercial basis a higher percentage of early stage processing, it could find no better place to look than the Opposition's Fightback policy. The complete removal of payroll tax, fuel tax and sales tax, as indicated in the Government's own Treasury document, would effect savings of over $100m per year.

The other part of this legislation makes some amendments—there are some other factors, but this is the important one—to the arrangements for the annual meeting. I acknowledge that the Minister had this Bill under way ahead of that meeting in early May, which indicates once again some of the unhappy legacies that he had to deal with and a recognition that it was not going to be the most successful annual general meeting that could take place. That has been proven to be the case, which is unfortunate. I believe that the new Wool Corporation has been doing a good job in restoring confidence in the industry. This has been an unfortunate and unnecessary blow to that rebuilding of credibility and confidence with regard to the peak industry organisational body.

I note that the changes are to allow registration for a three-year period. That seems to me to be sensible, because there were real problems with timing for the first AGM, when I think about 8,000 out of a potential 60,000 woolgrowers actually registered. There will be the opportunity for broader accountability in future AGMs beyond the restrictions to no confidence motions concerning the AWC and debate on the level of the wool tax. More general items to provide that broader accountability will be allowed. That seems to me to be sensible.

It is fairly obvious from what I am saying that we are supporting this legislation. However, I question the cost benefit of the big PR-type annual meeting, which has been best, or worst, exemplified in the meat industry with the AMLC meeting. Although the wool one has not cost as much as that, there are claims that it has cost $400,000. I note that in a dairy industry Bill to be debated later today the Minister has not required the same concept, and that seems to me to be sensible. One should not be forcing some sort of overall model on all industries. I question whether or not what is being maintained in this legislation—that is, the single AGM-type meeting—is the best way to have accountability in the wool industry. There are a number of other ways of doing it.

One way that seems worth investigating further—I have had some discussions with the industry, and I presume the Minister is having discussions with it also—is that, if we have only one meeting per year somewhere in Australia, because of the size of Australia we will have real problems in having an equitable spread of membership attending that meeting. Therefore, we will have great proxy battles. Smaller, less costly meetings in two or three geographical parts of Australia would seem to me to be an alternative that is at least worth further exploring. Unfortunately, because of the very severe guillotine that has been placed on this debate, and the limited opportunity that has been provided for others to speak, those are all of my comments, other than to say that the Opposition supports the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wool package comprises seven Bills. The omnibus Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) includes amendments to the following Acts: the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964 and the Wool Tax Acts (Nos 1 to 5) of 1964. The main purpose of the package is to provide the mechanisms to make rebates of surplus Australian Wool Realisation Commission funds. There are also some minor amendments to finetune the Acts in light of the experience with their administration over the past year.

PARA.TAB: The key amendment in regard to the Australian Wool Corporation Act is to enable wool tax payers to be registered for the purposes of the annual general meetings of the AWC and the Wool Research and Development Corporation for three years rather than the existing one year. There is another amendment in regard to clarifying the provisions concerning persons who may not be appointed members of the AWC so that members of the executives of peak national wool industry bodies are ineligible for appointment to the AWC Board. It will enable the possibility of an organisation other than the National Association of Testing Authorities to be the registering body for wool sampling sites, laboratories and show floors.

The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991 is to be amended to provide for the debt repayment schedule to be replaced on a cumulative basis. That is to enable the AWRC to carry over amounts repaid in excess of the current minimum annual repayments and to give the AWRC more flexibility in stockpile sales, especially in responding to downturns in the market.

The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act is to be amended as a consequence of changes to the AWC Act to enable growers to register for AGMs for three years rather than annually as at present, since the AWC register is also used as the register for the WRDC AGMs. The changes to the Wool Tax Acts (Nos 1 to 5) are to increase the maximum rate of wool tax on carpet wool from 4 to 6 per cent. Since carpet wool pays only the promotion and R&D components of wool tax, and the combined rates voted on at the recent AGM exceed the current 4 per cent maximum, the carpet wool councils have requested that the maximum be increased to 6 per cent. The actual rate to apply, if lower than the maximum, will be set by regulation. The changes to the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964 enable persons liable to wool tax to remit to the Commonwealth the prescribed rate of wool tax less the rebate, if a rebate is declared, to complement the new rebate provisions in the AWRC Act.

The prices received for wool have been generally better than expected. The market indicator has ranged from 434c to 648c per kilogram this season, after closing at the end of the last season at about 598c. It is encouraging, given the tough times that our wool producers have gone through over the last few years. I think there is some encouragement on the horizon. With the better weather across this country I think we can have a bit more optimism in regard to the industry and the challenges ahead.

I believe that there are some other speakers on this Bill today. Because of the guillotine I will conclude my remarks now to allow the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) to address these amendments. I think it is important that those honourable members who have indicated they wish to speak on this Bill can do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of wool tax Bills before the House—the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills, the Wool Tax (Administration) Amendment Bill and the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2)—is important. It is certainly important to woolgrowers. It is a move in the right direction, a move that has much more support from the wool industry than the Government's first proposal in addressing the circumstances of the substantially reduced debt of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, resulting from much more substantial sales and at better prices than were anticipated at the time the original legislation was brought into this Parliament after the demise of the previous wool marketing arrangements.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, it should be on the record that the Opposition is now in the position of saying, `We told you so'. The simple fact is that at that time the Opposition campaigned for a 10 per cent tax overall. I think history is now proving us to be the better judges and more confident in our wool industry than the Government is. But that is behind us. The current proposal creates a mechanism whereby on an annual basis the Government can reset the wool tax to reflect the previous year's marketing. It is a compromise between the Government's original position and the wool industry's position. My advice from wool industry people is that they are satisfied with that and, as a consequence, it has the support of the Opposition.

The moves as yet have not clearly defined how future tax may be split up. In the original proposals a 3.5 per cent promotion levy was reduced to 2.5 per cent in the construction of the original 12 per cent tax. That was a response to the ability of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to reduce the tax from 15 per cent to 12 per cent, and it is now to be lower.

I have heard all the arguments for promotion. Recently I took the opportunity to travel to Japan, in particular Osaka, and to South Korea, particularly Taegu, and asked people at the coalface, if you like, of the wool industry what their opinion was on its future and certain aspects of the industry as it is promoted in Australia by the various wool industry bodies. It was interesting to me that when technicians in the fourth biggest weaving and spinning mill in the world at Taegu in South Korea were asked what they thought of the current campaign in Australia for length and strength testing, they shrugged their shoulders and said, `If you provide it, we'll use it. But as professionals in the wool industry we make our own adjustments in that regard'. Those aspects should be taken into account.

A substantial amount of promotion also seemed to be taking place. I had interesting discussions with various people associated with the International Wool Secretariat and was impressed by their enthusiasm. I was also impressed by the quality of their office space and the views across Hong Kong harbour. I am sure that we could get equal effort from less expensive office space but, in general, I accept the role of promotion. Nevertheless, I am deeply concerned that at no time will this promotion be allowed to reach the levels of excesses, or fat, that I think occurred.

I note that Mr Excell, the new managing director or senior executive of the IWS, has been out here explaining to us how we are being taken over. His one-liner seems to be that the doona filled with synthetic product has replaced the blanket. All this happened while we were spending $200m-plus a year on promotion. There seems to be some contradiction in his argument that we have to spend more because that happened. It occurred when we were spending a fortune. It is evident that those people were taking woolgrowers' money—I am categorised in that group—and not protecting them from synthetic doona filling. It is fortunate, but probably a little late, that CSIRO—as I have reminded this Parliament time and again—has now come up with a wool filler product which I can testify is excellent and should be able to establish itself in the market.

I might add—I have already put it on the record—because it is worth while in terms of value adding, that Coles Fosseys sent me a new doona the other day for road testing and I am doing that. It is one that the company has manufactured to meet its particular market—a cheaper product. It appears excellent and I congratulate the company on its initiative. When I first discovered that CSIRO had come up with this excellent doona filling material, which is made of wool and polyester—the polyester is there to improve the product, not to lower its cost; it stops the product from felting down—I found that most of our major retailers were not stocking the product. My correspondence has encouraged them to do so, but Coles warrants special mention because, having had a look at the product and having realised that it could not market it at the price, it manufactured one specially that meets its price constraints. The company is to be congratulated on that. Having tried out the product, I can say that it is certainly keeping me warm at home. Australians should acknowledge that such products are available.

Promotion is something that we read about in the newspapers and is being provided in Australia by private enterprise. Nevertheless, the recent advertisements by the Australian Wool Corporation, which commenced on National Wool Day, are excellent. I think the advertisements have struck a cord because they promote Australian wool as a product which is not a chemical product. Considering the views, particularly in the Northern Hemisphere, concerning chemicals these days and the resulting pollution, we have a great opportunity to market wool as something very special. I congratulate the Corporation on its initiative.

However, I raise the caution that, as politicians, we are still to learn that throwing money at something does not necessarily solve the problem. As to the industry's demands for more money—as a woolgrower, I would give it more money—I expect to see performance. To stand up and say, `Well, during the period we failed you gave us twice as much as we get now, and that is why you should give us more money' is a very poor argument. I would like Mr Excell to adjust his rhetoric because I do not think it is a convincing argument. Nevertheless, I do not think any member of this Parliament stands away from the fact that part of the levy that must be imposed on wool growers is a contribution to promotion.

There is a substantial role for promotion by those who manufacture wool product. When I read about cotton in Australia I usually find that it is some jeans manufacturer or company of that kind which is promoting the product because it is fundamental to that company's product. We must encourage that at all times. After all, people do not buy wool; they buy woollen clothing, woollen blankets or other products.

It is worth noting that the Wool Realisation Commission has achieved outstanding sales and this is very encouraging. The Commission seems to have been able to achieve that with a limited effect on the market; the market has risen. There was a bit of a blurp and a fright when it got a little higher than anticipated and then, through some actions which were not very smart, particularly the one allowing too much wool to come onto a couple of sales, the price fell, but it has now stabilised. Whether woolgrowers like it or not, if we are to re-establish our product on the market we will have to look at something like a price indicator of 600c for some time to come. It is time—and I think it represents a challenge—for the Wool Corporation to sit down and advise our industry of the price at which the world will buy our product. That will be information that some people will not want to hear but, if it is 700c, the simple message to some is this: do not grow it; look for alternatives. I have a farm in an area which has traditionally been a fat lamb producing area. I cannot grow them at a profit and I told my manager the other day to get rid of those Dorset Horn rams; I do not want them on the property any more. I would rather not bother because for me they are not profitable. It is my job as a farmer to find something that is profitable, even in tough times.

If the world demands that we produce wool in the near future at a market indicator of around 700c there will be some woolgrowers who can produce at that and those are the ones that will have to do so. Obviously we would like more to do that. One of the ways over time that that economy will be achieved is when the industry also understands that it is impossible for it to continue to pay the prices for land that it has in the past. Australian land is simply not worth the price that farmers have paid for it and it is a significant aspect of their costs. That is a terrible message for the bloke who has already paid it and either has a debt or is sitting on that land. But they are all aspects of meeting the price that the world will pay.

My visit told me that in both Japan and Korea they are anticipating a 20 per cent increase by volume in their purchases. But, of course, the other fact of life is that they will also be affected by the price. I asked them what was the optimum price and their answer to me was, `Well, what can your farmers afford to produce it at?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to contribute a few words on the Wool Tax (Administration) Amendment Bill in the limited time left. I want to caution the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) about the overall tax levels for the coming 12 months because he has an enormous responsibility resting on his shoulders when he ultimately determines and is given the power to regulate the wool tax for the coming 12 months given all that has happened in the past 12 months. Whilst seasons may have turned for some woolgrowers across Australia, there are still a large number of producers forced to feed sheep and who are in a critical situation. So the lower that the Minister can make that tax quite responsibly this year the better it will be. Albeit that they may be very small gains, every dollar will be greatly appreciated by those out there in rural Australia in a critical situation in the coming 12 months, particularly the woolgrowers. The measure will certainly be supported from this side of the House.

PARA.TAB: I must say, though, that the 4 per cent figure proposed for promotion in the coming 12 months is a sensible one. Unfortunately, it is necessary this year to raise the promotion level to beyond what it could have been had the Minister not intervened last year and forced the industry to take only 2 1/2 per cent for promotion. In any industry—I am sure the Minister does understand this—where one has a problem selling one's product because of the events of the previous 12 months and the collapse of the reserve price scheme, promotion is extremely important. One just cannot sell a product without promotion, and promotion internationally is extremely expensive. This year the industry is forced to increase the tax above the level that it would have liked. Had it been able to have the tax that it proposed for promotion last year of 3 1/2 per cent, the increase would not have had to be so great this year.

One can look at what research money does and how it is spent. The dividend, if one likes, that is paid to the woolgrowers from that research money of one half of one per cent benefits not just the woolgrowers but all Australians. A paper was recently put out by ABARE on the dividend that is paid really as a result of that research. The money spent by CSIRO on Sirospun has been extremely well spent. I think there is a factor of about 10:1 in terms of the dividend paid from that research money.

There is one other aspect that I would like to touch on. In the intervening period between the last sitting fortnight and this sitting fortnight, I spent a few days in Russia. I was there on a project that I was involved in under the agricultural cooperation agreement prior to coming into politics. While I was in Moscow I had some very good discussions with the International Wool Secretariat and with Austrade. There was talk about the New Zealand wool deal that was floating around and which is being proposed now.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will just take the opportunity to respond to a couple of points that have been made in the debate. The first is that I do accept the comments that have been made not only by the other side of the House but indeed by me. I do see it as very important that we seek, against the background of prudentially continuing to manage the stockpile, to try to get as much back to woolgrowers at this time in the rebuilding process as is possible. I happen to believe that there is a great future for wool in this country; I made this point when I opened National Wool Day in this Parliament a month or so back. We are uniquely placed because we do have significant moneys in the rural adjustment scheme. Optimism has returned with the prices, the breaking of the drought substantially, the greater certainty and the preparedness for investment in tops-making beyond the scouring processing for which there is an overcapacity. But there is not overcapacity given the new demand and the strategic linkage that Australia can provide in the wool chain as a top supplier to an Asian market that is increasingly coming on stream where it can provide the spinning and weaving dimension with our providing the tops dimension. So I am keen to see that develop and not to restrict entry to simply one company.

PARA.TAB: I am on record as saying that the approaches through the TCFDA have to be transparent, they have to be available to all comers and they cannot be selective. There is a great opportunity. The rural adjustment scheme provides the basis for restructuring not just the wool industry but others in the farm sector, and I think we have to capitalise on that. I happen to believe that the capital base has been run down in the major industries. If we can reduce costs and returns to the growers, it will be an important impetus to enable them to rebuild that capital base. So I am convinced that what we have to do is to try to get back as much as is possible. This legislation gives us the flexibility to do that based upon performance. That performance has been achieved. The extent of that performance judged against prudential management is still a matter that I have to consider in the next couple of weeks, but I will be continuing to talk with the wool industry about the most appropriate outcome.

The second point I make just briefly relates to the question of promotion. I do not accept that the decision that I took last time to limit the amount spent on promotion at 2 1/2 per cent has seen a diminution in promotion by the Australian Wool Corporation. The Wool Corporation had in fact substantial reserves and it accepted when I made the 2 1/2 per cent decision that, provided it did not last for longer than a year, it could manage.

The other discipline that the cutting of promotion at that time had was to cause a fundamental rethink in the International Wool Secretariat. I, too, have had a number of important discussions with it and I am impressed by the direction that it is now pursuing. It is a much leaner and more market oriented organisation than it was and that is an important portent of things to come. The industry has to become market driven. It has to understand the significance of quality and service through the wool pipeline. It has to meet market demands. It cannot simply continue to be a supply driven dimension; that, I think, has been the reason that the industry has not prospered as strongly as it could have in the past. So, whilst I have taken notice of the decisions that have been taken at those meetings of the wool industry, I will be talking to the industry about its recommendations. I see promotion as fundamental to the future of the industry and I have made a commitment that I will not take any decisions which it could be argued would limit the capacity for it to promote. There is a great future for this industry, and this legislation will help it.

Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the remaining stages be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
