DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (PUBLIC MOBILE LICENCE CHARGE) BILL 1992]
Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Mr Snowdon:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day, the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), concurrently with the Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill. As there is no objection, I will allow that course of action to be followed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate I represent the Opposition's view on the part of the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill that deals with shipping. This Bill is very broad in nature. It does not deal just with transport and shipping issues, it deals also with communications and aviation matters. My colleagues the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) will speak in relation to their shadow portfolios in those areas following my contribution.

PARA.TAB: I wish to address the amendments to the shipping and maritime aspects of the Bill. In passing, I just make reference to the fact that the Government's guillotine limits the opportunity and the time available for members of the House of Representatives to address concerns that they believe are important. This Government is totally and utterly incapable of managing the affairs of the House of Representatives. We have seen the guillotine applied by this Government more times than the total recorded in the rest of the history of the Federal Parliament. It just goes to show that not only can it not run the economy, not only can it not create jobs for people throughout Australia, but also it cannot even get down to the business of properly managing the affairs of the House of Representatives so as to ensure that members have the opportunity to speak for a proper amount of time on subjects that they believe it is important to raise in order to represent the best interests of their constituents.

This Bill is not of a particularly controversial nature from the point of view of either the industry or the members of the Federal coalition. It deals with a number of amendments which we judge to be worthy of support. For example, the first aspect of the Bill that attracts my interest is an amendment to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990. It allows the Australian Maritime Safety Authority to provide services on a commercial basis to the Commonwealth, the States, the ACT and the Northern Territory. This ensures that any demands that are placed by either the Commonwealth, the States or the Territories on AMSA's services can be charged out to those governments on a full commercial basis so that AMSA is not subsidising Commonwealth departmental activities or, indeed, State or Territory government activities.

Because plenty of funds will be available, AMSA will be able to focus solely on providing the search and rescue and other maritime safety activities around Australia for ordinary citizens who get lost at sea. It also ensures the provision of services to commercial and recreational shipping so that those two areas do not feel that, through the payment of costs and fees, they are subsidising government departments at either the State or Federal level. This is something we can support. Indeed, we would support the further commercialisation of AMSA.

From time to time in the past the Opposition has said that there are certain aspects of the activities of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority which can be fully commercialised and, indeed, privatised. There is no reason at all why some of AMSA's activities cannot be privatised. We have indicated that, when in government after the next election, we will be moving in this direction. We will ensure that those who have a proper responsibility to pay for the search and rescue and other safety activities of AMSA will pay for them. That will enable the Commonwealth to focus its funding on those areas that are of a community service obligation nature, such as search and rescue operations for people lost at sea. This will ensure that we have more resources to carry out that very important task.

Another aspect of the legislation is a very minor amendment to the Navigation Act 1912. It corrects what was a very basic drafting error. It is sloppy drafting, and the Department of Transport and Communications can be properly criticised—indeed, constructively criticised—for what was a very poor bit of drafting. Instead of using the word `industrial' in the Bill when it was first presented and passed through this Parliament, the Government now wishes to change that word to international.

This does not have any great bearing on the nature of the Bill; it simply highlights the importance of having Bills properly drafted and properly checked before they come to the Parliament. Every time an amendment is required to correct a drafting error, it costs many thousands of dollars, takes up the time of this Parliament and creates unnecessary work and expense that could otherwise be directed towards better government. I just make the point that the Department has not acted as professionally as it could have and needs to correct itself in this area in the future.

The other, and probably more important, aspects of the legislation deal with the Protection of Sea (Powers of Intervention) Act 1991. They deal with environmentally hazardous chemicals carried on board vessels around Australian waters. We are all very much aware of the need to protect Australia's waters against oil spills and chemical spills that can occur from a ship in one way or another. A ship can break up, as was the case with the recent sinking of the Kirki off the Western Australian coastline when the bow simply broke off the ship and the oil spilled into the ocean or, as with the Exxon Valdez off the coast of the United States, a ship can run aground, hit a rock and split open, resulting in an oil spill.

These are two recent and well-known examples of how very environmentally damaging activities can occur at sea. This amendment to the legislation deals in a better and a more comprehensive way with widening the range of chemicals and other hazardous objects carried on board ships. It ensures that the list is kept up to date with the latest changes in technology and the types of chemicals that are being transported around the world by ships. It ensures that for every hazardous chemical carried on board a ship a proper safety program is available and a proper communications system is in operation to ensure that if any of these chemicals are spilled, either because of a ship breaking up or hitting a rock or because of sloppy handling in a port, the proper procedures are in place so that those chemical spills are reported correctly and that the correct procedures are enacted to ensure that damage to the environment is minimised.

Once again, the Opposition supports this amendment. For several years we have been very supportive of any reasonable move to minimise any potential environmental damage that may occur in our maritime environment. I note that the former Minister for Shipping and Aviation, Senator Collins—who was appointed to the Cabinet yesterday and whose shipping and waterfront responsibilities have been transferred to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook—has often been critical of the Opposition, saying that it stands for polluting the environment and all these dastardly things. Of course, as is so often the case, Senator Collins was exaggerating and not being fair, accurate or correct in his representation of Opposition policy or intentions.

In many of these areas of maritime safety and maritime environmental protection the Opposition has been as good as, if not better than, the Government in promoting the cause of environmental protection in our maritime environment. In this instance we again support wholeheartedly the amendment that we believe better protects our maritime environment, and we will continue to support any other issue we believe is important to environmental protection of our maritime areas.

The next aspect also deals with the protection of our maritime environment. It particularly deals with the protocol on environmental protection to the Antarctic Treaty. Australia has a very significant involvement in the Antarctic. We have a very important responsibility to fulfil there. We and the Government are proposing in the amendment to further the environmental protection of the Antarctic area by ensuring that all ships that enter Australian waters in the Antactic, whether signatories to the MARPOL agreements or not, are made to deal properly with the treatment of sewage to ensure that sewage is just not haphazardly dumped in that area, and by ensuring that any chemicals or hazardous materials which are spilt, or which may have the potential to be spilt into the Antarctic environment, are handled in a proper and responsible fashion.

The amendment will extend our powers in that area and will provide fines of up to $200,000 to ensure that ships that do not fly the flag of a signatory to the MARPOL agreements come within the responsibilities of proper legislation and proper activities in the Antarctic area. Once again, the Opposition wholeheartedly supports this particular aspect of the legislation.

Another aspect that we would like to raise has been brought to our attention by the Australian National Maritime Association, a very responsible and professional group of people who represent the shipowners of Australia. I would like to take the opportunity today to draw this matter to the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon), who is at the table, and to the attention of the departmental officials in the advisers booth. The association has said that, whilst it supports all the Government's proposals in this area, there is a need to take into account the provision of safe ports around the Australian coastline for ships that have a problem, be it the spillage of oil or some other hazardous chemical. It makes the point that there are many occasions when a ship may be leaking oil, or leaking some hazardous material, and the best way to deal with the problem would be to have that ship sail into a port, be it under tow or under its own steam, to have those dangerous chemicals, oil, or whatever it may be, pumped off the ship into safe storage on land.

This is a very sensible way of addressing the problem of the spillage of oil or other chemicals at sea; indeed, it could limit the damage to the environment. We need to have a proper strategy in place to ensure that we have safe ports so that if a ship strikes a problem of this nature it can sail into the port, secure in the knowledge that proper procedures are in place to deal with any environmental damage, and store those environmentally damaging chemicals, oils, or whatever they may be, so that we can minimise the damage to our environment. ANMA has made that plea. On behalf of ANMA and the shipowners and operators of Australia I extend that plea to the Government: we need to have in place safe ports where vessels in distress can be taken.

We also need to ensure the availability of tugs to take the vessels into the ports if they cannot get there under their own steam. For example, they could have been damaged in a storm, they could have struck rocks and lost a propeller, or their engines could have failed. This is something, I believe, which is very important. It is an issue which will become more important over the years ahead.

The world shipping fleet is getting older. Because of the age of the Kirki, sheer metal failure led to the bow breaking off and this will occur more often in the future. I expect, and look forward to, further legislation coming into this Parliament which will ensure that maritime environmental protection will be properly addressed. I can assure the Government and the industry that we will support any reasonable measure to safely protect the maritime environment for future generations of Australians.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Opposition Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills that are being debated cognately, the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill, relate to the communication side of this portfolio. On behalf of the Opposition I indicate that we will not be opposing the amendments.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, there are two amendments proposed to the first Bill, which can be described as an omnibus Bill as it covers several areas—the matters just discussed by my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), including aviation matters. One area relates to the Australian Postal Corporation Act and the Bill extending the Act to the Indian Ocean Territories and, as a consequence, the Government's decision to eliminate all differences between the law of those Territories and mainland Australia. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), is at the table. I think the Indian Ocean area comes into his jurisdiction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. A very pleasant part of the country.

—It is a very pleasant part of the country. It looks like philatelic sales will probably go up in that area as well. The second area relates to the amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991. An important amendment there is made to protect the name and symbol of Austel, the independent regulator of telecommunications. There have been recent examples where, we assume unwittingly, people have been using that particular name for commercial advantage, and that should not continue. That is why that amendment is there.

PARA.TAB: There are also some amendments relating to the international transit arrangements for the carriage of services. More importantly, there is an amendment that enables AOTC, the dominant carrier, which superseded Telecom—we now have a combined Telecom and OTC—to discriminate between customers in setting prices. It provides the opportunity for concessions to be made to pensioners. The details of those concessions have already been announced. It is important that people in our community who are users of telecommunications services, and who are on very low or fixed incomes, have the benefit, and this amendment enables that to take place.

The massive changes that are being made in the Telecom area are impacting on all levels of the community, not the least of which is the employment levels within Telecom. Some concerns have been expressed in Canberra in recent days. I say to the residents of Canberra that they are not the only residents in Australia who are seeing the changes that are taking place in telecommunications. I was in Warrnambool in Victoria recently and saw changes there. Being Tasmanian, I have seen changes in Tasmania. These changes will have to be made if we are to be serious about addressing the broader benefits that will flow from growth in the telecommunications market and the new competitive arrangements that have been supported by both sides of this Parliament.

I think the Government has to ask itself about the long term policy implications that flow from the necessary commercial charter that it has given Telecom. It would not be happening in the way that it is, and there would not be concern in the community about job dislocation that is taking place, if we were not in the middle of a recession. We all recognise that there has to be this change. When this happens, there will always be human costs. I think Telecom management is doing the best it can, but it is charged with carrying out a policy that the Government has given it. There would not be the disquiet to the extent there is in the community about the necessary changes, engaging the new technologies that are available and that we ought to be taking part in, if we were not in the middle of a recession that is biting so many people so hard.

We support the amendment to make sure that the pensioners of Australia get the benefits that we think they should get. But we also support the continuation of the change that ought to be taking place in telecommunications. This has been delayed for too long. Perhaps if we had been making changes in telecommunications over a slightly longer period, rather than trying to rush them through in the way that the Government has had to do, the impact on so many employees would not have been so severe.

I have always said that in the changes which are taking place we ought to be as generous as is possible to those employees in terms of additional training. I think AOTC is trying to do that. But they are issues which the Government must address. Many communities throughout Australia are asking the question and are not receiving any answer.

I suppose it would be an opportune time to pose a challenge to the new Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, who has been appointed and formally takes up his position today. I congratulate him and welcome him to the portfolio. I think he is the fourth Minister that I have shadowed in this area in about 12 months. I hope that he will stay there at least until the election. In any event, he is charged with a very weighty responsibility.

I think most people would recognise that telecommunications services and broadcast services touch each and every family in this community. So the decisions that the Government makes about these areas are indeed important. They need to be thought through very carefully.

One of the other matters we are debating here today relates to the Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill. As I understand it, we are debating these Bills cognately. I indicate, on behalf of the Opposition, that we also support that Bill. That Bill puts in place a charging regime for the new mobile telephone service that is to be offered for sale. At the present time, we have Optus Communications which will be the alternative telephone company in this country. It will provide a mobile service. We also have the existing AOTC service, which is called Mobilenet. The Government proposes to issue a third licence to commence in 1995 and this Bill sets up a charging regime for the licence. This is a very valuable licence which will be bid for—and I stress that point—by competing consortia to be the third mobile carrier.

It is clear from the figures that the only area of rapid growth in telephone-type services in the country at the present time—given that we are in the middle of a recession—is that of mobile telephones. Even growth in that area has slowed down a little. It is interesting to note that in our Party room only this week we had an example of the pervasiveness of mobile telephones. A member who was sitting in the room had a mobile telephone and it actually rang. We did not know whether this was the latest way of disseminating information out of party rooms—of course it was not—but it did strike a chord with all of my colleagues to the effect that mobile telephones are now becoming far more prevalent. They are part of what is happening in telecommunications. Greater convenience and greater efficiency in telecommunications is what we want to foster in this country, and utilising this technology in the best way possible is what we want to see.

This Bill is important. Interestingly, it follows the coalition's policy, which has long been to support the concept of a third mobile licence because we believe there ought to be competition, as much as possible, among these services. The Australian Telecommunication Authority, Austel, to which I referred earlier, completed a report in July last year about the mobile services and the need for a third mobile licence. That report was released in only April this year.

It seems to me that there was some nervousness on the part of the Government as to whether or not it ought to have released the report which recommended a third mobile licence. The Government held it back and it has been very nervous about embracing competition and giving the Australian community the opportunity to have a competing range of services. I suppose the Government should be congratulated on finally having crossed the line, but I expressed some concern earlier about the fact that it held back the Austel report for so long when it really confirmed what ought to have happened and what has now finally happened.

I also believe it is worth making some comment about the whole process of the selection of the mobile licensee. Whilst we want it to take place, we stress that it must be open: the whole process must be transparent. The Opposition wants to see, the community needs to see and particularly I in my office want to see a totally transparent arrangement. We do not believe the awarding of these licences ought to be done in other than an open manner. I appeal to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon), who is at the table, to make sure that we are kept fully informed about the major changes that are being proposed.

The licence will be issued in a way which takes account of the experience and financial strength of the potential bidders, industry plans, development commitments and Australian equity participation. All of those matters are indeed important, but at the end of the day we want a service which will be sustainable, truly competitive and benefit all of us in this country. That ought to be the outcome that each and every one of us seeks in this particular area, complicated as it is.

As I have said, we support these two Bills. I take the opportunity to say that I understand that the amendments—I have just been handed a copy of them—are minor in relation to the main points that are made in the legislation. As far as I can see, we do not have any concerns about those.

A problem is developing in this chamber, which I spoke about yesterday. I think it is incumbent upon those of us who are concerned about the method by which legislation is rushed through the House to raise this matter when we have the opportunity to do so. These Bills are important Bills. They propose major changes and new services in telecommunications. Yet we are here today debating them under time constraints. Many of my colleagues will not have the opportunity to speak, which I think is regrettable, and people on the other side of the chamber will not have the opportunity to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not regrettable.

—That is less regrettable. In any event, I make the point that I had to receive a briefing on one of these Bills from departmental people by way of a telephone conference. I was quite happy to do that because I have a lot of respect for those people and I have been dealing with them for some time. But I do not think that is the appropriate way in which we ought to be preparing for legislation. We have some amendments and there has not been much time to consider them in detail. If we are going to have the process of legislation by exhaustion—sitting until midnight every night and rushing through Bills without deep consideration—we will make mistakes. All we do is compound the errors because governments come back here with further amendments to pick up anomalies, drafting errors or oversights.

PARA.TAB: I think the processes in this chamber are designed to improve legislation. We did this admirably with the telecommunications legislation last year. We went through a lengthy parliamentary process and we got a better piece of legislation for it. So I make this appeal to the Government and, particularly, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). It is incumbent upon him to have a more measured program which facilitates a wider and more lengthy debate. It is not just a matter of his coming in here, dishing it up and shoving it down our throats; that is not acceptable. That is why on each and every occasion we will protest, and protest strongly, because we do not get the good legislation that the nation deserves.

I conclude by asking the new Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, to make clear at the earliest possible time what he is proposing with regard to broadcast legislation. We have been waiting for a long time to see broadcast legislation revisited in this country. The Government had a proposed Bill, for the first time in 50 years, and it has been redrawn. I do not know, as I stand here today at the dispatch box, what the Government's intentions are. I have received some information and briefings from departmental people. Obviously, with a new Minister—the fourth Minister in 12 months—there will be a revisiting of some of these issues.

With regard to pay television, it needs to be made clear that the moratorium ends on 31 October-1 November. We need to know exactly what is proposed. The legislative program is about to be completed. Senator Collins needs to make a clear statement early on so that everyone, both in the Opposition and elsewhere, knows exactly what the Government is proposing.

I will use something which fell out of my newspaper this morning to make this point. Newsvision is starting in Australia. The technology that is driving change in this particular area has to be recognised. Whilst we will all have some debate about how we address those problems, we have to make sure that legislation is technologically neutral, facilitates the march of technology and does not constrain it. If we are going to hold up the whole process because of our inability and the Government's inability to determine where and when it is going, then we, the Australian people and consumers, will be the losers. They are the very people who ought not to be the losers; they ought to be the winners.

I appeal to the Government to try to get its house in order as quickly as it can. It is getting good advice. It has good people there who are giving good advice—and, of course, we are not always going to agree with it. But the Government now has a new Minister for Transport and Communications, and it has to let us know, let the community know, and let the industry know where it is going. Any further delay, procrastination and political game playing is simply not satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I would like to pick up a couple of comments made by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and also the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). First of all, can I thank the honourable member for Bass for taking his turn in the way that he did. I am sorry he was caught short; so was I.

PARA.TAB: There are two points I want to pick up before I go to the legislation. If those opposite are going to wander around the nation making the point—and it is a valid point—that there have been some changes in the Ministry and that the new Minister for Transport and Communications is the fourth Minister that the honourable member for Bass has had in his time in the shadow portfolio, he should not repeat the claim that he just made, because it was absolutely wrong. The honourable member has exaggerated it by 25 per cent. He said that this was his fourth Minister in 12 months. It is only the third. Mr Beazley was there for 2 1/2 years, Senator Richardson was there for a few months, and now Senator Collins will be there for the duration. So he should at least keep it square, because we have to deal with these exaggerations.

Secondly, I do not think it is fair for the honourable member to come into the chamber and complain about the Government guillotining the legislation and imposing the time constraints within which we deal with it. I say that for two reasons. Those opposite understand very well why we are on this legislative timetable. It is because the Senate, which is controlled by the Opposition and the Democrats, has laid down the legislative timetable. It has said that it will not deal with legislation that comes across from this chamber after this week, and those opposite know that very well. This is important legislation, and if honourable members opposite want more time to spend on it—I would like to spend more time on it; we would all like to spend more time on it—they only have to direct their senators to give the debate a bit of time in the Senate. So it is entirely up to those opposite, and it is not reasonable to come in here and complain about the guillotine when their people are driving the timetable in the other House.

Let me go to some of the aspects of this legislation. As the honourable member for Bass indicated, those opposite are not opposing it; they are in fact supporting it. In many areas of transport and communications reform we have had quite a degree of unanimity between the Opposition and ourselves because we all understand the directions in which these industries have to go. We all understand that technology is driving us in some of the areas, and we all understand that the timetable has to be moved along. But remember, too, that it is the Opposition that is claiming that the reform process is not happening quickly enough. I am saying that the legislation has to keep pace with the reform process. Major structural changes have taken place and this legislation is now reflecting them. Decisions that have been taken and announced and will be falling into place are reflected in this legislation. So it is necessary to deal very quickly with the legislation to make it possible to do the things that we all agree have to be done. We have common ground on many of them.

Let me quickly go through some of the aspects of the dramatic reforms in the Australian economy that are reflected in this legislation. Real reforms have taken place since the return of the Government in March 1990. Real reforms have taken place which are not just things that have occurred during these two years; they are things that in some cases have been waiting 90 years to happen—90 years when there was plenty of opportunity for earlier governments to tackle them. All of a sudden they have been taken on and moved along at a dramatic pace by this Government. It is totally unreasonable to make the claim that the reform process is not happening fast enough. In fact, it is happening so quickly that many Australians cannot understand it and many Australians are uncomfortable with it. But we in this place know that, given the internationalisation of our economy and the adoption of principles such as world best practice, we cannot afford to slow that process.

For instance, I refer to the reform that has taken place on the waterfront. The honourable member for Gilmore makes great play of wandering around to the rural constituency in particular and promoting visions of things that take place on the waterfront that are at least five years out of date. I noticed an article published in the daily shipping publication where John Spiers, one of the very respected writers in the industry, makes exactly this point: those on the other side are now, for electoral opportunism, purveying myths—myths that containers do not move on the waterfront; myths that the wharfies lose stuff, and all this kind of thing; myths that we still have to get rid of all this labour on the waterfront. The fact is that we are now at the point where the stevedoring companies are saying to the Government that they need to employ new people, particularly new people who can keep pace with the technological changes that are taking place in the handling of transport equipment.

As a matter of interest, the Opposition makes enormous play of the waterfront as the area of reform that is needed in this economy. The Industry Commission analysed the waterfront last year—it was actually 18 months ago now, at the start of this process—and indicated that it was a $1 billion per annum problem for the Australian economy; there were $1 billion worth of inefficiencies in the system. The same Industry Commission analysis assessed the road-rail imbalance, the misuse of road transport as against rail transport in this country, and drew a conclusion that that was a $8 billion problem. In other words, it was eight times the problem of the waterfront in this country, caused by a dilapidated rail structure and misinvestment of funds to encourage road transport in areas where rail transport was clearly the desired form.

Major reforms have taken place in the past two years in road and rail transport. As a matter of interest, I would suggest that the most glaring example of this imbalance used to be the 2,000 trucks a day driving up and down the Hume Highway parallel to a standard gauge railway line carrying containers. If we have a look at the Hume Highway now, we will see that there are not nearly as many trucks on it, but the trucks that are on it are specialist transport vehicles. The containers are in fact on the rail. There has been a major shift. That is the way it should be, for a whole lot of reasons to which most Australians continually point.

Those reforms are taking place. The most dramatic reform of the lot has been the formation of the National Rail Corporation; the bringing together of the States to agree to the principle that we will abandon four different State railway systems and three different railway gauges. We will cooperate in the formation of a National Rail Corporation and we will finally build the standard gauge rail between Brisbane and Sydney and between Adelaide and Melbourne to give Australia one standard rail freight system from Perth through Melbourne to Brisbane.

Those changes do not take place just in a vacuum; they take place under a government that is prepared to, first, commit funds to public sector expenditure—and I want to come to this point in a minute—and, second, say to industry, `This has to be done sensibly and this is how it is going to happen'. Those changes are falling in place dramatically.

I turn quickly to the issue of AOTC and the opening up of Australia's telephone network to competition. We all understand that our major telecommunications provider, Telecom, needed an injection of competition to make it more sensitive to customer requirements and to gear it up for a much expanded international role. The Government chose to do that by merging OTC and Telecom into the new AOTC and introducing a competitor in the form of Optus. For the first time in 90 years in this country, the communications system has been opened up for challenge. It is a dramatic change. It is a difficult change for the 80,000 Telecom employees to accept. They are working their way through these processes. The new board of AOTC, under the new Chief General Manager, Mr Frank Blount, has developed a business plan by which it will approach the competition. It is well aware that the new communications competitor, Optus, will win a share of the market and it is well aware that its capacity to retain market share will be based particularly on customer service.

The employees of AOTC, as it is now called, have a very big charter before them, that is, to be part of an organisation which is dramatically changing. It is under a price cap. We as a government are not lifting the price cap regime. We are allowing, as this legislation provides, for some liberalisation of the tariff structures so that AOTC can respond to changes that come through competition. The overall price cap of inflation minus four, I think it is at the moment, remains intact.

That is a very interesting challenge that AOTC faces in a low inflation economy. When inflation was running at 6 or 7 per cent, we set Telecom, as it was in those days, a pricing regime whereby its prices had to reduce in real terms; they had to be the inflation rate minus a factor of two, three or four. That is still in place at a time when inflation in the economy has fallen to below 2 per cent. That means that the pricing regime, the revenue from call charges, has to go backwards in real terms. That is a real challenge for an organisation which has been through a lot of change and a lot of discipline from the Government as its shareholder—discipline which came with the election of the Labor Government.

As I said, there are many areas on which we have common ground. Were there more time to peruse the legislation in the way that the honourable member for Bass would like, I am sure there would not be all that much that we would be at odds on, as he understands. However, there is an area where there will be considerable difference between the Government and the Opposition as we move a little further down the track, that is, the future of these organisations—whether they remain in public ownership, whether the Government and the people of Australia continue to own them, or whether we move down the Opposition's road of flogging them off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—I am sorry. Is the honourable member for Bass offended by the term `flogging them off'? Would he like me to rephrase that? There is no need for him to interject again. He would like me to say `the Opposition's plan to offer them for sale to whoever'. That is undefined; it could be foreigners or whoever. `To offer them for sale' is a nice parliamentary way of saying `flogging them off'. I think I refer to it in a way that most Australians understand.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that there will be a very major debate over the issue of privatisation of organisations such as Telecom, Australia Post, our airports, the Commonwealth Bank and many other public assets that many of us will argue should stay in public ownership because they are performing well; they are now operating under a commercial structure and providing the dividends that the taxpayer is entitled to receive from them. That will be a debate. I know where the Australian public will be when we get to the end of that debate.

There will also be a big difference—and it is interesting that I relate this to transport—in the area of pricing structure. The difference in pricing structure comes through the issue of the proposed goods and services tax, the GST. I have not yet found a tourist organisation or a tourist operator—perhaps the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) will be able to tell me when he speaks—who thinks it is a wonderful idea that there will be a 15 per cent increase on air fares, hotel rooms, motel rooms, meals and all the other things that are associated with the tourism industry, which, of course, is so dependent on the transport sector. That is one little factor where there will be a difference. When we talk about the price cap on AOTC and on the charging for telecommunications, in comes a nice little 15 per cent consumption tax on one's phone bill. The effect of that has to go into the inflation factor.

When I was thinking about the claim that the Opposition will abolish seven taxes and have just one big tax, I was thinking in terms of the ordinary football fan who uses our transport services to go to the football. In Melbourne that person will have seven new taxes: tax on the tram fare; tax on the footy Record on the way in; tax on the ticket at the gate; tax on the drink; tax on the pie; tax on the bet down at the TAB; and tax on the tram fare going home. There will be seven new taxes for the footy follower, but at the same time John Elliott's corporate box up in the MCG will have a big tax deduction with the changes in company tax claims. There will be a tax deduction for the corporate sector but a full 15 per cent load-on for the ordinary football fan in the outer. There will be a 15 per cent tax on the tram fare of the public transport user going there and back, but there will be a discount for the company car and a discount for the footy box for the corporate sector.

They are the sorts of factors that will come into the GST equation. While that will be one level of debate, I think some very serious thought needs to be given to the fact that we are jointly saying that it is a wonderful idea to drive AOTC with its tariff pricing with an inflation minus X factor while one of the parties in this Parliament, the Opposition, is touting a consumption tax that would drive that whole formula out the window. I think the Opposition has to do some serious thinking about its application of a consumption tax to phone bills and how it would approach the question of Telecom's pricing regime—before it sells Telecom off—under the current inflation minus X factor.

On behalf of the Government, I certainly welcome the fact that the Opposition is supporting the legislation. Obviously, it reflects the fact that we have common ground. It is sensible and there is no real debate about the issues. We have different views about why we are under such time restraints in passing this legislation through. The common ground that exists now is going to give way to major debate and major disputation between the Government and the Opposition over the Opposition's plans to privatise these public sector operations and over its plans to introduce a goods and services tax which will affect every transport charge in the nation. I think that is a fair summary of the way the debate will unfold. I thank the House for the opportunity to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) was drawing a pretty long bow when he talked about the effect of the coalition's taxation policy on the tourist industry as part of his speech on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I must say in response to him that he has again run the line that a 15 per cent tax is to be added to everything; he has certainly got a few of his statements wrong. He can tell his constituents that they will not have to pay a GST on the bet when they go to the football, because that is a financial transaction, as I understand the situation.

PARA.TAB: He does not say, for example, that the major airlines will be saving themselves something like $9.5m per year in payroll tax. He does not talk about the 27c a litre saving for the general aviation industry through the avgas levy. Most importantly, he does not talk about the real liberalisation of the Australian international airline regime. I was surprised that he did not, because the One Nation statement that we had from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in February, made great play of this. Here we are sitting back terribly excited about it because the Government in fact pinched half our policies and we congratulate it for that; we are at last seeing some sense in it.

The plain fact is that, five months down the track, absolutely nothing has happened. We are dying for the day when some of the brave statements that the Prime Minister made actually come in as policy for this country, because the one thing that will open up Australian tourism is making sure that we get that correct international aviation regime. On all that hangs all the law and the prophets. Once we get that system right and we have, as suggested by the Industries Commission, a 20 per cent reduction in the price of international airfares into Australia, then those opposite will be able to watch tourism boom and watch the jobs it creates. In government, we are going to do that. Mr Deputy Speaker, although this Bill has absolutely nothing to do with the coalition taxation regime, I very much appreciate being able to intervene in that respect.

The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) does not provide too many difficulties for the Opposition in terms of the aviation sector. Only one section, clause 15, is to be amended. That is the clause covering the Civil Aviation Authority and the situation of statutory liens; I will debate that a little further on. But the rest of it does not cause us too many problems at all.

The Air Navigation Act amendment, which changes the protocols to be scheduled to the Act, is one on which I would like to make a couple of comments. This is really of no great concern inasmuch as, as I understand the situation, the size of the ICAO committees are going to be expanded to allow the admission of the Commonwealth of Independent States following the break-up of the Soviet Union and a change of the regimes in Eastern Europe, and we would welcome that. But there are very few opportunities in this House to pay tribute to some of the work that Australia has done over very many years in terms of international civil aviation.

This ICAO amendment gives, I think, a real chance for us to put on the record some of the things that Australia has done, because Australia has been involved since 1944. It was one of the original participants in the first conference in Montreal in that year. Australia, along with New Zealand, was one of the foremost countries to submit a draft convention to that initial conference, which very much looked at the development of international civil aviation around the world. It is interesting that Australia and New Zealand, Canada, Great Britain and the United States were there.

It is quite fascinating to go back through history to see the proposals to govern civil aviation that were put up at that stage. They included one by the Americans for open slather in international civil aviation. I wonder whether the people from the Department of Transport and Communications who go to America to negotiate on behalf of Australia wonder just how genuine the Americans have been from 1944 to this present day in terms of our access to their markets in aviation.

Australia and New Zealand proposed at that very early meeting an even more radical concept, the international ownership and management of all long-range international services. I think a lot of us would probably cringe now if that proposition were put to us. But the really interesting part about ICAO and the work it has done is simply the fact that while there were some requirements for ICAO to meet certain standards in the composition of the Council, including some geographical requirements and some other requirements in terms of technical capability, the major countries really took control. Places such as Canada, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK, China and the United States have always been in there, but so has Australia.

Australia has been there despite the fact that, while we have a tremendous record—that is probably why we are there—we really have a very small international aviation industry compared with some of the other countries. Australia has always held a seat in either the category 1 or category 2 area of the Council. It is interesting that, when unsuccessful in its bid for a seat as an important aeronautical state, it has always been virtually guaranteed a seat as a major contributor of facilities or by virtue of its geographical position. This is despite the fact that countries such as Singapore or Korea have a greater aviation industry than we do. Surprisingly, we are still regarded very much as being an integral and necessary part of the governing body of international civil aviation. I think that speaks a great deal for the people who have gone before us and the role Australia plays in terms of the governance of international aviation. So we welcome that particular amendment with regard to the Air Navigation Act and the ICAO requirements.

The Federal Airports Corporations amendments do not worry us too much. We certainly go along with the Government in terms of the requirement for the Federal Airports Corporation to look after its own environmental impact costs, and we agree with the transitional arrangements for the FAC and the CAA in terms of the changes in their nature and requirements of the taxation Act.

I would like to mention very briefly, though, clause 15, which is up for amendment today. Clause 15 is amending section 75 of the Act because under section 69 of the Act the Civil Aviation Authority is empowered to recover any unpaid charges owing to it by imposing liens over aircraft. As I understand the situation, the proposed amendments are designed so that the CAA statutory liens are to have priority over all other financial security interests, including pre-existing mortgagees. There are a number of conditions that must be met, we admit, before the CAA can move there. But I must say there is a great deal of concern, particularly within the general aviation industry, on just what the ramifications of that CAA requirement in the Act might bring about.

For example, one of the propositions that has been put up to us is the fact that private companies, such as leasing companies and hire purchase companies, that might be involved in selling aircraft would have to make an appropriate adjustment in terms of charges, if the Civil Aviation Authority had that provision and there was open slather. It is our intention to vote against clause 15 because basically we believe that the Authority already has that protection of the first bite in section 69 and if it were to have that overriding power some very real concerns would be caused. So I flag to the Minister that in the committee stage we will oppose that proposal.

I think there is a great deal of concern within the general aviation community as to just what its future might be. I mentioned in a speech in the last week of sitting that last year around Australia we saw something of a decline of 14 per cent in the amount of activity in the general aviation industry. The concern that we have—I know that people on the Government side also have it—is about the cost impact of the full cost recovery program. Let me make it perfectly clear: the Opposition is all for cost recovery programs, but we have to make sure that any cost recovery is done on the right base, one that can be afforded by the industry and that is fair to the industry. It does not really matter whether we are talking about flying a Cessna 402 or a Boeing 747; we can argue about whether or not some of the charges that have been proposed in recent times by the Government are fair and equitable.

I know that Qantas would argue very much against the proposed safety levy charge. In fact, Qantas would have to be one of the safest airlines operating in the world. It has a huge department that does nothing but regulate Qantas operations. When one looks at the record of Qantas, one sees it has done a marvellous job. But on top of doing that sort of thing, it was then supposed to come up with another bill for millions and millions of dollars to make a contribution to the Government's police force, we assume, in just looking at whatever Qantas was doing. I think that we sometimes get misconceptions about the aviation industry. Those in the industry are not always a mob of cowboys; they are very responsible people, and when they go flying their own lives are involved in terms of flying operations. I sometimes wonder whether we should sit back and have a good look at exactly what we are imposing through the Civil Aviation Authority in terms of some of the regulations and charges as part of that cost recovery program.

In government I would certainly be looking at having a full review of the cost recovery program to make sure that if we go down the path of cost recovery, we have an equitable situation for all concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum which deals with the three amendments. The first amendment will insert two new clauses in the Bill which will make some minor technical amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988. The first is a new clause 13A, which will correct a typographical error in paragraph 20AA(1)(a) of the Civil Aviation Act. New clause 13A will also amend subsection 20AA(4) to clarify that it is an offence for an aircraft to commence a flight unless it has a maintenance release that is valid for the duration of the flight. The second new clause inserted by amendment No. 1 is new clause 13B, which corrects a typographical error in subsection 32AF(4) of the Civil Aviation Act.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 2 inserts four new clauses in part 10 of the Bill, which amends the Telecommunications Act 1991. These new clauses, together with the proposed Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill 1992, will enable a fee to be charged for the grant of the third public mobile licence and an allocation process for the selection of the licensee to be determined by the Minister.

The amendments are of a technical nature and do not affects the objects, underlying principles or general thrust of the Act. They provide a greater degree of commercial certainty about payment arrangements and the allocation process for mobile licences at a time when parties are considering whether to make substantial investments in developing proposals for the selection of Australia's third public mobile licensee.

New clauses 43A and 43B will amend the Telecommunications Act to enable the Minister to determine a new allocation system for granting new public mobile licences. A charge will be imposed on the grant of a new public mobile licence by clause 4 of the Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill 1992.

New clause 43D will insert a new division 5A in part 5 of the Telecommunications Act which will enable the collection and recovery of the public mobile licence charge. New clause 43C will amend the Act to make a minor consequential amendment to section 70 to ensure that the third public mobile carrier will be able, if it chooses, to enter into an agreement with the Commonwealth preventing the exercise of the power under new section 57A to grant further public mobile licences.

Amendment No. 3 will amend the proposed new paragraph 183(3)(b) of the Telecommunications Act 1991, to be inserted by clause 45 of the Bill to correct a technical defect in the amendment. The amended provision will ensure that AOTC can proceed with proposed concessions to be offered to all beneficiaries of the current telephone rental concession scheme. I know that the shadow Minister wants to say something. I would just say that I have taken note of the objections he has raised in terms of the Civil Aviation Act. However, I think they are addressed adequately in the amendments which have been moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make two quick points. Firstly, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) made the allegation that I was 25 per cent wrong in my counting of former Ministers. In fact, I think he is wrong, because the now Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin) was a Minister for communications for a time. I hope the honourable member will take the opportunity to make a public apology for his attack on me. It might be that those on the Government side of the chamber forget who their Ministers are, but active shadow Ministers on this side of the chamber certainly know who the Ministers are.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make about the amendments is by way of a qualification. It relates to clause 43C, which makes an amendment to section 70 of the principal Act to enable carriers to enter into agreements which I have described as being anti-competitive. I make the point that, in the event that a third mobile carrier enters into an agreement with the Commonwealth under section 70 of the principal Act, it would be doing so in a manner that would, in our view, restrict competition.

There are difficulties in that the existing carriers—and particularly the Optus mobile service—would have the benefit of a section 70 agreement, and it would be unfair, I suspect, to leave the third mobile carrier out there on its own. We would address this broad issue of the problem, as we perceive it, of section 70 at the time we came to government, and it is important that anyone who purchases should do so under the knowledge that we have a different view about this matter. We will not seek to amend or divide now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe there are five minutes left for debate on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The Parliament is entitled to use up all of this time. I would like to raise a couple of matters of concern to me. One of them has been raised by the shadow Minister for aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), and that is the decision to give the CAA special rights in terms of other people's debts. The Australian Taxation Office has that right, but the fact that the CAA has been made a corporation is, to my mind, every reason why it must stand with all other corporations in terms of recovery of its debts. I hope the Government will take account of that point.

PARA.TAB: It is notable that the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), in making some remarks about the waterfront in relation to some of the navigational aspects of this legislation, accused one of the Opposition's spokesmen of being at least five years out of date. I presume he was suggesting that some of the current reforms are worth while.

I remind the honourable member that in Western Australia the other day the owner of a small ship contracted successfully to cart 700 tonnes of potatoes from Western Australia to Mauritius. I am sure that would help the balance of payments. Nevertheless, when he discovered that the established stevedores wanted $36 a tonne to load his small ship, he put an advertisement in the newspaper to get a competing quote. The competing quote he got was $7.50 a tonne. I say to anybody who thinks that the charge of $36 a tonne is a measure of success that, clearly, it is not.

Irrespective of the improvements that may have occurred, we still have a gap of about $28 a tonne in terms of loading freight of that nature in Fremantle. That is outrageous, and it must have an effect on the ability of primary producers such as potato growers to do something about it. The WWF picketed to make sure that the private contractor could not get in, and in the end the Western Australian Potato Marketing Authority cancelled his contract—not worrying, apparently, about our competitive situation. I give notice that I will bring private members legislation before this Parliament in the near future to correct that situation which presently allows the Western Australian Potato Marketing Authority to say who grows potatoes in Western Australia, be they for export or otherwise.

I say in the couple of minutes remaining to me that there is considerable debate regarding the role of AOTC and its rationalisation project. I note that many other members are expressing concern about what are basically attempts to achieve efficiency through centralisation to very large or capital cities. I have had considerable correspondence with Mr Blount on this matter because there is plenty of evidence to show that, whilst rationalisation of the work force is something we naturally support, it does not have to be by concentration in capital cities. If Mr Blount, a new arrival in Australia, were to ring Australia Post, he would discover the disaster that was the centralisation of mail sorting in times gone by. If he were to ring the Australian Securities Commission he would find that it has located in the Latrobe Valley with a very high level of success in terms of absenteeism and staff turnover. It is operating very successfully in that semi-rural area. I would like him to think that he can cut back, but not by way of centralisation to the cities.
