TALK.START.PARA: —While the coalition will not be opposing the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill, we do intend to move an amendment, which has been circulated. Basically, it insists that consultation be held with the respective States and the Municipal Association of Tasmania, in the case of Tasmania, and the Local Government Association of the Northern Territory, in the case of the Northern Territory, in relation to clause 4 on page 2 of the Bill. I think the reason for this is fairly obvious: it will mean that on any decision made in relation to this funding there will be consultation with the appropriate State or Territory authority.

PARA.TAB: In saying that we will not oppose this Bill, I think it is worth going through a bit of the background to this legislation and the changes that have been brought about. The most significant thing is what was said in 1991. The Government said that it would be moving to general purpose grants or funding for local government and that the funding that would be going to local roads would no longer be tied. A significant part of the 1991 second reading speech on the Bill said that the Government guaranteed to provide a real term funding guarantee for local government general purpose funding `on the understanding that Australia did not experience a major deterioration in its economic circumstances'. There would be a real term funding guarantee on that basis.

There is now a very serious concern facing local government, which is becoming increasingly apprehensive because the question is, quite simply: has Australia experienced a major deterioration in its economic circumstances? I think all honourable members would be well aware of the difficulties that this country is facing thanks very much to the recession we had to have and its architect, the man who now calls himself the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

The question again is: will that funding be maintained? I do not think local government got much joy out of the answer the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) gave in this place yesterday when he was asked whether the Government was, as hinted by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), considering increasing taxes. The Treasurer is reported today as having said that as the Government:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . sits down to put together this Budget—
that is, the coming Budget—
it will be concerned, once again, to exercise the kind of restraint on expenditures. . .

Given that, I think it is very important that the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) give an assurance to local government that whatever that restraint on expenditures will be, the Government will nonetheless still honour the undertaking to provide a real term funding guarantee for local government. Otherwise, I think local government will again be the one that suffers.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that with a major deterioration of Australia's economic circumstances that could be here, the Government has to give a very clear answer. When we talk about government cuts, we all know that this Government has not cut Commonwealth spending anything like it has cut spending in other levels of government. While one might accept that some cuts had to be made, particularly to some State budgets, we still would argue very strongly—and we have put the case very strongly in the Fightback package—that there is opportunity to make further cuts to Commonwealth spending. It would almost appear, from the Government's putting in that escape clause back in 1991, that it is still intent on making other levels of government pay for the mess it has made of our national economy.

As I said, the coalition does not oppose this Bill. We accept that giving local government more flexibility and more responsibility for the money it spends will probably lead to more accountability and better decision making at the most appropriate level. We are certainly pleased to see that this funding will be identified for a further three years. But I think we have to remind ourselves of the appalling record that the Labor Government has in road funding.

In the nine years since this Government came into office, road funding has fallen in real terms by about 20 per cent. Yet at the same time, fuel excise—that is, the tax that has been taken from the road users, the motorists—has increased by a staggering 120 per cent. So when we look at the so-called increase in road funding that was announced in the February statement, if we do the analysis carefully, we see that that one-off increase to road funding will restore the level of road funding only to what it was when this Government first came into power. It really is the Government saying, `We have taken it all off you. We are now just going to give a bit back. It is a one-off situation'.

TALK.START.PARA: —To do a few repairs.

—To do a few repairs, and not much more, as my colleague the honourable member for Maranoa has pointed out. We have to look at what the effect of these cutbacks has been on our roads. We have seen a rapid deterioration in the road network. People who travel around this country as some of us do—on this side at least—will find that the deterioration is causing grave concern to both State and local government. We have heard of sealed roads now being ripped up and of the danger of potholes. We know that the age of more than half of our network is well past 20 years and rapidly approaching what would be called the normal lifespan.

PARA.TAB: Another matter concerning local government is some of the furphies being put around by Government members in relation to what the Fightback package will do for local government. I want to make it very clear that people in local government are not fools. They have done some very careful analysis. For example, the Municipal Association of Victoria, the MAV, did some analysis some time ago. It has re-examined that analysis because some of the Labor candidates in the next election seem to have a propensity for getting it wrong more than right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Government.
—That is right. I think of one particular gentleman who is campaigning for a seat that he lost so spectacularly at the last election. The paper points out:

PARA.TAB: In the December 1991 review of GST it was concluded that local government would `marginally' benefit from the proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: The paper revisits the whole thing. It continues:
Now that a more thorough examination and modelling of the impact of GST on Victorian local government has been completed, the same conclusion emerges.

I hope that the Minister, being the responsible person that I know he is, will take note of that and tell some of his less responsible colleagues that they ought to be a little more cautious in running around making very misleading statements. The paper goes on to point out another factor in relation to the GST and the Fightback package:
The administrative costs involved in councils' running GST, according to external expert advice, appear to be minimal.

Again, that is a significant factor and one that many people have been trying to misrepresent. I put those two points up because it is terribly important that we correct the misunderstandings that some honourable members opposite are trying, irresponsibly, to peddle. `Mistruths' would be the correct word, Mr Deputy Speaker, would it not?

PARA.TAB: Knowing that some of my colleagues wish to speak to the legislation, I just reiterate that we do not oppose the legislation, that we do have an eminently sensible amendment and that I hope the Government will take it on board. I also raise the very serious question about whether or not the Government is prepared to give a cast iron guarantee that the funding will be maintained in real terms despite the blow-out in the Budget deficit and the very serious mess that this Government has got the economy into. As has been pointed out, we believe very strongly that the introduction of the Fightback package would be of great benefit not only to the whole nation but also, and particularly in this case, to local government. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 2, line 36, after "Minister" insert "after consultation with the respective States and the Municipal Association of Tasmania in the case of Tasmania and the Local Government Association of the Northern Territory in the case of the Northern Territory".

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to recap a little on the matters raised by the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) in his second reading speech, even though he is at the table and obviously knows what is going on, because it is important to understand that the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill relates to the untying of financial assistance to local government and to an improvement in the way that local government is able to administer its road funds.

PARA.TAB: Since the interim arrangements were agreed to in 1991—of course, that all arose from the Premiers Conference in 1990—there have been extensive consultations with local government. I do not believe credit for that was given by the Opposition in the speech by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), the Opposition spokesperson, a moment ago. These consultations were marked by a positive attitude and a genuine desire on the part of all the parties to develop arrangements acceptable to everybody concerned. The Minister at the table is renowned for his ability to consult in a meaningful fashion with people around the nation. I congratulate him on that ability and the fact that he gets very good results as a consequence.

Therefore, the arrangements contained in the Bill reflect the advice and suggestions obtained through the consultation process and, as a consequence, the Bill ensures that funding will continue to be identified separately rather than absorbed into general purpose assistance, and that is an important factor for local government. It will also ensure that each State's share of the funding level of some $300m will be maintained at its present proportion and that the arrangements will operate for a three-year period. That is important too, because local government needs certainty, as does State government and Federal government, in its funding. It enables local government to make plans on a triennial basis as so many organisations in Australia now have the ability to do because this Government has made triennial funding one of its planks.

The funds will be distributed in each State on the basis of principles reflecting road needs and legislation will no longer provide specific allocations for special roads works; rather the funding of such works may be provided for in the principles which will govern the distribution of funds in each State.

That is important because it is not always possible for local government to anticipate the needs of either associated local government areas or, in fact, the State itself. Some sort of cooperation is essential if we are to have proper road funding allocation which meets the needs of the broader community as well as the local community.

The 1991-92 funding will be untied and able to be spent entirely at the discretion of the local governing body. The commitment the Government previously gave to maintain the funding in real terms will be honoured. I note that my colleague who spoke previously, the shadow Minister, was trying to intimate that that might not be the case, but I am sure that this Government will make adequate provision for local government road funding, as it has done in the past.

It is no good people on the other side of the Parliament talking about the Government's road funding as if it will somehow be worse than the Opposition's road funding. In fact, the Opposition does have in Fightback a proposal to reduce the financial assistance to these types of organisations by 5 per cent. That does equate to a very large segment of funds—approximately $35m in this current financial year—so people should not be misunderstanding that Fightback has the potential to be troublesome for local government, irrespective of what the previous speaker said.

We have, on this side of the House, a great commitment to local government. We understand that it is an essential tier of the administration structure of Australia. In fact, it was a Labor government that gave recognition to local government many years ago—about 1972 or 1973—as a proper entity in the Australian system of government. It was also a Labor government that tried to ensure that the Constitution was changed to recognise local government. Unfortunately, the people did not agree or were not able to understand the arguments sufficiently to agree that local government should be recognised in the Constitution as an entity.

As I have already mentioned, the distribution of funds between local governing bodies in each State will be in accordance with the principles reflecting road needs. It is important to realise that, given the size of Australia and the way the population is distributed, local government has had an extremely important role to play in the past and will always continue to have in the years to come.

The place of local government in our society is secure. In many instances State governments are challenged, but local government is seen to have a very important and continuing role. These days its responsibilities are many and varied; they used to be simply roads and rubbish. In fact, the name `Roads Board' came from the main function it provided. There is now less emphasis on roads and rubbish; there is more emphasis on social and other infrastructure. But roads are still a very important factor of many local governments in this country, particularly in rural areas.

The importance and the distinction of local government is that it is a grassroots form of government—it has touch with the local people. But the fact still remains that some local government bodies have not always applied road funds in the most beneficial way. We all know of some appalling stories of the odd road being sealed out to a mayor's property or what have you. None of us wants to see that sort of thing continuing. The way that the Government is approaching road funding in this particular Bill and in its previous Bill ensures that there is discussion and consultation, albeit that local government still has its own discretion in terms of how the road funds should be applied. I do believe that that is important, though, because planning for a whole region must involve local government. Local government cannot be seen to be a totally separate tier of government from the other levels—State and Federal.

Obviously, some local government regions have a much greater need for road funds than others. An assessment of that need may vary over time. For instance, outer metropolitan areas in the northern suburbs of Perth—where my electorate is—have a need for road funds to link new housing or commercial estates with local facilities. These are definitely seen as local roads, not arterial roads. We have a lot of problems in the Wanneroo region in particular, which is a very fast growing region; it claims to be the fastest growing region in Australia. It has a lot of difficulty keeping up with the needs of the community in terms of road funding. I know that the changes that have been made here, and the certainty with which the funds will be allocated over the triennium, will be welcomed by the council there.

It is worth mentioning in this context that current works associated with an upsurge of activity and construction in the Wanneroo region, under the auspices of the Joondalup Development Corporation, will result in a complex which combines intellectual, tourist, commercial, housing and hospital health facilities as well as local government administration. Obviously, none of these things can exist, survive or be linked to each other without adequate road funding.

I am glad to hear that the Opposition does not intend to oppose the Bill, but I exhort the members of the House to support this change. It is a very crucial one for local government, not only for its continuity but also for it to play its part properly in the patchwork quilt which actually is Australian administration of infrastructure. We certainly cannot underplay and understate the role of local government. I congratulate the Minister on having had the consultations about the way this funding will be administered. I am sure that local government will welcome the change.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill provides identified road funding for local government over the next three years, from 1992-93 through to 1994-95. It is very pleasing that support for local government these days enjoys broad community acceptance. All sides of politics recognise the vital role of local government in our community and the responsibility that the Federal tier of government has to assist financially to ensure that local government is able to effectively carry out its functions.

PARA.TAB: This Bill reinforces that commitment. I am interested—as the shadow Minister for land transport, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), said in his response to this particular Bill—to note that the Government has put a condition on its commitment to future funding to local government; namely, that there is no serious deterioration in our national economic circumstances. It seems to me that that commitment has got the Government into something of a bind. Is the Government saying that the trebling of our Budget deficit—or quadrupling or whatever the figure may be by the end of the financial year—is not a gross deterioration in our financial circumstances which may, in fact, throw open the question of whether the Government's commitment to local government is going to be honoured? Or is the Government actually saying that this is not a serious deterioration; that it intended to do it all along and therefore local government has got nothing to worry about? I think local government councils everywhere are concerned that this Government's word on this occasion will be about as reliable as it has been on many other occasions and that the commitments that have been made are indeed on very shaky territory.

Federal assistance to local government comes basically in two parts: through the untied general purpose grants, currently amounting to some $719m, which are distributed amongst the various States on a per capita basis; and through the identified grants for local roads, set currently at $307m, which are distributed amongst the States on a local needs basis. These road fundings for local roads will be identified but untied; in other words, there is no specific obligation on local government to actually spend the money on roads when it gets it. However, one would hope that the public discipline of the democratic process would ensure that every local authority guarantees that the moneys that it receives for road funding are, in fact, spent for that purpose. Indeed, a lot more should be spent by councils because they clearly have a joint responsibility to care for local roads and to assist in funding them.

It is appropriate that the Commonwealth should assist councils to fund their local roads. A lot of fuel is purchased to drive on local roads, and so a lot of tax is paid by local motorists. The fuel tax receipts of this Government have multiplied many times since it has been in office, but it has largely frozen road funding. Motorists have certainly been given a raw deal.

It was a welcome change to see, for the first time, a reasonable boost in road funding incorporated in the One Nation statement. It needs to be remembered that the Government is not giving anything to motorists that they have not already paid for. In actual fact, this boost in road funding will be comfortably funded by bracket creep, by the increases in excise compulsorily levied on motorists by the Government automatically twice a year.

Whilst we welcome the boost in funding—the first break in the freeze in the history of Labor in government—it will not go nearly far enough to restore the road system, which has been allowed to deteriorate under this Government. In particular, it will give local authorities the opportunity to recover some of the lost ground.

I commend the fact that the distribution of funds under the local roads program between the States will be on a needs basis. As I mentioned earlier, the general purpose grants are distributed on a per capita basis—so much per head. It would be completely inappropriate to use that kind of technique to administer road funding. In each State there are different road lengths, different road building conditions and different needs. For instance, while Western Australia will get 16.3 per cent of the funds for local roads, South Australia will get only 5.8 per cent, even though their populations do not differ much. No-one could argue that South Australia has the same road responsibilities or needs as does a vast State such as Western Australia. Queensland will get 20 per cent of the funding.

It could be argued that Queensland is not generously treated by that kind of distribution. Queensland has a very extensive road network. It is the second largest State, but it is very decentralised and has its population spread right through its area. Indeed, there are particular climatic difficulties which make road building in Queensland particularly difficult and expensive. Flooding occurs regularly; Queensland needs many more high level bridges than the other States. Bridges can be very expensive: a couple of million dollars spent on bridgeworks sometimes builds only a few hundred metres of bridge. There is a case for Queensland being allocated a larger proportion of local road funding.

It could be said that similar arguments apply to the general purpose grants. It seems to be totally inconsistent for local government general purpose grants to be distributed amongst the States on a per capita basis. Local governments in the different States have different needs: their cost structures are different; their disabilities are different; and, most fundamental of all, their functions in each State are different. Local governments in each of the Australian States have different responsibilities. Yet, the funding for local government is distributed amongst the States strictly on a per capita basis. It is a system that very generously advantages New South Wales and Victoria, but seriously disadvantages Queensland and the other States.

Fiscal equalisation principles, in other words needs based funding, applies for all other distributions of Commonwealth funding. Indeed, the States are required to use fiscal equalisation principles in distributing general purpose grants amongst the various local authorities. But when funds are divided amongst the States, for some completely inexplicable and totally unjustifiable reason, it is done on a per capita basis. It must have a fair bit to do with the political power of New South Wales and Victoria, their enormous domination of the Federal Cabinet and their domination of so much of the political processes in this country. There is a very strong case to extend needs based funding in distribution principles for general purpose grants for local government.

The States also are not equal: some are larger, some have small populations, and climate and industry factors are different. In this instance, the Federal Government divides the funds amongst the States on fiscal equalisation principles. I ask again: why is local government treated differently?

The Federal Government has a great deal of power in influencing the economic growth and prospective fortunes of each of the States. It decides where government departments are located, what projects are going to be supported and whether there will be tariff protection, which of course benefits the manufacturing States—particularly Victoria. There has been an enormous transfer of wealth between the Australian States because of the intervention of government policies. That is a normal aspect of the processes and business of government.

One other factor which ensures that the States of New South Wales and Victoria enjoy an advantage over the more widespread States is the head office mentality. The fact is that most large corporations and companies—even those that generate most of their wealth in the outer areas—tend to have their head offices in Sydney and Melbourne. There is a transfer of taxing capacity to the State governments in New South Wales and Victoria and the local governments of New South Wales and Victoria as a result of the location of those head offices in the capital cities of New South Wales and Victoria.

There is a strong case for taking those kinds of factors into account when determining the way in which we distribute Commonwealth grants to State and local government. I strongly support the view that fiscal equalisation philosophies should be used in the distribution of all Commonwealth grants to local government and, as a result of this Bill, this principle will be used for local roads. That principle should be also extended to the last remaining area of per capita distribution—general purpose grants. That is essential if we believe in balance and fairness.

There are often arguments, even within the States, about the way the funds should be distributed. I was quite surprised to see the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Alderman Soorley, complaining bitterly in the Sunday press last weekend about the distribution in Queensland. He was backed up by some of his Labor allies—the Mayor of Ipswich and the Mayor of Townsville—in complaining that the cities are doing badly compared with the country areas.

I deplore the attempts by Alderman Soorley to destroy the Local Government Association and the unity of local government by introducing quite foolish arguments of the nature that he tried to portray over last weekend. It is essential for local governments to work and stick together to ensure that they are well treated in these sorts of issues.

The fact is—Alderman Soorley ought to know this—that it was the Federal ALP Government that insisted on the criteria that are used for distributing grants in Queensland. The former Federal Minister for Local Government persistently refused to accept the criteria that existed in the past, which were more generous towards the cities, and insisted that these criteria be adopted. On one occasion Senator Reynolds, when she was Minister for Local Government, actually refused to accept the Grants Commission's recommendations and carved the grants up herself. She used her discretion in deciding which councils got the money.

In Queensland, the Goss Labor Government has dismissed all the Queensland grants commissioners and has appointed its own people. We have a formula designed and administered by Labor, and now the Labor Lord Mayor of Brisbane is complaining that he is treated unfairly. It hardly seems a reasonable argument.

If one looks at the some of the conservative city and shire councils like the Gold Coast, Albert, Toowoomba, Redland and Caloundra—the places that vote Liberal and National—one finds that those places get considerably less money than the Lord Mayor of Brisbane or the Mayor of Ipswich. I suggest that they should be very quiet. They should acknowledge the fact that they are being very generously treated under the current arrangements and acknowledge that the processes have been put in place by their political mates.

The only criticism that Lord Mayor Soorley makes that has some validity is that the people of Brisbane get $21 a head from their local government grant, whereas the people of Canberra get $42 a head. I suppose that is par for the course—Canberra getting twice as much as all other cities—but it would be interesting to see what justification the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) might have for that kind of distribution.

The facts are that road funding is one of the most important elements of the local government budget. Local roads are vital arteries; they carry most of the national wealth. The Government at the Federal level has accepted a responsibility for the national arterials. But most of the mines are not on national arterials; most of the farms are not on the arterial roads; most of the residential suburbs are not on arterial roads; neither are the resort hotels nor the tourist attractions. They are essential, yet they are maintained by local government by local ratepayers.

We therefore have a clear national obligation to contribute also to the local roads system, particularly now that the Federal Government is opting out of its responsibilities to local aerodromes and the States have closed rural rail services. Country roads have become absolutely critical. This Bill recognises that and I congratulate the Government on making a commitment, for three years, of reliable funding for local roads to local government.

We are concerned at some aspects of the untying of these grants but there will be no diminution in the effort on roads. Local, State and Commonwealth governments have this joint responsibility to ensure that the national wealth, the national prosperity, is able to travel to our export ports through the use of an efficient and well-maintained local road system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that this short debate on the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill has been quite interesting. In listening to the three contributions made today I changed my mind on a number of occasions about what I should say. I note the sincerity of the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) in the comments he made. The view he put forward well and truly supports the hopes and aspirations of those he represents. However, should Australia have the misfortune of electing a coalition government, it would be very interesting to see the honourable member for Wide Bay go into the coalition party room—presuming the Liberal and National parties were still in coalition—and try to argue some of the case that he has put to us in this chamber today.

PARA.TAB: When I follow members of the Opposition in debates like this and I consider some of the outlandish statements made by their shadow ministerial colleagues about cost cutting, I wonder in what areas funds would be cut. Even though the shadow Minister who led for the Opposition today, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), made some statements about the amount of funds put towards roads in Australia, at no time did he make a commitment about what a coalition government would do.

What does he say to a member such as the honourable member for Wide Bay in the context of the promised $10 billion cuts that are part of the Fightback package? He came up with an analysis and scantily quoted comments that he alleges that the MAV, the Municipal Association of Victoria, has made about the effects of the consumption tax. But are those comments just about the consumption tax or are they are about the full Fightback package? He quoted what the MAV said in September 1991, before the full details said that local government would marginally benefit. He then said that it had done work at a later date that came to the same conclusion. Does it take into account the full package?

He graciously mentioned a former colleague of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) and me. I am assuming that he was talking about Peter Cleeland, who will be returned as the member for McEwen, especially as his Liberal opponent has now been given the job, on behalf of the Opposition, of selling the GST to consumers. I find that laughable in an electorate that stretches from the urban fringe neighbouring my electorate up through the rural core of Victoria.

In the context of the effect that the GST and the whole Fightback package would have on local government, and using the work that the MAV has done, one of the municipalities that service some of the area that I represent indicates that just on rate revenue alone there would be rate increases of up to 2 per cent—based on its scant calculations. It went on to say that it was unable to calculate the effect of any funding cutbacks that one has to assume would occur because of the words that are in the Fightback package. That is what it is all about. It is all about things that are very much unknown.

The honourable member for Wannon criticised Peter Cleeland for writing to the local government authorities in the electorate that he expects to represent again in the next Parliament and asking them to make an analysis based on some of the facts that are contained in the Fightback package. That was all that Peter Cleeland said in the letter that he sent to local government authorities. He quoted portions of the Fightback package and asked local government to comment. The honourable member for Wannon could not even mention his name. That is all right; I do not think Cleeland would really be upset by that. But he has to be given credit. He has been around and he is causing a few headaches because people realise now that there should be concern about the way people perceive the effect of the Fightback package.

The Opposition proposes to move a very strange amendment to this legislation. I suppose it implies that because the two governments involved are conservative governments we will not talk to them. I do not think that the history of the way that this matter has been discussed would indicate that. I think that all the Ministers who have been involved have gone to great pains to involve all interested parties, whether they be State governments or local government associations representing the interests of local government. To suggest that in some way the Northern Territory and Tasmania are going to dip out on being well and truly consulted is a nonsense.

One of the important things that this legislation does is that, like the general untied grants to Aboriginal communities, it gives access to the `identified road funds'. I think it is disgraceful that that has not been the case in the past. It perhaps is a little sad that this has had to be addressed in the way that it has. It is to the credit of all the State and Territory governments that, when they sat down with the Commonwealth, they supported this nation and acknowledged that we need to move in that direction. That is a very important aspect of this legislation.

The second part of the legislation that is before us, of course, is that the interim measures that were announced after the Premiers Conference of 1990 are to continue. They do two things. They give flexibility to those local government authorities that wish to use that flexibility, but they reassure local government in general that in some way there will be no skulduggery done in the way that the figures are handled. We will have the general purpose grant. We will have a portion that is identified as the road funds, but at the end of the day the judgment on the use of those funds will be exercised by the local government authority. I think that across the chamber there would be agreement that that is a fair thing.

Local government is the sphere of government closest to the people. It should therefore be the most accountable form of government. As a past councillor in a municipality, I know that a lot of the decisions, whether they be minor or major, are put under great scrutiny by local communities. Local government is a form of government where one has to be on one's toes. I think that that is a fair thing. At the end of the day it will be the judgment of the communities that are represented by local government authorities that will determine whether these funds are being used appropriately.

There has been much discussion about the different merits of the direction of road funding policy under this Government. A lot of people have pushed their own local barrows. I am pleased that, through the national arterial road program, important roads in my electorate have been given access to Commonwealth funding. They are just as important to the day to day lives of the people who live in my electorate as are other roads that have been mentioned here today. It is important that there be flexibility in the road funding; that the Commonwealth take a great interest and continue to take a great interest in the establishment and building of roads throughout Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Senator Evans yesterday asked us to believe that his office had critically important information and documents on the Symons affair but kept the Minister totally uninformed about them for over one month despite the fact that the matter was a major political issue. Does the Prime Minister still believe, as he said in his press conference on 18 May, that Senator Evans's response on this matter has been appropriate? When will the Prime Minister demand from Senator Evans a full report on his involvement in the Symons affair in the same way as he demanded explanations from Senator Richardson and Senator Sibraa? Does the PM stand by Senator Evans's integrity in the same unequivocal way as he stood by Senator Richardson's only a few weeks ago?

—The difference here is that Senator Richardson was a principal in the matter; he had been in touch with the Government of the Marshall Islands; and the relationship was one between Senator Richardson and Mr Symons. No such relationship exists between Mr Symons and Senator Evans. In this case Senator Evans is simply a respondent in the Senate. The Leader of the Opposition said—
—We do not need any help from you, John. We have been here long enough, thank you.
—Order! The Prime Minister will refer to the honourable member by his title.
—I remember other episodes like this when you were over here—just remember that!
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.

—I am just reminding those opposite that they need a decent corporate memory in here—and I have one. The Leader of the Opposition said that this was a major issue for a month before Senator Evans was apprised of it. This is not so. It was desirable that Senator Evans's staff person who had contact with this material should have apprised Senator Evans of it so that in the event of Senator Evans being asked about it he could have replied more fully. The notion that the staff member should have been alert to a political issue much earlier than when it developed, as it did, is not to be sustained as an argument. Therefore, the requirement on any staff person who sees material which is not particularly in the public domain or is not particularly a public issue, given the hundreds of issues that any such person deals with, to have a meticulous knowledge of these things and to bring them all to the attention of the Minister, with the administrative complexity within this building, is basically not on.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans made clear his position yesterday when he came into possession of knowledge of these documents. The responses relate to the letter by Senator Sibraa to our mission in the United States and subsequent replies. It does not go principally to the issue. The issue is one where Senator Richardson, not improperly but unguardedly, became involved in discussions with this person, Symons, and has paid a very high ministerial price for it. If people on the other side think that they can extract from Senator Evans some sort of a price on the basis of his being a Senate respondent and his not having an encyclopaedic knowledge of all these events and being able to roll off at Questions without Notice technical replies requiring a lot of information, I think they are mistaken—politically and in every other way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to an analysis of Australia's service sector, published by the Bureau of Industry Economics this month? How important does that analysis indicate Australia's service industries are to the economy? Can the Treasurer tell us what the economic outlook for these industries is?
—I thank the honourable member for her question.
—Tell us about the railways.
—Order! The honourable member for Bruce will cease interjecting.

—The BIE's report makes it very clear that the service sector is playing a vital role in providing new jobs in Australia and contributing to the improvement of Australia's balance of payments position. It is a fact that job growth in Australia in the past year has been particularly strong in two of Australia's service industry sectors; namely, the community services sector which saw employment growth of 4.8 per cent between February 1991 and February 1992, and the recreational and personal services area where employment grew by 6.3 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the recreational services sector is overwhelmingly conducted in the private sector and is weighted towards small business activity. Because tourism plays a major role in this sector, it makes a significant contribution also to Australia's balance of payments. Of course, foreign tourists coming in are the equivalent of increased export earnings, and when Australians holiday within the country, rather than going overseas, this is the equivalent of reduced import spending.

The national accounts figures show that the real GDP in the recreational services sector grew by 2.9 per cent for the six months from June 1991 to December 1991. That corresponds to an annual rate of 6 per cent and is the fastest of any major industry sector in that period.

The BIE report indicates that the economic outlook for the services sector as a whole is good, and the survey of business expectations in the sector conducted by the National Australia Bank in March indicated that 68 per cent of respondents expect demand to increase for their services over the next 12 months. Firms expecting profitability to improve over the year outnumbered firms expecting profitability to fall by a margin of 27 per cent of total responses.

It is important to realise that these surveys and these results relate to the current circumstances and the current taxation regime. But, of course, there are proposals to introduce a tax which would impact upon the delivery of many of the services which are provided by these rapidly growing parts of the economy. This is notwithstanding the fact that there are alleged compensations or offsets, because many of the providers of these services are small businesses and pay little or no payroll tax. Because the industry deals largely in services and in food and refreshments, it stands to gain little from any of its proposals to abolish the wholesale sales tax. Indeed, the Treasury analysis of the Opposition's particular proposals shows that Australia's tourism would be hit with price rises of between 8.4 per cent and 11.4 per cent.

—I ask the Prime Minister to inform the House as to what progress has been made in implementing the reform initiatives contained in the Government's One Nation statement.
—Three months ago—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.
—I announced a program—
—I warn the honourable member for Higgins.

—which would accelerate our recovery from recession and put us on a low inflation path—which of course we are now on—and would create 800,000 jobs over four years. This historic program contained 93 measures designed to increase output, competition and flexibility in the Australian economy to better train our young people, to rebuild our transport infrastructure, and to give us one of the most comprehensive and competitive business tax structures in the OECD.

PARA.TAB: I think it is fair to say that the program has been, in the main, warmly welcomed. I am delighted to tell the House today that, of those 93 measures announced only 12 weeks ago, 26—more than a quarter—have already been implemented; another 13 are currently on track in the implementation process and are due to come into effect next financial year or beyond; and the remainder will be implemented as the necessary legislation is brought forward, or negotiations with interested parties are concluded.

The speed of the implementation has been quite profound. Most honourable members are probably aware of some of the things we have implemented already. For example, we have cut taxes on passenger motor vehicle sales, paid the special family allowance bonus to help those worst hit by tough times—

PARA.TAB: In competition policy, we have progressed negotiations to establish a national grid corporation, separating transmission from electricity generation in line with the decisions of the 11 May heads of government meeting; removed aviation specific restrictions on equity investment between Australian operators; commenced renegotiating bilateral air services agreements with a view to securing multiple designations; facilitated passenger and freight charter operations by Australian based operators; invited New Zealand to agree to multiple designation on trans-Tasman routes; commenced negotiations with New Zealand on a single aviation market with a common border; commissioned an Industry Commission study on port authority services.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. I refer the Minister to the release yesterday of the Government's national electricity strategy discussion paper. What steps is the Government taking to increase efficiency in the electricity supply industry?

—The Government clearly supports the objective of an efficient, competitive and nationally focused electricity industry as a vital adjunct to Australia's international competitiveness. The national electricity strategy discussion paper, which I released yesterday, builds on the reforms to date and, in the Government's view, provides a blueprint for the future development of this important industry. The strategy is based on the premise that the full benefits of reform can only be realised through the adoption of a partnership approach between and across all levels of government and industry.

PARA.TAB: The centrepiece of the strategy is the formation of the National Grid Corporation, as foreshadowed by the Prime Minister in his One Nation economic statement. I also repeat the agreement to the principle of separation of generation and transmission elements of the electricity sector, as successfully pursued by the Prime Minister at the heads of government meeting on 11 May.

The Government believes that this type of structural reform provides the key to improved competition and offers major efficiency gains. The strategy also provides a range of other initiatives, including the establishment of a broadly based National Electricity Industry Council.

The Commonwealth is committed to working with the States and other key parties to realise these efficiency gains. Already our policy of working cooperatively with the States over recent years has produced significant improvements in the efficiency of the industry with average real electricity prices now at the level they were in the early 1970s. However, further gains are achievable and they are essential.

The Government's planned and coordinated approach to structural reforms stands in stark contrast to the policies of the Opposition. The Opposition, in this context, talks big on micro reform, but it is lacking in substance. In terms of the Prime Minister's enunciation of some of the major reforms of this Government, I am tempted to ask members of the Opposition to name just one major area of micro-economic reform in their whole period of government. They cannot answer, of course.
