—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. What contact has his Department had with the Government of the Marshall Islands regarding Gregory Symons? What investigation is his Department undertaking, or proposing to undertake, regarding possible criminal activities committed within Australia over the Marshall Islands affair? Is the Australian Federal Police investigating or proposing to investigate the whereabouts of any moneys fraudulently obtained from investors? What assurances will the Minister give this Parliament that no Australian laws have been broken in attempts to establish business migration schemes in the Marshall Islands?

—On 10 April this year, after Mr Symons had been arrested and charged in the Marshall Islands, Mr McPhillips, who is the Attorney-General in the Marshall Islands, contacted the Australian Attorney-General's Department. The purpose of that call was to ascertain whether or not it was possible for Mr Symons to enter into an undertaking to return to the Marshall Islands if, in fact, he did come back to Australia; that is, whether he could give an undertaking that he would not contest an extradition proceeding back to the Marshall Islands. Mr McPhillips, the Attorney-General in the Marshall Islands, indicated that such a procedure is available in the United States. The Marshall Islands being a United States protectorate, US law applies there.

PARA.TAB: It was explained to Mr McPhillips by the Department here that no such procedure applied in Australia and that, if Mr Symons did return to Australia, he could not give an undertaking that he would not avail himself of his rights in contesting any attempt to extradite him. Later that day there was a second phone call along the same lines from a Mr Strauss, who was the defence counsel for Mr Symons, inquiring about the same matter—that is, the issue of whether or not some undertaking could be given whereby any objection to extradition could be waived by Mr Symons. He was advised in the same way: that there is no such provision in Australian law.

In the same conversation with the Department on 10 April, it was mentioned that it was a possibility that Mr Symons had committed offences in Australia in the course of the alleged conduct with which he was charged in the Marshall Islands. Mr Symons was believed to have performed certain acts in the course of that conduct that might be offences in Australia. Mr McPhillips said that in due course, if charges did not proceed in the Marshall Islands, it may be appropriate for that conduct to be investigated in Australia.

Mr McPhillips was told that any such investigations would be a matter for the Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions, and maybe State authorities, depending on where the offences may have arisen, if there were any such offences. He was further advised that, if he had any information relevant to the matters he was talking about, he should pass it on and it would be referred to the Federal Police in the ordinary way.

Later that day a number of documents were faxed to the Attorney-General's Department and were passed on to the AFP, in the normal way, with a request that it investigate them in the normal way. As of yesterday the advice given to Senator Tate by the Australian Federal Police was that on the examination of the documents provided by Mr McPhillips there was no evidence of any offences on the basis of those documents that it would investigate in relation to Australia at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister explain to the House why the Government settled on a target level of superannuation contributions of 12 per cent of income by the end of this century? Is there any independent support for this level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's end of century superannuation contribution standard will provide a retirement income of the order of 40 per cent of pre-retirement income. This reflects community targets. A compulsory level of savings of the order of 12 per cent would allow that sort of income level to be attained.

PARA.TAB: I was very interested in the evidence which was given in the Senate inquiry now being undertaken into the question of superannuation and compulsory superannuation. The person appointed by the Leader of the Opposition to examine the coalition's superannuation policy, Associate Professor David Knox from Macquarie University, went before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and gave the following evidence. He was asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Do you see potential problems arising for this country in paying its pensions if we do not pursue some sort of compulsory funding type arrangements?
I think given the ageing population, the demographic situation if you like, then my answer is yes.

We could argue that we do not need to do anything because we are going to have enormous increases in productivity and we are going to be able to fund the age pension in the year 2020. I do not buy that argument. I think if you do have significant productivity and it all goes to the age pension, then the workers are going to get a bit uptight about it. So I believe we do need to do something on a long term basis, on a compulsory basis—
I would add my comment that I think we need a compulsory core and an optional extra.
I would put it in the range of an employer contribution of 7 to 12 per cent.
He was asked further questions and went on to ask himself a question rhetorically:
So should we proceed with the SGL? I suggest that we should. . .

He went on to make some other points. In other words, here is the person appointed by the Liberal Party to examine its optional tax-driven, tax-related superannuation scheme—opposing as it does the superannuation guarantee levy—saying that he thinks we should have a compulsory system. The notion that he went on to argue was that we do not need to do anything because of productivity. Guess who is arguing that line? Those opposite. He went on to say:
I do not buy that argument.

In other words, he rejects the basis of your proposition—that is, your own inquirer objects to the basis of your proposition that there should be a tax incentive-driven superannuation scheme without compulsion. He went on to make it dead clear that he regards a compulsory scheme as the only basic scheme—a core scheme with optional top-ups, if you like, through the tax system. In addition, I noticed that in today's Australian Geoffrey Lehmann, who has supported the Opposition's line of policy, including its policy on the GST, stated, under the heading `Compulsory super is an urgent need'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again. Reading newspapers again. Clipping service.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!
—I know he does not like it. He should just listen and cop it.
—You are a clipping service.
—Order! The honourable member for Lowe.
—Mr Lehmann stated:

PARA.TAB: One of the political paradoxes in Australia is the Federal Coalition parties' opposition to compulsory super.
In the long term, compulsory superannuation has the ability to reduce and almost remove dependence on the old-age pension.

This is a long-term project because workers in their fifties, and even in their forties, on modest salaries simply cannot set aside enough out of current income to achieve financial independence in their old age.
To achieve this, these workers would have to start contributing a substantial percentage of their income to super in their twenties.
Is this likely without compulsion? The answer is no.

ANSWER.PARA: There is Mr Lehmann, who has supported you on many of your policies and supports your general line of argument, rejecting you on compulsory super and there is the person whom you appointed, Professor Knox, telling the Senate Committee that he believes we need compulsory superannuation, that he supports the SGL and that he supports core superannuation of the order of 7 to 12 per cent. Where does that leave you? On the outside as usual—wreckers as you always are. You have tried to wreck the one opportunity we have had to get the work force to agree to put 12 per cent of their income away in savings. At the important point you went and wrecked it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—As we move towards the change in the demographics of 2010 or 2020, when the retired age population of this country will be about twice what it is now and the national Budget will not be able to afford pension payments at levels which those people will require or the Budget can sustain, and at a time when we can do something about it, who stands in the way of a decent structural change for higher living standards in retirement and national savings? The Federal coalition.

PARA.TAB: As my colleague the Minister for Tourism and Minister for Resources said a few moments ago, the Opposition cannot name one structural change that it supported. It cannot name one major micro-economic impediment that it removed in the years it was in office. This Government has had to reform not only macro-economic policy but also the whole of the micro-economy. While doing so, it is lifting retirement incomes and making provision for Australian workers and adding to national savings. Like the narks you are, you want to destroy that too. You destroy it against the advice of the person you appointed to inquire into it.

Some of those who support you, including the AMP Society and National Mutual, have condemned you, as has everybody in the superannuation industry. You are left on the basis that you will provide a few tax concessions and if people take them up, well and good; if they do not, bad luck: it is bad luck for them, bad luck for the Budget and bad luck for the nation. But you will go your wilful way. These are the issues that matter in the long run. You will go your wilful way to try to wreck the SGL and drag out a Senate process hopefully to the point where the legislation is not passed to try to wreck a national scheme which it has taken from 1983 to 1992 to put in place. That is the kind of mindless obstructionism and vandalism that you have always been famous for.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question to the Prime Minister about wreckers. I refer the Prime Minister to the findings of the Gyles Royal Commission that much of the anarchy, mayhem and thuggery in the building and construction industry in New South Wales flows out of compulsory unionism or the notorious no ticket, no start rule which is ruthlessly enforced by unions and companies alike in that industry.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Reid!

—Given that finding, will the Prime Minister now acknowledge that compulsory membership of any organisation is fundamentally wrong and will his Government facilitate the immediate debate of the Industrial Relations (Membership of Associations) Bill 1990 which, if passed, would guarantee that membership of all organisations throughout Australia, be it the Law Society of New South Wales or the Building Workers Industrial Union, would become completely voluntary?

—The honourable member for Bennelong has for a long time been trying to prove that the destruction of the inflation rate in the late 1970s and the policy of deregulation, as he put it then, of our industrial sectors was something that he was right about, and he has been trying to revisit it through these proposed changes he is arguing for in industrial relations. They all go to the core of removing the right of workers to a collective bargain, to negotiate as unions with their employers.

PARA.TAB: Now he raises the building industry, which has been marred by this kind of activity, which he and Mr Gyles referred to, in all States of Australia. This Government took the initiative of outlawing the BLF in the 1980s as a result—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Master Builders?
—Order!

—We took them on. As far as Gyles is concerned, the Government will examine his recommendations. It is a royal commission appointed by the Government of New South Wales. We will examine the report. If the honourable member thinks that he can use that as an argument to hop into trade unionism and the right of workers to argue—
—No, Mr Speaker.
—Order! Does the honourable member have a point of order?
—Mr Speaker, my point of order is that my question was concisely drawn to elicit a response—
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will get to his point of order.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I thought you were getting a little concerned—
—That is not a point of order.
—That is not a point of order. He is arguing.
—Order! If the honourable member for Bennelong does not get to his point of order, he will resume his seat.
—Well, you and those people are the ones who are interrupting me—

—The honourable member for Bennelong will resume his seat. If the honourable member has a point of order he will come to the point of order. He will not start to make remarks about the Chair or respond to interjections. State your point of order and I will make a ruling on it.
—My question was concisely drawn to elicit a response from the Prime Minister, not about unions generally but about—
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will get to his point of order.
—Well, are you going to protect me from these mindless interruptions?
—Get to your point of order.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard—Well, you invite me to get to my point of order—

TALK.START.PARA: —Get to your point of order and hurry up about it.

—You invite me to do it and they keep interrupting. I concisely asked a question to elicit a response from the Prime Minister about one issue and one issue alone and that is the principle of compulsory membership of organisations. The Prime Minister has been on his feet for over a minute and has yet to address that question.
—Order! The honourable member is now debating the point. The honourable member for Bennelong asked a very long question, encompassing a number of issues. The Prime Minister is answering the question.
—I asked a concise question.
—Order! If the honourable member for Bennelong continues to interject, I will name him.
—I have said in my answer that we will examine the Gyles recommendations. The report was presented yesterday, apparently. I have not seen it, but I will have a look at it.
—What about no ticket, no start?
—Order!
—I cannot understand why the honourable member for Bennelong, as a person from humble origins, wants to put the boot into the ordinary Australian worker. I cannot understand it.
—You are obsessed with social class.
—Order!

—I know he has crossed the Rubicon to serve the Liberal Party, but to serve the Liberal Party must he be so contemptuous of the interests of the working people as to try to take away from them the ability to organise themselves as a collective to negotiate for their working conditions, rates of pay, et cetera? The whole notion of the policy being pursued by the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong is to remove the right of working people to negotiate with unions or to bargain collectively so that—
—Wrong! Wrong!
—I know you are running away, away from APPM and all that that situation means.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Rubbish!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not rubbish. You run away from what you say. You are not even prepared to stand for the policy you articulate. You go over to New Zealand and rat on Australia. You berate Australia and the attitudes of Australians. You go over there and say that attitudes here are wrong, that you think there ought to be a big bang approach to industrial relations, that you are supporting their industrial contracts legislation, that you are extolling its virtues. The Minister for Finance read out what happened to a New Zealand worker two weeks ago when that person lost all pay and conditions as a result of the so-called agreement that that person was forced into.
—You are defending their actions.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—Yet, when you have to face up to your policy in the House of Representatives, you want to deny it, you want to move away from it. Well, you will not move away from it. We will tag you—and your little mate beside you—with your policy right to polling day.
—Order! The Prime Minister will refer to honourable members by their titles.

—Having both come from the wrong side of the tracks, you are so committed to proving to the blue bloods that your blood is bluer than theirs, that you have to sink the boot into ordinary people, that you will tear away at the guts of Australian unionism—
—You are obsessed. You are obsessed.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for Bennelong interjects again I will name him.

—You will remove the right to collectively bargain. You will take away Federal awards. The only protection that people can get for their rates of pay and their conditions is through the award system, but you want to take that away. And who is doing it? Not the people from the western districts or the Toorak blue bloods or even our mate over here from South Australia, but a couple of scrubbers from western Sydney who basically have taken out Liberal Party tickets and have said, `Right, we are now in the Establishment and we have been fitted up for the pinstripe suits; let's get our boots out into the ordinary people'.
—Look at yourself.
—It is not a pinstripe suit.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—You are rubbishing half of your voters.
—But I have not ratted on my people as you have—that is the difference.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—I am still representing the people who have nothing to represent but their labour. You have the idea that you can surreptitiously, quietly, whistle away compulsory unionism, whistle away the right of workers to collectively bargain, whistle away Federal awards in some sort of technical debate about conditions or segments of the industrial arbitration Acts of this country. You are quite wrong if you think you will slide away on a policy that knocks out Federal awards and does these things. So, John, do not come at me about the building industry. Own up to a bit of decent policy and try to argue for a policy which you can defend in public, not one which you run away from every time a question is put to you.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—The Prime Minister has continually referred to members on this side of the House by their incorrect title, and I would ask you, under the Standing Orders, to direct the Prime Minister to address honourable members on this side of the House by their correct title.
—Order! The Prime Minister will refer to honourable members by their correct title.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for Bennelong interjects again, I will name him—immediately.

—There has been no greater elucidation of a more spiteful and malignant policy than that articulated by the honourable member for Wentworth. The spitefulness of it is to rob people of things like occupational superannuation; the malignancy of it is to attack their rights to organise and to bargain for their rates of pay and conditions of work. No Liberal leader has approached the electorate with a more ideologically bent right wing agenda than has the honourable member for Wentworth. It is the sort of policy which Malcolm Fraser would not have a bar of—he has said so—nor would any of his predecessors. Yet in the twilight of some of these debates, they think they can slip through this sort of arid right wing policy.

PARA.TAB: The fact is, not only will you be pinned with the GST, but you will be pinned by this kind of approach, your zero tariffs, using monetary policy to decimate the economy, which you have been proposing—
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. Order! The House will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Leader of the Opposition continues to interject I will deal with him.

—trying to wreck industrial relations in this country, trying to say that we will have the battle for Burnie, APPM, across the countryside, in all the capital cities, in all the provincial cities, as we see industrial confrontation and industrial disputes. You know that industrial Australia will not cop it, business will not cop it, the unions will not cop it and the electorate will not cop it. So, John, if you want to come at it through the building industry, understand what you are proposing. Every time you try to run away from it on The World Today or AM, we will pin you for the policies that your leader has pinned you to, and that is wrecking the award system and trying to rob ordinary Australian people of their right to bargain for pay and conditions of work.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister aware of an article in the Tweed Daily News of 25 May—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not unless you have given it to him!

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.

—Is the Minister aware of an article in the Tweed Daily News of 25 May headed, `Tariff reductions to be eased in: Fischer', which claims that it is the Government's intention to remove sugar tariffs by 1998? I ask the Minister: is this true, and will he advise the House of the current status of consultation with the sugar industry?

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. There is far too much noise on both sides of the chamber.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to the article.

PARA.TAB: Mr Bruce Scott interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Maranoa will cease interjecting.

—The answer in brief is that no, it is not the Government's intention to eliminate tariffs by 1998, despite the assertion that was made by the Leader of the National Party. Our position is clear. I have made it clear in this House and I have made it clear in discussions not only with the canegrowers in the area represented by the honourable member for Richmond but also in central Queensland which I visited the other day with the honourable member for Herbert. Our position is that there will be no further adjustment to the rate of tariff post the 1 July decision that has already been announced, until such time as there have been consultations with the industry.

PARA.TAB: We will not be driven by the IC's report, as will the Opposition. We do have a strategy to develop the industry. We have set up a committee to develop that, and the process will be similar to the very successful one that resulted in the dairy industry plan. That has been indicated to the canegrowers in the two areas mentioned, and they are very happy with that outcome. It has been well received and they are prepared to work with us, but not so the coalition.

It is true, in terms of that article, that the headline read that the Leader of the National Party said that tariff reductions would be eased in. But what does the coalition policy say? As recently as the AMIC dinner on 7 May, a dinner which the Leader of the National Party attended—he was sitting at the same table as I was—this is what the Leader of the Liberal Party said.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was well received.
—You did not bat an eyelid then, Tim, so let us see what you say now. This is what Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Liberal Party said:

ANSWER.PARA: We will eliminate tariff protection by the year 2000.
There were no qualifications in relation to the sugar growers; there is no mention of the so-called word `negligible'. You were there, Tim; you did not bat an eyelid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will refer to the honourable member by his title.

—The Leader of the National Party was there, Mr Speaker, and he did not bat an eyelid despite the fact that that statement is as clear as the water that flows from those springs that he sits under on Mount Kosciusko.
—Oh, that is a good line.
—The same day the Leader of the National Party was on radio saying this:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not Liberal or National Party policy to cut tariffs to zero immediately or even by the year 2000.

Where were you when the Leader of the Opposition's office was putting together the speech for AMIC, which you attended? You did not raise a query. But the speech clearly says, `We will eliminate tariff protection by the year 2000'. The problem is that you will get caught out. As the Prime Minister said, it does not matter which issue you take; you go and say one thing in the bush and you roll over here. You get walked all over.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the National Party is on the record as saying to those canegrowers in the electorate of the honourable member for Richmond:

ANSWER.PARA: We would not stand for a zero tariff policy for the sugar industry.

Too right you would not stand for it! You would lie down and be walked over. That is what happens every time you get put under pressure in this place. You say you would not stand for zero tariffs; but what did Ian Ballantyne, the chief executive of the Cane Growers Association, say when he met with the Leader of the Opposition? On ABC radio on 7 May he said that Dr Hewson had confirmed that he would not look at holding a tariff at $55 per tonne and that tariffs would come off on a progressive basis to reach zero.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the National Party has been found out. It is no wonder that, in addition to that headline that I have referred to, we have another one: `Tweed sugar chief will snub Fischer'. It is little wonder that they are going to snub you.

I will conclude on this point. I again quote ABC radio, where it is reported that a leading north Queensland sugar industry figure has turned up the heat on the coalition to reconsider its zero tariff policy. That is what those people are saying; they do not believe a thing that you say. This is what you have to wake up to. They do not believe you; you have no credibility in the bush when it comes to this double standard that you have been trying to promote in relation to tariffs. That same leader went on to describe the coalition's policy as `disgusting'—and so he should. As I said before, the canegrowers of this country—
Mr Tim Fischer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the Leader of the National Party.
—are very happy with the approach that this Government has outlined to them and are prepared to work with us. All they will do with you is walk away. And you deserve to have them do it.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that at the time of the arrest of Gregory Symons in the Marshall Islands, Mr O'Leary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade recorded a file note on a telephone conversation that he had with Mr Peter Stanford of our Embassy in Micronesia and the Marshall Islands, in which he said, `Richo has been ringing members of Cabinet and President seeking leniency'? Is it also a fact that this information was conveyed directly to the office of Senator Evans on 6 April? Given that this file note has come to light only this afternoon in the Senate, does the Prime Minister agree that the involvement of Senator Evans, his Department and office indicates that relevant facts have been obscured over the last seven weeks since the telephone conversation took place? I ask the Prime Minister: why will the Government not come clean on this sordid matter and put the full story on the public record, rather than have every detail painfully extracted in the Parliament?

—Senator Evans referred to this matter yesterday in the Senate and he made it clear that aspects of that file note went to matters in relation to the prosecution in the Marshall Islands and other matters of privacy which related to other people. He gave that indication and he said that if a request were made, he would consider tabling it under the FOI Act, but with appropriate deletions. That is a fact. Senator Evans is simply a respondent to questions in the Senate. The principal in this matter has paid the price of resigning his position as a Minister. But your notion that, for your shabby, lousy, political purposes, you can now try to drag in the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade on the basis that every note that exists in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is not produced to you the moment that a back bench senator rises on a question without notice in the Senate and asks the Minister to deliver an avalanche, a truckload, or whatever is available, of compendium file notes or departmental notes on these matters, is unreasonable. Therefore, to try to suggest that Senator Evans has not been truthful with the Senate is a very cowardly thing to do.

PARA.TAB: The real issues which the Leader of the Opposition wants to get away from are the ones I mentioned earlier. Members of the Opposition are trying to torpedo the superannuation guarantee levy which will affect Australians for the next 50 years.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—Mr Speaker, I ask the House to make a judgment about the relative weight of the issues—that is, the malicious destruction of this legislation by the Opposition in the Senate; the attempts by the Opposition to argue a case for the abolition of collective bargaining in this country; all of the other elements of their nark approach to public affairs; their attempts to talk the economy down at every turn—compared with a question in Question Time about a file note by a Foreign Affairs officer—
—Get back to the point. How is this relevant?
—Order!
—which contains private information about other people that will not be released under FOI without deletions—
—Order! The Leader of the National Party on a point of order.

—Mr Speaker, my point of order is that, whilst it is allowable for the Prime Minister to make passing reference to other matters, he is now developing detailed arguments far beyond the specific question which related to the request for leniency lodged by Senator Richardson and involving Senator Evans. He should come back to the question.

—Order! The Prime Minister was asked a question about a file note. The last words the Prime Minister used before the point of order was taken were words about a file note. The Prime Minister is in order. The Leader of the National Party ought to listen to the answer.
—At any rate, the most important point is that the file note contains hearsay. Therefore, the notion that a Senate Minister should make this sort of note available so that other people are maligned—
—You should check his notes and find out about it. When did you find out about it?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—and people not involved here may be mentioned, is of course irresponsible. The Government is not doing it. Senator Evans has said he has proposed to release the document with the appropriate deletions—
—And release it.
—Order!

—That is right. We will release it to you, with the appropriate deletions. The fact is that that is the appropriate way to go. But the notion that the Leader of the Opposition, for his miserable purposes, can think—
—Why are you so guilty?
—Order!
—that there is any point in his asking for one document after another—do not be so stupid.

—Can the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services inform the House as to the main points made in the report on the short term prospects for the housing industry recently released by the Indicative Planning Council? Also, is the Minister aware of the comments of the Housing Industry Association on the nature of the recovery in housing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of comments—

PARA.TAB: Mr Charles interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for La Trobe will cease interjecting.

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Housing Industry—

—Order! The Deputy Prime Minister might resume his seat for a moment. I have warned the honourable member for Mackellar earlier today. I might just repeat for the honourable member for Mackellar and other members of the House that, when an honourable member is warned, the next step is naming. That may have been something that has slipped some people's minds. I just draw it to the attention of all honourable members. I remind the honourable member for Mackellar that I have warned him, and I reiterate that warning. For any member who is warned, the next step for continued disorderly conduct, such as interjections, will be naming.

—I am aware of the comments of the Housing Industry Association. They illustrate the dangers involved in seeking to make too much of one figure. Indeed, we heard something of that from the honourable member for Flinders in the context of uncertain recovery, which was the theme of his remarks yesterday. So it is important that from time to time we go back to authoritative sources, such as the Indicative Planning Council, which did meet last month and released a report on Sunday of this week that confirmed that housing recovery was on track. The IPC forecasts a 13 per cent increase in dwelling commencements to 137,000 in 1991-92, and a further 11 per cent increase in 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: The report on short term prospects confirms the IPC's October 1991 forecast of modest growth. There has been speculation that recovery would overheat the housing market. However, the IPC's view is that this is unlikely to occur, as trades, labour, materials and land are in ready supply in the short term. This recovery, then, will return the benefits of steady growth rather than the windfalls that were gained by the fortunate few in the last housing upturn.

The comments of those who would denigrate and those who would pick a particular statistic to create an atmosphere of uncertainty in relation to the housing industry are certainly unfortunate. In that respect, it is worth reflecting on a range of press releases that have come from the honourable member for Forrest: `Government threatens increase in building approvals', `Housing figures highlight volatile market', `Housing recovery not a sure thing' and `Minister wrong on housing'. The Opposition, through its spokesperson, through its shadow Treasurer, would say anything at all to understate, to undercut, to threaten the possibility of recovery. One has to reflect on the fact that affordability is at the highest level it has been for seven years, but for the last nine quarters there has been an improvement in the terms of affordability; that, essentially, the housing industry in this country runs on the basis of confidence.

What do we get from the Opposition? There is not a jot of concern for those who need housing around this country, no concern for new home buyers, no concern about the recovery of the housing industry. All those opposite want to do is undercut the possibility of recovery; all they want to do is achieve a negative statistic that essentially will threaten the steady course that the IPC forecasts are about. That is extremely unfortunate because what that suggests is that as far as those opposite are concerned, they have not a jot of interest in terms of policy; the housing industry is of no concern to them. The honourable member for Forrest may be interested himself in property, but in terms of the nation's housing he has no special interest at all. That then translates itself into that kind of knee-jerk reaction. The Government has no intention of allowing itself to be distracted by that kind of talking down—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just been.
—Order! The honourable member for Isaacs will cease interjecting.

—by that kind of meanness in terms of the Australian economy. In contrast, we are seeing steady recovery in the housing industry. We are looking comprehensively at our policies and today we released the fifth issues paper as part of the National Housing Strategy series—
—You are good on paper.

—The Leader of the Opposition says that we are good on paper. The reality is that in terms of the housing industry we are prepared to publish papers; we are prepared to discuss and debate. But what the Opposition wants to do is essentially talk down any possibility of recovery, destroy confidence, and, in fact, destroy Australia.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said to honourable members on a number of occasions that I do not think the anticipation rule should be used as a vehicle to hamper debate. PARA.TAB: If my predecessors used the anticipation rule in the manner in which the honourable member seems to be suggesting, they would have had to rule out many questions that are asked at Question Time that oppositions of both political persuasions use to elicit information that they intend to use later on in the day in the MPI. INTERJECT.PARA: This program of proposed business is issued for the general guidance of Members. It is not a formal document and the business listed is subject to change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is in response to your reply, Mr Speaker, for which I thank you. I did not question your position, Mr Speaker; I questioned that of the Minister, who quite clearly knew what he was going to do that day.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—What are you doing? Are you moving anything?
—That would be a first.
—Order!

—I am trying to be helpful to the honourable member for O'Connor. I am also trying to be helpful to you, Mr Speaker, again. I should have said that the Bill would be debated on Thursday, as it will be. So to the extent that I contributed to the confusion, I apologise. Nevertheless, it was quite a good answer.

—It might help the honourable member for Calwell and the House if I say that I intend to report to the House on what the honourable member for Menzies raised earlier today. —With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, if I can make some brief comments it might help you when making your determination on a matter raised earlier.
—Oh, no!

—Order! Earlier today the honourable member for Menzies raised some matters that related to the honourable member for Calwell. The matters raised were important issues, I am sure, otherwise the honourable member for Menzies would not have raised them. It might help all of to us hear the point that the honourable member for Calwell wants to make.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—I think it might help us all to hear the honourable member for Calwell.
—But not on a personal explanation.

—The honourable member for O'Connor might listen to me sometimes, just once or twice. I said that I will hear the honourable member for Calwell. I am not hearing him on a personal explanation or a point of order. I am giving him indulgence. I am hearing him. I am not hearing the honourable member for O'Connor. I call the honourable member for Calwell.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker, for your indulgence. I would like to make two brief comments on this very important matter. Firstly, I was not at all consulted by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), which is the normal practice and courtesy before raising a matter such as this. Secondly, the honourable member raises a number of very serious issues in his comments. I am still in the process of attempting to obtain all the facts surrounding these issues. However, as more information becomes available it may be necessary for me to raise such a matter before this House.
