TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —A paper is tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the paper will be recorded in Hansard and the Votes and Proceedings.

PARA.TAB: The schedule read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 1.INDUSTRY COMMISSION—Report No. 20—National Procurement Development Program—31 March 1992.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The intention of the Keating government to extend the industrial relations system prevailing in the building and construction industry and roundly condemned by the Gyles Royal Commission to the home building and other industries.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every so often it comes the fortunate way of the Opposition to strike gold during Question Time, and we struck gold during Question Time today when we questioned the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about his reaction to the Gyles Royal Commission report in New South Wales. I think any observer of Parliament today—any member of the press gallery, any member of the public, or any interested supporter of the Labor Party or the Liberal Party who may have been observing Question Time today—would have had totally removed from his or her mind any lingering notion that by any stretch of the imagination the present occupant of the Prime Ministership of Australia could be called a modern, progressive, reform Labor Party leader.

PARA.TAB: If ever a man exhibited an obsession with class, an obsession with background, a total insensitivity to his remarks, and a total inability to understand what makes the modern Australian nation, it was the Prime Minister today. One of the pejorative terms of Australian political argot has become `a scrubber from the western suburbs'. This defender of the working men and women of Australia, this paragon of egalitarianism, this man who is supposed to defend the equality before the law and the equality in society of every Australian man, woman and child, apparently regards it as in some way dishonourable to be a `scrubber' or, indeed, anybody else from the western suburbs of Sydney.

Anybody listening to the debate today could not have failed to be struck by the soaring irony. This man who so deserted the western suburbs of Sydney that he needs a Gregory's directory to find Bankstown, this man who is no longer simpatico with the people of his origins and no longer has any real understanding with his original social roots in Australian society, has so far removed himself from the people whose respectability and love he craves that he can actually insensitively invent a pejorative term which is meant to bring a little bit of political rhetoric to wound the Opposition. But, far from being political rhetoric that wounds the Opposition, it reveals him as being a mindless, class-driven politician still locked in battles which most of us regard as having disappeared in this country decades ago. That is why this man cannot understand what is involved in the debate about the building industry in New South Wales.

This debate has nothing to do with the persecution of what he would have us believe to be the working class of Australia. What it has to do with is equality before the law and observance of the laws of this country by all sections of Australian society. I am not asking for an industrial relations system that oppresses employees. I am not asking for an industrial relations system that will turn back the clock to the 1890s. What I am asking for, and what the Opposition will proudly present to the Australian people at the next election, is an industrial relations policy that will carry this country into a productive and competitive future in the twenty-first century.

If Government members wanted any evidence of the abysmal failure of the present industrial relations system to deliver this nation a productive and competitive future and the damage it has done, if they wanted any evidence of just how Australians—all Australians; not, as the Prime Minister would say, `ordinary Australians' or `average Australians', but all Australians; wherever we may have been born and from whatever part of Sydney or Melbourne we come from—they only have to read—
Opposition members—Adelaide!

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Adelaide, the western districts, the Pilbara, the great Maranoa district of Queensland, or anywhere else—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Tasmania. I am sorry. I do not hate Tasmania. One has only to read the report of Mr Roger Gyles, QC. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: My Report of the Hearings reveal nothing less—
honourable members should listen to these words—

than industrial anarchy in which any pretence of the rule of law or the application of principle has been abandoned. . . In this situation, the power of a left, militant, disciplined union such as the BWIU claims to be supported by other unions in the BTG, has been accepted as the dominant force and the employer side has been reduced to short-term expediency.

Any notion Government members might entertain that this speech is an exclusive attack on the thuggery of the Building Workers Industrial Union, a union that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) was a senior official of until he entered the Commonwealth Parliament, will be dispelled by my saying that I will be equally trenchant of the criticism levelled against the Master Builders Association by Mr Roger Gyles.

PARA.TAB: As far as we are concerned, in relation to the registration of the Master Builders Association, the Federal Government should be willing to do what the State Government is willing to do: to refer the findings of Mr Gyles to the Crown Law authorities to see whether they are sufficient to found an application for deregistration of the Master Builders Association. Just as we do not come to the issue of voluntary membership of associations with unclean hands and a warped, biased attitude, and as we assert that it is just as wrong to compel a man or woman to join the Law Society of New South Wales as it is to compel somebody to join the BWIU, so we will say to this Parliament that if Mr Gyles has found against the employers, they ought to be in the dock along with the trade union leaders. There will be no double standards from this side of the House as there so often are from the other side of the House.

What is staggering to us, and what I think must be staggering to the Australian people, is the extraordinary coincidence that Roger Gyles has brought down a report which finds monumental evidence of union thuggery, of the loss of billions of dollars to the people of New South Wales, of countless strikes and stoppages, of collusion, of corruption, of false dealing, of dishonesty, and perhaps of corruption of people in official places, all of which has occurred in the commercial building industry in Sydney, and all of which has sprung out of an industrial relations system that is based upon the principle of compulsory unionism and its notorious manifestation in the commercial building industry, namely, the no ticket, no start rule; in other words, anyone who does not belong to the union is not allowed on the site. It is as simple as that.

As everyone opposite knows, that rule has been ruthlessly enforced. As the evasive behaviour of the Prime Minister in Question Time today revealed, that rule has been ruthlessly enforced by unions and companies alike. Yet amazingly, despite all this evidence and the findings of the Royal Commissioner, what the Keating Government is doing right at this moment is endeavouring to transfer that industrial relations system from the commercial building industry of Australia to the home building industry of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—The honourable member says, `That is nonsense'. I thought Government members would say it was nonsense. I will tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, what nonsense it is. The High Court of Australia upheld the legitimacy and the authenticity of the Troubleshooters hiring arrangement. Honourable members will remember that Troubleshooters was formed because of the appalling state of the building industry in Melbourne. If there had not been a BWIU thug in every building site in Melbourne, Troubleshooters would never have been formed: there would never have been a need for it. If the BWIU had been doing its job, Troubleshooters would not have had to be hired: there would have been no need for it.

PARA.TAB: When the appeal was upheld and the High Court of Australia said that it was a lawful, legitimate, independent contracting arrangement, after hearing some submissions from the present honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), it made another extraordinary finding. It found that the men employed by Troubleshooters and hired onto the building sites were paid more than they would have been paid if they had been operating under an award. So much for a sham transaction. So much for sweated working conditions. So much for the oppression of the working men of Australia. No such situation arose.

What the High Court found was that it was a lawful and legitimate arrangement. It slapped damages on the BWIU in Victoria for contempt of court. When the union secretary wrote to his membership he said, `You are all levied an extra 10 bucks to pay the fine, but don't worry, brothers, I've been told by the Federal Minister that they are going to amend the Industrial Relations Act to overcome the effect of the Troubleshooters case'.

That is what this contractors legislation is all about. It has nothing to do with those migrant women as out-workers in the textile industry. It has nothing to do with the oppression of workers. It has everything to do with overturning the Troubleshooters case; it has everything to do with transforming and transplanting the industrial relations conditions of the commercial building industry of Australia into the home building industry of Australia.

That will be a crying shame for Australia because the home building industry in this country is one of the most efficient in the world. It is cost-efficient; it is productive; and it is relatively free of industrial strife. That arises from one very simple fact: the home building industry is built on independent contractors. It is built on the sweat, labour, initiative and competitiveness of small business men and women. It is not built on the union thuggery of people that Peter Cook used to represent and still does, but from a far more dangerous position. It is built on decent, hardworking Australians who believe in private enterprise.

But that is too much for this corporatist mob opposite. Not content with wrecking the commercial building industry of Australia, they want to wreak the same havoc and wreckage on the home building industry of Australia. That is why they bring a Bill before the Parliament. There is no other reason. If honourable members do not believe me they should look at what the Secretary of the union said when he levied his members to pay the $300,000 that the union was fined by the Federal Court of Australia. He put it fairly and squarely by saying, `Don't worry, brothers. I've been promised that they will act to overrule the decision of the courts'.

Those opposite are trying to act to overrule the decisions of the court. The only thing that stands between that happening and the status quo being preserved will be how they vote in the other place. We can be certain that the herd instinct will operate here. They will all line up in front of the cattle prod and vote to extend the industrial relations system which has been condemned out of hand by Gyles as a rotten, corrupt system costing the nation billions of dollars. It has been labelled by Greiner as a national, even an international, disgrace.

What will those opposite do? It is not good enough just to wreck the commercial building industry; they are going to wreck the home building industry as well. They are the prime wreckers of Australian politics. It is not enough to destroy commercial building; it is not enough to have buildings such as the Qantas building in Sydney take years to complete. People end up disappearing into concrete pours on occasions in the building industry in Sydney. But what do those blokes opposite want to do? They want to transfer that system from the commercial building industry. They do not want to stamp it out there; they want to give it to the home building industry. Those opposite know—and the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) knows because he has a background in this area—how the movement works. They know very well that under this legislation all the BWIU would have to do would be to recruit one independent contractor into its ranks, lodge a log of claims and drag 100,000 home building contractors before the Industrial Relations Commission. Game, set and match! It is as simple as that.

Those opposite will pretend that they are trying to protect migrant workers. They are not trying to protect migrant workers. If they cared about migrant women, they would have done something about them eight or nine years ago. They do not give a damn about migrant women. But they do give a damn about the power of unions such as the BWIU. What they are in the business of doing is wreaking the same wreckage and havoc on the home building industry as they have on the commercial building industry. They ought to be driven out of office.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps at the outset in responding to the tirade from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) one should make any listeners aware of the fact that since this Government has been in office there has been a dramatic reduction in the level of industrial disputation in this country, not an increase as one would gather from his diatribe. The fact is that the amount of time lost in industrial disputes under this Government has been 60 per cent less than it was in the period of the Fraser Government. So let us start off on the basis of the facts, which are that this Government is very proud of the fact that its industrial relations record is infinitely better than its predecessor in government which had an appalling industrial relations record when the honourable member for Bennelong was a major member of that Government.

PARA.TAB: So let us start off on the basis of facts about what has happened with industrial relations in this country. The building industry has always been one of the most turbulent parts of the industrial relations scene at any time in our history. The nature of the business seems to lend itself to that kind of relative turbulence. So it is the case that, despite the fact that we can point to a very considerable improvement in industrial relations outcomes not just in terms of time lost in industrial disputes but also in terms of costs of wage increases, et cetera, in the building industry relative to other parts of the economy, the results are not as impressive. But, of course, we have shown concern about that.

It was this Government that took action to deregister effectively the Builders Labourers Federation. The previous Government mucked around with the deregistration process for ages and got nowhere. It was we who eventually took the effective step of deregistering the Builders Labourers Federation, which was of course a very dramatic step. To be effective it required not just that the union be deregistered but that there be a preparedness of other unions to take over its members. There had been deregistration before; there had been deregistration of the BWIU for about a decade and a half. There had been deregistration of the BLF for several years in the 1970s. But in both cases those unions were able to survive pretty well because of effective agreements by other unions that they would not touch their members.

Deregistration is effective in the case of the BLF because there was acceptance by the unions that they should not regard the BLF territory as inviolate and that they should take over its members. The consequence has been that the BLF in Victoria and New South Wales in particular has basically been wiped out. That is relevant to mention in the context of discussing a proposal for deregistration of the BWIU.

I certainly have not had time—and nor, I guess, has anyone in this place—to assess in any detail the findings of the Gyles Royal Commission. But one thing is for sure: if there is some idea that deregistration of the BWIU would be some cure-all for the problems of the building industry in New South Wales, a lot more thought ought to be given to that before people nail their colours to that mast. If there were no such agreement as there was in the case of the BLF, all that might happen could be that the BWIU could continue outside the system, effectively free of any constraint but still controlling most, but not all, of the territory that it had previously. That is something that the Opposition should perhaps consider.

It is also important to note that the honourable member for Bennelong effectively has misunderstood the Gyles report. It does not say, as he said at Question Time and sort of said in his address in this MPI, that the real problem is compulsory unionism, the no ticket, no start rule. That is, of course, not a Commission decision. There are no Commission decisions to give compulsory unionism. That is agreed at an enterprise or site level as part of the conditions of employment, in particular in certain parts of the building industry. But that is not something that is provided by the Commission.

Mr Gyles mentioned it as part of the system in the Sydney major projects building industry. But his finding was not that that is the problem; rather, it was that the problem is with the BWIU officials themselves. I do not want to make any comment on that at this stage because we have had no time to assess the report. It came out last night. We saw it only a couple of hours ago.
Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member has effectively misunderstood and misrepresented that report because he said that compulsory unionism is the problem. In fact, from what I have read in the time that I have had to read the report, Mr Gyles points out that in the civil engineering industry, where there is a high level of unionism, there is no such problem. So the honourable member should not say that this is a problem brought about solely by compulsory unionism or the no ticket, no start rule.

PARA.TAB: Once we put that to one side, the central point of the honourable member for Bennelong's comments, despite the fact that he does not understand the report, is that he says that we are trying to bring that system of industrial relations that prevails in the major projects sector of the building industry in Sydney and the other capital cities into the cottage industry, the house building industry. That is an allegation that he and others have made since this proposal for the independent contractors legislation, which is now in the Senate, was announced. It is utterly, completely and totally untrue. It is a complete fabrication by the honourable member for Bennelong and others who are making that allegation.

The Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Cook) has gone out of his way to say time and again that this is not the intention of the legislation and that it will not happen. The legislation, which we are not here to debate in detail today, will not allow that to happen. Its intention is simply to address the circumstance where there are sham contractors, where people are seeking to breach award conditions by putting in place supposed contractor arrangements, not because that is the normal way in which business in that area takes place but to try deliberately to undermine and destroy the award wage system. Those are the circumstances that the legislation is trying to address. In doing that, it is not doing anything unique; it is not doing anything that is unknown elsewhere.

In fact, it is particularly interesting that all this has come from a report about the New South Wales building industry. This actual provision that the Opposition says that we are trying to use to bring the system that operates in the major building industry into the cottage industry exists in the New South Wales industrial law. It has existed in the New South Wales industrial law for years. In the new industrial law from the Greiner Government, it is still there.

It is an absurd situation. The honourable member for Bennelong is saying that we are trying to put something into legislation, bringing this total union system into the cottage industry, which will have this devastating effect, which will destroy the world as we know it, when virtually the same provision has existed in New South Wales legislation for ages—and it is still there, despite the fact that the New South Wales legislation was massively reformed.

If this proposal is so heinous, why did Mr Greiner—the same man who brought about a royal commission into the building industry—not get rid of it? If those opposite think this piece of legislation is so heinous and will have such terrible effects, how come the man who set up this royal commission still has it in the New South Wales legislation? It is absolutely ridiculous for those opposite to make this allegation. It is a complete and utter falsehood which has been refuted time and time again. The allegation just keeps coming back as though those opposite hear nothing and learn nothing. They keep making allegations which are made absurd by the reality of the situation as it exists in the New South Wales legislation.

Of course, by far the most important issue that this nation faces at the present time is the future of the industrial relations system should the Opposition become the government of this country. The fact that those opposite do not care about the independent contractor legislation—which, as I say, is meant to ensure that we do not have sham contractors destroying award conditions—the fact that those opposite do not want that legislation to come in, is entirely consistent with their approach which, effectively, is to destroy the award system. That is the Opposition's policy. Its policy is basically to do that. Of course, those opposite have not set out exactly the final form of their policy. It seems to be talking about it in different ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives you a choice.

—Yes, a choice in that—as was put forward by the honourable member for Bennelong—if an employer says that an employee can be in the award, he can be. Is that not a terrific choice to be able to make? If the boss says it is okay, the employee can be covered by the award; but if the boss says it is not okay, an employee cannot be covered. Some choice! That is a real Claytons choice for many people in the work force.

PARA.TAB: The whole of this policy is designed to enable a massive breakdown in award conditions. Obviously it will not happen across the board. There will be areas of the economy where unions will be strong enough and where there will be enough demand for some workers' labour to ensure that that will not be the case. In other areas, where workers are weakly organised or where there is poor demand or poor bargaining power, the Opposition policy would open up massive exploitation. Those opposite know that to be the case. If that is not the case, why are those opposite proposing this? Why are they proposing something that would enable employers to provide for below award conditions?

We hear those opposite say that we are going to have some legislation to ensure that there will be sick leave or annual leave entitlements of some unspecified nature and some minimum wage which the honourable member for Bennelong told Laurie Oakes could be below the award wage. So there is some sort of protection. How we legislate for that is another interesting point in itself, since it involves a big question of constitutional power. Assuming that we can get around that, the honourable member for Bennelong said that workers will have some sort of protection.

What about all the other award conditions which people now have which they would lose in those circumstances? The whole intention of the Opposition's policy is to push people into a position where the security, the safety net, that the Australian work force has always enjoyed is no longer there; where people's conditions would be at the whim of the employer; where they could lose their award entitlements; where they could be forced into some contract which says, `You can have a 44-hour week' or, `You have no overtime rights ever' or, `You have no lunch break' or, `You have no long service leave', or, whatever the employer wants to provide. That is the sort of approach the Opposition would allow to prevail. That approach to the work force indicates a great lack of concern for people who would be unable to protect themselves.

Those opposite stand up in this place and say that they are concerned about the work force and that people will be free to bargain with their employers. It is great freedom for a kid who has just left school to work with BHP to be able to bargain with that company or to be able to go to the local milk bar proprietor and bargain with him. Who are they to bargain? How can people who are in weak bargaining positions bargain with an employer? The employer will simply say, `If you want to work here, this is how it is. There used to be award conditions. We do not have them any more. I will tell you the situation, and you will cop it or go somewhere else'. That is the situation that those opposite want to introduce into this country.

The Opposition, as the potential government of this country, is in an amazing position. It wants to walk away from the position that all conservative governments in this country have supported since Federation, as has been the case with all Labor governments. All of the coalition's conservative predecessors have maintained this system of safety nets, of award conditions. It has been a unique feature of the Australian system. It has meant that we have had protection, that we have not had the exploitation that has occurred in other countries. Yet those opposite, with this system that they would bring in, would open up this massive exploitation of the work force and force people into a position where the kinds of protection they presently have would no longer be available.

To say that the independent contractor legislation is bad legislation because it will bring the New South Wales building industrial relations system into the cottage industry is just absurd. Those opposite are against it because it is part and parcel of their whole position of opposing award conditions, wanting to break down the award system, wanting to ensure that in this country there is a system under which the vast majority of the people can be put onto lower wages and conditions. When those opposite tell people about Fightback giving them full compensation, the real joke is that not only does it not give them full compensation but also it means that under the industrial relations part of the package many people will be many dollars a week worse off as a result of what would happen to their wages and conditions. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The prediction of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) of the Government's reaction to the Gyles report is quite accurate. He says that it is predictable that that reaction will have everything to do with helping the mates, preserving the interests—the often rotten interests, the usually selfish interests—of the mates, and nothing to do with looking after Australians of whom about one million are unemployed at the moment, of whom much has to be said as they face ever declining employment opportunities and living standards. In essence, that is what this whole debate is all about.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), talked of a reduction of 60 per cent in industrial action in recent times. I remind the Minister that it is a little like inflation. As Max Walsh pointed out, it is always low in a depression. I think it is fair to say that very few people out there are willing to risk industrial action in the current climate, for the simple reason that they are all too concerned about hanging onto their jobs. I do not know whether the Government can take any great credit for that, unless it really wants to boast about having brought on the worst recession in 60 years.

If it is untrue that the sham contractors legislation will not allow increased union coverage of contracting, I ask the Minister for Finance why it is that virtually all major employer organisations in this country are massively opposed to it and are preparing to mount an enormous campaign against the Government's legislation, against its intentions, because they do not trust the Government and they do not believe that anything other than industrial mayhem, restrictive work practices and a general winding back of productivity will result from it? I would suggest that the Minister's claims are blatantly untrue and unsustainable.

The fact of the matter is that the provisions of the legislation allow unions to recruit contractors, endow the unions with exclusive representation on behalf of contractors, allow the Commission to vary contracts—in fact, to make awards for contractors—and allow the Commission to prescribe the use of contractors. Those sorts of objectives go far beyond what the Minister and, for that matter, Senator Cook in the other place, claim are the legislation's limited—that is their word, certainly not ours—objectives.

The real lie in this is totally underlined by the reality revealed in the Troubleshooters case—that most contractors end up in a situation where they get better workplace outcomes than those whose outcomes are negotiated by unions. I would suspect that the unions' real fear in all of this is the loss of control which will result as employees come to realise that the best results, the best outcomes, are not as a general rule the product of negotiations by unions.

To come back to the matter before us, which relates very much to the Gyles Royal Commission and its findings in New South Wales, we need to keep in mind what Mr Gyles said of the unions. We really need to concentrate on the power of these words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . nothing less than industrial anarchy in which any pretence of the rule of law or the application of principle has been abandoned.

That is what he said. In the interests of balance, I will insert the following because it is only fair that I do so. He said of the employers that `a spineless and expedient approach to industrial relations' was in evidence. He went on to say that the most effective way to end weaknesses, inadequacies and compromise on their behalf is in fact to address the whole question of compulsory unionism, despite the denial of this by the Minister for Finance. It is quite interesting to read what he said. He recommended that the appropriate New South Wales authority move for deregistration of the BWIU in both the Federal and New South Wales jurisdictions. He specifically mentioned the Federal responsibilities in this matter, and for that reason it is appropriate indeed that we consider these issues here before us.

PARA.TAB: He went on to say that he also observed the potential for disruption and, indeed, violence when these activists are confronted by those who have their own money at stake and either are not prepared or are unable to do the type of deal sanctioned by the major contractors. At the heart of all this lies the union commitment to militant direct action rather than compliance with the rule of law and the obligations of a registered organisation. He is basically referring here to the very union which Senator Cook, an ex-bureaucrat of that union, is prepared to bend over backwards for. For example, he has seen to its becoming a senior partner in the Building and Construction Industry Reform Authority, the much touted talkfest approach to solving the problems underlined by Gyles, who plainly regards it as inadequate. The New South Wales Government is surely correct in seeing it as nothing more than an attempt to pre-empt actions that are very damaging—if one happens to be on the side of the BWIU, as plainly Government members here are—to the interests of that organisation.

Commissioner Gyles went on to say that a comparison of the behaviour of the BWIU State branch with that of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots is most instructive. What the latter did pales into insignificance beside the conduct referred to in these reports, yet its coverage was cancelled virtually peremptorily. That is very interesting. This Government's willingness, or lack of willingness, to act in this matter will indeed, as he points out, be most instructive. I would suggest that, as the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said today, they will in due course be responding to what has been put before them. I would suggest in fact that in terms of this alone there is an enormous responsibility on the Government to bite the bullet and not attempt to evade the issues raised. Commissioner Gyles went on to say—and this is interesting too:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be those who will contend that the plan of action that I have recommended for law enforcement is confrontationalist, adversarial, union bashing and a denial of various rights.
We are hearing all that dragged out, of course, by those who feel that their interests are threatened at the moment. He went on to say:

This would be nonsense. I do not suggest any special remedies or powers be created or that anything be done which is not a normal part of the law. It is not in any sense unreasonable to expect that all should obey the law.
We would all, I hope, agree with that. But the fact of the matter is that Gyles holds out no real hope of this happening. He went on to say:

I cannot but regard the policies and personalities of the New South Wales Branch of the BWIU as being a considerable impediment to genuine workplace reform for all of the reasons to which I have referred. The fact that some arrangements may have been reached with favoured companies does not alter my view. With a serious recession in the industry—
the point that I made a moment ago—
and much more scrutiny than usual, some tactical retreats have taken place, but I do not believe that there has been any change in strategy.

As the Sydney Morning Herald put it this morning, now comes the hard part. Now comes the responsibility to do something in the wake of a royal commission which has cost $25m, which has issued a report 5,000 pages long and which makes 62 recommendations. We really have to look at what is necessary now to overcome industrial anarchy of which the Commissioner said:
There is a lack of integrity and respect for the law by a substantial cross-section of the companies, associations and unions involved.

Again we cannot escape the reality that Mr Gyles reserves his harshest words of criticism for the BWIU. He in essence blames it for the industrial mayhem which is reflected in the loss of time on major Sydney projects.

PARA.TAB: The question becomes one of how this Government will respond. There are obviously other questions but, in terms of this debate here today, that is the question before us. It is unbelievable that the Government should put the interests of its mates in the BWIU before those of the economy and the people of this country, yet that is precisely what Senator Cook and the Government appear to be about to try to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mateship.

—Mateship. The impact of inefficiencies and cost excesses in the construction industry is just not well enough understood in this country; nor are the effects of the legislation that is being put before us by Senator Cook in relation to the construction industry. It would be difficult to overstate the implications of the Bill which is about to come before us. It cannot be denied that it has the potential to totally reshape some of our industries by leading to the cessation of contracting in industries where that contracting is most successful, in those industries which are currently least unionised and where the unions are most vehemently opposed to it.

PARA.TAB: It needs to be highlighted that the building industry, for instance, has claimed that the displacement of contractors by award labour could add as much as $25,000 to the price of the average Australian home. Where is the looking after of the Australian people in that? Where, if you like, is the commitment to putting people above mates? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the more reassuring aspects of New South Wales—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I refer to standing order 196. Is the honourable member going to declare a pecuniary interest in this matter? After all, his brother's job is at risk.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —After he was Greiner's QC. Where is the conflict there? He is making money from the Royal Commissioner.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Corio keeps interjecting from a seat which is not his, and I ask you to bring that to his attention. He is lecturing everybody else in this House on a regular basis.
—Order! It is a point of order, and the honourable member for Corio might observe it.

—One of the more reassuring aspects of New South Wales politics in the last decade, as the Premier has steadily dragged the morality of the State and its institutions into a quagmire reminiscent of the nineteenth century with Parkes and Robertson, has been the continued preparedness of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) to knife the Premier on all occasions because of their longstanding vindictiveness towards each other. So it is all the more touching that today he comes here in an attempt to contrive a very convoluted defence of the State Premier, who, as we would be well aware, is in the middle of an indictment on his ethics.

PARA.TAB: Today we have an attempt to prop up a red herring royal commission undertaken, as we well realise, by the very man who has taken up a brief for the Premier in defending himself against these charges before he brought down the report. That is the first thing that perhaps puts this Royal Commission in its proper context.

It is interesting to note that when the Premier and the State Minister for industrial relations totally misconstrued the report with comments about a campaign of disruption and distortion, they went well beyond Gyles's allegations about his interpretation of industrial anarchy, et cetera. The attempt of the Premier and the Ministers to in some way impute dishonesty as being a motive for deregistration does not stand up to the light of that very inquiry, which states in its conclusions at page 130:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no acceptable evidence of widespread or serious corruption of full time union officials.One corrupt BWIU organiser was identified. He has not been employed by the union for some years, but he still purports to be able to arrange favours and rewards. There is no cause for complacency in the field, as there is ample evidence of the propensity of contractors and clients to offer money to officials of the union, whether for themselves or for the union.

In the last day or so the Premier has put a very strong emphasis on this issue of corruption. I think his own credibility with regard to morals, ethics, bribery, forgetfulness or whatever is very much in the public eye at the moment.

PARA.TAB: In contrast to minimal comments about the officials of the union, which I have just quoted—and there has been no serious evidence of corruption—a few comments have of course been made about employer thugs: people with known criminal backgrounds who have been brought into the industry by employers. On page 130, the Commissioner says:

There has been some involvement of persons who can be properly described as reputed professional criminals in the building industry. I do not refer to the many people who have been convicted of criminal offences who happen to have a job in the building industry. I speak of those who because of their criminal background and associations, and particularly because of their notorious reputation, offer services to those in the industry. These services include or purport to include infiltrating the workforce with sham unionists, intimidation of workers, union delegates and subcontractors by violence or the threat of violence;

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bennelong made the usual kind of comment about the MBA. He said, `Oh, we are going to get tough with the MBA. We are going to attack the lawyers. We are against forced unionism even in the private sector and even amongst professionals'. He delivered the usual throwaway lines in an attempt to compensate for this wholesale attack on the union movement and workers' conditions.

PARA.TAB: This New South Wales Government which now talks about deregistering the BWIU came into power with the same kind of rhetoric about how it would deal with these professionals, whether they be architects or lawyers. The only pathetic performance it put on was a five-minute debate in its caucus and Cabinet concerning conveyancing, when the Minister was repudiated and forced to retreat because he dared to actually talk about doing something about conveyancing. That is the track record of this Government in New South Wales and that is the track record of rhetoric that the honourable member for Bennelong hides behind.

It has been stated earlier that the Federal Government's attempt to do something about independent contractors is connected with a long term conspiracy theory engineered by Senator Cook because 20 years ago he was an official of the BWIU or something or other. This is somehow connected with an attempt to impose those conditions on the home building sector. The honourable member for Bennelong has continually attempted to avoid the reality that, despite the draconian industrial legislation that the Greiner Government has introduced in New South Wales in order to try to undermine people's wages, annual leave and sick leave, section 88F is, to all intents and purposes, in existence.

The honourable member might be able to argue that it does not have provisions which deal with whether people can join registered organisations and a few other technicalities, but he well knows that that legislation is the basis for undermining sham contracts. He well knows that it provides the power to set aside those contracts. He well knows that, in actuality, this legislation is largely a continuation of the legislation which the Greiner Government still enforces in New South Wales. We can talk about section 275 and section 278 of the State Act and what the State Government has done about this and that. This is one area where it has not moved, and the honourable member knows it.

A constructive element of the industry—not on the employers' or the employees' side, but the authority that is responsible for actually superintending the reorganisation of the industry—has had something to say about this situation in New South Wales. Mr Peter Barda, the Acting Chief Executive Officer of the Construction Industry Development Agency, was not too impressed with this attempt to deregister the union—the same union that in 1986 the mob opposite was hoping would wipe out the BLF.

If one were to go through the speeches made in 1986, one would expect to see instances where one or two Opposition members had got up in here and said, `The BLF is not the whole problem in the industry. There are the building workers; they are just as bad really'. One would have expected that kind of ingredient to come into the debate, but not one of them said anything. If one goes through all of the speeches—even that of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who was the most clear cut of them all in that debate—one can see that there was a constant hope that the Building Workers Industrial Union would have the strength and the guts to actually take on and defeat the BLF and do the job that they wanted done. Not one Opposition member made any attack on the BWIU or said that it was a major threat in the industry.

I have not had the opportunity to get hold of the State Hansards in the last hour or so to repeat for the honourable member for Bennelong the ringing words of praise which came from the honourable member for Camden and the honourable member for Ku-ring-gai in support of the BWIU and the unions during a series of debates in that State House. As I have said, an authority involved in this industry which does not really have a vested interest in either side has commented on this matter. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: CIDA takes a very different view. The Industry's representative structures are vital components of the reform and development strategy. Far from alienating them from the problems we are striving to involve them in the solutions. They are the signatories to the reform and development agreement together with client organisations and governments, and they have committed their memberships to its attainment.

In other words, people are trying to iron out the problems in this industry; they are trying to change work practices and they are working with employers and employees. That kind of organisation sees no valid need for this course of action; it sees it as undermining the reform process. As I have said, there are some points of interest in Commissioner Gyles's recommendations. I was particularly impressed by the racist attack on Anglo-Saxons and people of Irish descent in that report. Somehow it is a crime that four or five of the 50 or 60 officials of the union actually come from the United Kingdom and Ireland. At page 89, the Commissioner saw some great importance in this and commented:
As my inquiry progressed I could not help but notice the number of BWIU full-time officials and activists who were born in Britain or Ireland.

That is the level of intellectualism that he was able to contribute to his analysis of the industry. In conclusion, the Government of New South Wales has continued the practice of undermining unfair contracts. It has attempted to make sure that people's wages and conditions will not be undermined in a period of recession by the continuation and strengthening of unfair practices in the industry. It is absolutely ridiculous for the honourable member for Bennelong to come in here and say that the Federal Government, in attempting to bring in similar legislation, is somehow attempting to act as a stalking horse for the BWIU.
