SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes that today, 27 May 1992, is the 25th anniversary of the historic decision by the Australian people, voting in the referendum of 1967, to give the Commonwealth Government power to make laws about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and to include them in the national census;
(2)affirms that 27 May 1967 marked a turning point in the development of the Australian nation and acknowledges that the task commenced in 1967 is an ongoing one;
(3)reaffirms its commitment to the implementation of the Commonwealth's response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody; and
(4)reaffirms its commitment to the process of reconciliation and calls on all Australians to participate in this process.

On this day 25 years ago, Australians voted in a referendum by a 91 per cent margin to support change to the Australian Constitution. Some would say that such a level of support for constitutional reform would be worth commemorating in itself.On 27 May 1967, the Australian people gave the Commonwealth Parliament power to make laws with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and to include them in the national census. As with many constitutional issues, the technical meaning of these amendments does not fully explain their significance. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and many other Australians see the referendum as a turning point in black and white relations. The result of the referendum—the 91 per cent endorsement of the proposition that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were to be regarded as part of the Australian nation—signified the beginning of a new maturity of outlook and understanding of the position of indigenous Australians.

PARA.TAB: Importantly, the passage of the referendum is the very foundation of Commonwealth action in Aboriginal affairs. Without that change to the Constitution there would have been no legal or constitutional capacity for the national Parliament to make any laws directed towards Aboriginal people on a national basis, and in current times there would be no Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and no action by the Australian Parliament to initiate the process of reconciliation.
Quoting from the Yes case provided to voters 25 years ago illustrates the point. In clear terms, the pamphlet stated that the constitutional change to Commonwealth powers would:

SPEECH.PARA: remove words. . . which many people think are discriminatory against Aborigines. . .
enable the National Parliament to make laws. . . relating to Aboriginals.
and that:
the Commonwealth's object will be to cooperate with the States to ensure that together we act in the best interests of the Aboriginal people of Australia.

I believe it is important for this House to reflect on how the overwhelming endorsement of the constitutional change came about, and on the lessons that we can learn as we continue to work towards justice for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

PARA.TAB: I want to give the House five brief quotes from the debate in this House on the Constitutional Alteration (Aboriginals) Bill 1967, as I believe that they raise important issues for us to consider today. In introducing the Bill, the then Prime Minister, Mr Holt, recognised the effective public campaign which had been waged by Aboriginal people and their supporters in support of that constitutional change. The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal of thought has been given, both inside and outside the Parliament, to the constitutional provisions relating to the Aboriginal people and there has been much activity by Government private members and organisations concerned with the welfare of the Aboriginals. In the light of this activity the government . . . has decided that an amendment to the Constitution should be put to the people.

I wish to take this opportunity to pay a personal tribute to the courage, the tenacity and the dignity of all those people who worked tirelessly to organise support for that 1967 referendum and who were in every sense the driving force for the change. Another speaker in the House of Representatives debate was Gough Whitlam, the Leader of the Opposition at the time. He spoke very strongly in support of the Labor Party's support for the Bill. He said:

Members of this Parliament will be able for the first time to do something for Aboriginals—Aboriginals representing the greatest pockets of poverty and disease in this country . . . Hitherto it has been impossible for the Commonwealth to do these things directly itself. Hereafter it will be possible for the Commonwealth to provide the Aboriginals with some of that social capital with which most other Australians are already endowed.

Three other contributions to the debate are especially worth remembering, being contributions from three of the great parliamentary champions of Aboriginal people. One of those was the then member for Mackellar, Mr W. C. Wentworth. I guess in those days, many of us on this side of the House would have had profound disagreements on a range of policy questions. In that debate, he said:

Some people say—I think wrongly—that no discrimination is necessary in regard to Aboriginal people. I think that some discrimination is necessary. But I think it should be favourable, not unfavourable. . . It is not right to say to these people: `We will treat you as we would treat any other Australian.' To do this would submerge and destroy their culture.

I should mention that Bill Wentworth's commitment to the Aboriginal cause continues to this day. He, of course, was one of the people from the conservative side of politics who attended a great day in Australian history—the handing over of Uluru to Aboriginal people and the return of that place to Aboriginal people. I was delighted to see him there on that occasion. In the debate in 1967, the then member for Wills, Gordon Bryant, said:

When all is said and done, this is only the first of three steps that will have to be taken. The proposal must first be passed by the Parliament. Then we must get the support of a majority of the people in a majority of the States. Then we as a Parliament and as individual members must take up the challenge on behalf of the Aboriginal people and recover the last 180 years. . . I hope honourable members will realise that it is not sufficient just to hope and pray that this referendum will be passed. We ought, in honour bound, to campaign with the full vigour with which we campaign to return ourselves to the Parliament.

The final quotation is from what I respectfully consider to be the most powerful and far-sighted contribution to the debate on that occasion, and it came from the then member for Fremantle, Kim Beazley Sr. He said:

We have the problem that as self-government has advanced in this country, there is no question but that the status of Aboriginals has declined. . . I believe that the Government of the Commonwealth, which is exposed to the conscience of the world and must answer to the world on these issues, should have this prohibition on legislating on Aboriginal affairs . . . deleted from the Constitution.

I say that the Australian people must be deliberately responsible. I believe their very security is involved in their being able to say to the world that this community will ensure sane and just race relations.

Those words are as true now as they were in 1967. The Bill was read for a third time and, following a division, the unanimous support of the House was recorded. Members of parliament from both sides of the House took up the challenge to join with community organisations and individuals, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, to campaign for a yes vote. The question was put to the people, as I have said, on 27 May 1967 and received the overwhelming endorsement that I have already referred to.

PARA.TAB: The essential lessons that I believe this House and this Parliament should draw from the debate and the results are these: firstly, that the combined activity of members of parliament and community organisations concerned with Aboriginal people profoundly shaped and influenced the position of the government of the day and that of the Opposition in relation to the referendum; secondly, that the issues of justice for indigenous Australians ought to transcend party politics and party political point scoring and that nothing less than our identity as a nation and place in the world is at stake; and, thirdly, that the Federal Parliament has a consequent moral and political responsibility to act to redress Aboriginal disadvantage, and to seek to meet Aboriginal aspirations. If we can put aside our differences, find common ground and speak with one voice, then that leadership I believe sends a powerful message to the wider Australian community. I also believe that these lessons are of great contemporary importance.

As I have said before, the desire to regain cross-party cooperation in Aboriginal affairs was one of my first goals as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Indeed, the desire to regain and re-build the overwhelming community support achieved in 1967 was fundamental to the strategy in developing the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991. Honourable members will recall that Act achieved unanimous support of both Houses of the Parliament, and that the Act included a powerful preamble, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that as part of the reconciliation process, the Commonwealth will seek an ongoing national commitment from governments at all levels to cooperate and to coordinate with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as appropriate to address progressively Aboriginal disadvantage and aspirations in relation to land, housing, law and justice, cultural heritage, education, employment, health, infrastructure, economic development and any other relevant matters in the decade leading to the centenary of Federation, 2001.

Unanimous support was achieved, by the passage of that Bill, for an Act which requires initiatives to promote a just reconciliation between Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and the wider community; for an Act which requires extensive public education about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander history, culture, past dispossession and continuing disadvantage, and the need to address that disadvantage; and for an Act which places firmly on the public policy agenda of this country the question of whether or not that reconciliation would be advanced by a formal document or documents.

PARA.TAB: All Australians must take up the challenge begun in 1967 and involve themselves directly in promoting a lasting reconciliation to the Australian community—a reconciliation which, as the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act commits us, as a Parliament, is based on justice and which has a major focus in local communities across this country. Over the last few days many Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people have asked themselves the question: where are we 25 years down the track, and what progress have we made in ending and addressing Aboriginal disadvantage?

It is not my intention to use this occasion to be an apologist for governments around Australia for the things that remain to be done. Nor have I any intention of minimising the extent of outstanding injustice. As we know, the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody brought home to us how far we still have to go despite the great distance that we have already travelled. The Commonwealth has given support to 338 of the 339 recommendations of the Royal Commission which establish a practical and detailed agenda for change. On behalf of the Government, I take this opportunity again to express appreciation for the support given by the Opposition to the Commonwealth response to that Royal Commission.

The Government has announced new funding to implement recommendations of the report and will be announcing further funding within the month to tackle the underlying disadvantages that the Royal Commission found give rise to overrepresentation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in custody at such a shocking rate that we are all aware of. Importantly, the Government has established a rigorous and thorough regime of reporting and monitoring mechanisms. The regime is centred around monitoring by ATSIC and an annual state of the nation report to ensure that progress can be measured and that the response of governments to the Royal Commission will not be allowed to gather dust on a shelf.

In this way we can keep our nation accountable for the implementation of the Royal Commission recommendations and for meeting those Aboriginal aspirations to which the Federal Parliament has unanimously committed itself in the reconciliation process as a national objective leading to the centenary of Federation in 2001. Support has now been forthcoming from the States and Territories for the reconciliation process, and the Commonwealth will continue to work with the States to give effect to the Royal Commission recommendations.

But the Royal Commission also made it clear how important attitudes of mind and heart are in underpinning the achievement of real social justice. As was the case in the referendum result of 1967, the lasting answer to achieving justice for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people requires a change in the attitudes of all Australians. From that referendum 25 years ago grew the acknowledgment that Aboriginal people themselves could and should set the agenda; that Aboriginal political, economic and cultural values have their own validity and place within the diversity that is Australian society.

There has been increasing recognition that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people must be able to make decisions for themselves on their own future, as reflected I believe in what is now the cross-party support for the existence of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people themselves can take credit for changing the way we look at issues as they assert their aboriginality, their right to be heard, and to implement their own solutions to the issues that they face.

Clearly, there remains much to do and our speeches today should not be read by Aboriginal people, by Torres Strait Islander people, or by any Australians, as self-congratulatory. It is more a matter of acknowledging the first—but very necessary—step in formalising equitable relationships in this country. The report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody brought home to us just how far we still have to go and how important attitudes of heart and mind are in underpinning the achievement of real social justice.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) addressed the inaugural meeting of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in February. He said that, in his view, the current status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is awful and he suggested that the Council and, by implication, all of us, need to act in a practical and concrete manner to change the status quo. That indeed is the great challenge and the great opportunity facing the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation as it sets out on its historic task.

Experience since 1967 has shown us that there is more to social justice than carefully designed programs of assistance. That is where the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation has an important role. The Council is to be the catalyst in seeking a better knowledge and understanding of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, their cultures and experiences, so that there can be fundamental changes in attitudes, and therefore in relationships. When we have achieved that attitudinal change we may have discovered what are the missing pieces of the jigsaw that prevent us from completing the picture of Australia that we want to see and be part of.

As were the efforts that produced the referendum result of 1967, the lasting answer to the relationship issue rests with people, with the ordinary people of this country, and with their attitudes towards one another. There can be no higher objective for our country and its people, as we count down towards the centenary of the Australian Federation, than that we achieve a just reconciliation between the wider community and the original inhabitants, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country, the first Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-five years ago today Australians voted in a Federal referendum to break the nexus between the number of senators and the number of members of the House of Representatives; to allow the Federal Parliament to make laws relating to Aboriginal people; and to remove a section of the Constitution which prevented Aboriginal people being counted in the reckoning of the numbers of people in the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The first proposal to break the nexus was defeated and yet, in spite of being coupled with this controversial proposal, the second and third proposals were voted on as one and received the highest support of any single referendum proposal in our country's history. Nearly 91 per cent of Australians voted yes; in my home State of Victoria the figure was nearly 95 per cent yes, and the lowest vote in any State was still over 80 per cent in Western Australia.

Over time events can gather their own mythology. Reading the newspapers today one can be excused for believing these proposals had something to do with Aboriginal people gaining the vote, equal pay, or full Australian citizenship. It was none of these. So what is it today that we are actually commemorating?

To my way of thinking, the 1967 referendum did two things: first, it was a time when white Australia considered the situation of Aboriginal people and extended a hand of friendship. The Australian Parliament, and then the Australian community, stated very clearly that they wanted something done to assist Aboriginal people. Secondly, this was the first time that Aboriginal people created a role for themselves in the political process—people such as Charlie Perkins and Faith Bandler. Not only did they create a role for themselves; they created a positive outcome. Both these people have gone on to give a lifetime service towards advancing the welfare of Aboriginal people. So what were these two sections of the Constitution? Section 51 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:-
The people of any race, other than the aboriginal race in any State, for whom it is deemed necessary . . .
Section 127 states:
In reckoning the numbers of the people of the Commonwealth, or of a State or other part of the Commonwealth, aboriginal natives shall not be counted.

It seems extraordinary that the founding fathers actually paid no attention to Australia's Aborigines in drafting the Constitution and that the only two references are highly negative in character. When one looks through the debates of Federal conferences and conventions of 1890, 1891, 1897 and 1898, what is surprising is that it was not merely that the founders treated Aboriginal questions as a matter for the States, but rather that the position of the Aborigines was never mentioned. In those debates no delegate ever suggested, even in passing, that there might be some national obligation to Australia's indigenous people. In the debates concerning section 51, the exclusion of Aborigines was never mentioned at all; it was simply taken for granted. In the debates concerning section 127, Aborigines were barely mentioned.

PARA.TAB: When giving evidence on Aboriginal questions for the 1927-29 Royal Commission on the Constitution, the Chief Protector of Aborigines in Western Australia suggested that the inference of the founding fathers to such questions was due to two main reasons: first, there was no reliable counts of the Aboriginal population available at the time and guesses tended to grossly underestimate the likely numbers; and, secondly, it was thought that Aboriginal people were a dying race whose future was unimportant.

To be fair to our founding fathers, I must say that their original intention may not have been what we imagine today. Geoffrey Sawyer, then a professor of law at the Australian National University, wrote in the mid-1960s:

SPEECH.PARA: The exclusion of the Aborigines may not necessarily have been against their interests in accordance with ideas at the time; while they might have lost the possibility of Commonwealth laws for their protection and advancement, so far as such laws have to depend on Section 26, they were also saved from the sort of laws against their interests which were uppermost in the minds of the delegates as likely to be passed.

Such laws against certain racial groupings were certainly common around the world at the time. Section 127 of the Constitution is even more curious. In every account that I have read over the last couple of days about the 1967 referendum, this is referred to as the section which allowed Aboriginal people to be counted in the census. However, this almost certainly was not the intent of the original draft of the Constitution.

PARA.TAB: If one relates this section of the Constitution to the entire Constitution, one is faced with the question: under what sections of the Constitution is a reckoning of numbers of people of operational importance? This really applies only to section 24. This section relates to the calculation of the membership of the House of Representatives to be distributed amongst the States.

If one looks at the constitutional debates at the time, one gets the view that section 127 was not a blanket prohibition on counting Aborigines, but it was related to the specific operational clauses of the Constitution. It would appear that section 127 related to the difficulties of calculating the entitlement of seats, and thus it only ever had a very restricted scope. Sadly, notwithstanding this, it became to be used generally. From an early date, Commonwealth authorities acting under the Census Act took the view that section 127 was a qualification on the census power and that accordingly, when taking censuses and publishing population figures, the Bureau must not include full blood Aborigines. This was clearly ludicrous. Nonetheless, in censuses published since the first census in 1911, a note to this effect appeared:

SPEECH.PARA: No State ever felt bound by such a restriction and even though the Constitution did not provide any definition of Aboriginal native the census interpretation restricted it to full blood aborigines.
The ludicrous nature of the interpretation of the Bureau of Census was carried further when the Bureau presumed to count Torres Strait Islanders in the census but not Aborigines.

PARA.TAB: So it was against this background that referenda proposals centred on removing the negative references to Aboriginal people in Australia's Constitution. This was not the first time that we had such a constitutional debate in this country. On 19 August 1944, under the heading `Post-war Reconstruction and Democratic Rights', the Australian public voted on 14 powers to be transferred to the Commonwealth for a period of five years. These included empowering the Commonwealth to legislate with respect to people of the Aboriginal race. This was a curious grab bag of proposals—some of which had been rejected as early as 1913; others, the so-called democratic rights, were rejected overwhelmingly by the people in 1988. This proposal was rejected. In 1944 Aboriginal people and Aboriginal people's involvement in that debate barely got off the ground.

The debate in 1967 was different. Aboriginal people were different in that they were vocal and they were participants. They had survived and their culture had survived. The day before the referendum, Faith Bandler wrote the following:

SPEECH.PARA: For Aborigines an overwhelming Yes vote can mean a new life of hope—when you write Yes in the lower square of your ballot paper you are holding out the hand of friendship and wiping out nearly 200 years of injustice and inhumanity.
She continued:
Only the Federal Government has the money and so by voting Yes you give the responsibility to the National Parliament and make possible a real programme of equal rights and equal opportunity. . .

The ground swell of support for this proposal was so overwhelming that the Electoral Commission sent out only the yes case. When queried about this, it replied, `We have yet to learn that any opposition to the Aboriginal proposal exists from any quarter'. The rest is history.

PARA.TAB: Today we celebrate that hope and remember a time when the Australian population expressed a very clear wish for improvement in the condition and opportunity for Aboriginal Australians. Twenty-five years is nearly a generation. In fact, fully 60 per cent of Aboriginal people alive today were not born when this referendum was passed. It is worth reflecting today on where we are 25 years later. What has been achieved and what is still to be achieved?

The year following the referendum an office of Aboriginal Affairs was established and W. C. Wentworth became the first Minister with direct responsibility for Aboriginal Affairs. Commonwealth funding for Aboriginal programs has increased well over tenfold in real terms since 1970-71, when there was the first substantial budget allocation.

We are entitled to ask: what results have we seen? The answer is mixed. There are some real achievements in education. We have gone from a situation where in 1972 only 72 Aborigines were in higher education in Australia to today, when we have nearly 4,000. We have gone from a situation where in 1967 there were absolutely no Aborigines holding positions in higher occupational status categories to today, when, although there are not many, there are some Aboriginal people at the top, and the number is growing.

In the area of health, there has been a dramatic success with the reduction of infant mortality. Twenty-five years ago in the Northern Territory nearly 10 per cent of Aboriginal infants died. Today that has been reduced by 70 per cent. While that is still high, it shows a dramatic turnaround. Aboriginal people are running successful enterprises and organisations. Fifteen years ago, the Aboriginal community of Warburton in Western Australia was mentioned in this Parliament on three occasions within a month as being one of the most desperate, violent and depraved places in the country. Today it is a model community which is quite distinguishable from its difficult past.

Aboriginal enterprises in Cardwell in north Queensland, Woorabinda in central Queensland and the Aboriginal communities at Moree and Port Lincoln all have one thing in common: they have happened when Aboriginal people have become tired of waiting and decided to do things for themselves. It has needed help, encouragement and patience from the broader community, but in the end it has been Aboriginal people doing it for themselves. In central Australia, the Tangentyre Council provides a model for Aboriginal organisations. It is currently looking to diversify its enterprise operations and to expand its financial base.

Finally, on the positive side, Aboriginal people are participating more in all aspects of Australian life. The Wiluna Shire Council in Western Australia is now Aboriginal controlled; it is the only shire council in Australia to be so. In the Northern Territory, Aboriginal communities have incorporated under the Northern Territory's Local Government Act and are managing their own affairs at a local level. This is an enormously exciting development and it will require just as much patience and sensitivity as we can muster.

This is not to pretend that many challenges still do not face us. Aboriginal health and Aboriginal employment, particularly Aboriginal self-employment, are areas where we have to say that to date we have failed. Even today in Australia, Aboriginal life expectancy of men and women is 17 to 18 years less than that for the general population. For the New Zealand Maori it is six years less. In parts of Australia life expectancy is actually decreasing. In parts of central Australia the life expectancy for an adult male is just over 40 years of age. It can be conclusively shown that this life expectancy has dropped every decade since the Second World War. All this is happening while Aboriginal infant mortality is improving. So clearly we have to be honest with ourselves here and realise that our efforts to date have not been up to the mark.

The Aboriginal unemployment rate has increased from 18 per cent in 1976 to 24 per cent in 1981 and to 35 per cent in 1986. Employment as a percentage of the Aboriginal population is falling, whereas until recent times in the rest of the country it had increased. Only 2 1/2 per cent of Aborigines in Australia are self-employed, compared with 15 per cent for the rest of the population, and virtually nothing exists in this country to help them get the skills to enter business for themselves.

This takes me to the last point that I wish to make. It seems to me that there is almost no innovation in Aboriginal Affairs today. We have reached a point where much of the fire, the innovation and the dynamism of early days has gone. We have now created many Aboriginal organisations that, in effect, strangle the emergence of any new or competing organisation. This is a tragedy because it is just in that period of establishment in the early days of growth that an organisation is its most dynamic, productive and innovative. I still find it a tragedy that, in spite of 68 per cent of people in south-east Arnhem Land voting for their own land council in a plebiscite in 1990, those people have been denied it on a legal technicality.

A similar thing happened in central Australia, where an organisation representing the Arrente people had its funding denied lest it be a threat to established organisations. I was on the Gove Peninsula last week and met with the clan leaders of the 13 clans in the area. They are concerned that windfall royalty moneys coming from Nabalco are going to be used not to provide long term benefit to the clans in the area, but rather to expand land council operations. These are the same people who brought the bark petition to this Parliament in 1970, which, along with the walk-off from Wave Hill station, signalled the beginnings of the land rights movement. That bark petition is framed in this Parliament. The only survivor of the original signatories, Roy Marrika, is the senior clan leader in the Gove Peninsula today.

He and 12 other leaders are once again to approach this Parliament to ask that moneys from mining be more directly used to the benefit of those affected by the mining, and to provide some long term security free of welfare. It will be interesting to see the reception they get, for, rather than fighting white insensitivity as they were 22 years ago, today they are fighting entrenched Aboriginal interests.

With those comments and that background, I am here to celebrate hope. The hope was set alight 25 years ago. It has flickered and it has waned, but it is still alive. It is alive in a move to seek greater common ground in Aboriginal affairs; it is alive in the tireless work of ATSIC commissioners. The Royal Commission showed that there was considerable agreement on the way ahead in Aboriginal affairs, and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is a chance for Australia to examine the place of Aboriginal people in the Australian nation, and the type of nation we wish to be. We finally have a chance to put the neglect and insensitivities of the past behind us. We owe it to our future and our children not to waste this opportunity.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Refurbishment of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Perth

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Refurbishment of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve Bank of Australia, Perth branch, has operated from its current premises since it was completed in 1973. The building no longer complies with current building regulations in a number of respects, and some services are nearing the end of their operational life. A substantial refurbishment is required to meet current standards for safety, accommodation, amenities and operational efficiency. The proposed scope of work will comprise upgrading of basements and office areas, including the removal of asbestos fire retardant material in ceiling spaces; the installation of new ceilings, carpets and building services; and the extension of a sprinkler fire service to all levels of the building.

PARA.TAB: The estimated capital cost is $34m in April 1992 prices, with funds to be provided from the budget of the Reserve Bank of Australia. This is a significant public work which will materially improve the operational facility of the Reserve Bank of Australia and generate significant leasing income. On behalf of the Minister I table the supporting drawings, and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Defence Logistics Redevelopment Project

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Defence Logistics Redevelopment Project—Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre and Air Force aspects.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion relates to the Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre and the Air Force component of the defence logistics redevelopment project. The Navy and Army components of the project are yet to be fully developed and will be the subject of separate approval.

PARA.TAB: The defence logistics redevelopment project, which was announced by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) in June 1990, implements a rationalised and centralised strategy of wholesale storage and distribution for the Australian Defence Force. Substantial savings will be achieved through the reduction in operating and manpower costs.

Revenue from the subsequent disposal of redundant property at Randwick, Zetland, Regents Park, Broadmeadows, Tottenham, Banyo and Toowoomba will largely offset the cost of the project. A central part of this strategy is a modern tri-service storage and distribution facility, the Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre, which is to be established primarily at Moorebank. Additional warehousing accommodation at Leichhardt, Regents Park, Bathurst and Dubbo will also be used.

Concurrently, each service will improve its regional warehousing infrastructure. The Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre will accommodate most of Navy stocks, a small element of Air Force stocks and part of the Army national stocks, plus those Army logistics functions currently the responsibility of the Moorebank logistics group.

The accommodation provided will be a combination of new facilities and existing facilities, which will be upgraded where appropriate. This will give the Defence Force a modern and efficient warehousing complex which will enable current technology and systems to be best utilised. The construction of the Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre will allow the closure of warehousing operations at Randwick, Zetland and Penrith and will contribute to the part closure at Regents Park.

The Air Force component will enable the relocation of the majority of Air Force stocks to bases, and will involve the modernisation of storage and handling systems in warehousing accommodation at seven operational bases. This will allow the disposal of property at Tottenham, Toowoomba and Regents Park. Additionally, other activities such as one operational support unit and air training corps located at sites identified for disposal will be relocated.

Environmental effects of the planned redevelopment works have been determined to be minimal as works are restricted to the confines of existing bases. An environmental certificate of compliance has been issued. The cost estimates of the proposed works at April 1992 prices are $100m for the Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre and $27m for the Air Force component. On behalf of the Minister, I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition is pleased to support this reference to the Public Works Committee because there is an urgent need to reform the logistics area of the defence establishment. The logistics area is a perfect example of the problems of defence which we on this side of the House have been highlighting for some time. According to Department of Defence figures, there are some 14,000 military and civilian people employed in defence stores and armaments depots, and nearly 7,500 of these people are in the Defence Force itself. That is, there are 7,500 uniformed people performing an essentially civilian job.

PARA.TAB: The Government's own figures tell us that currently some 14,500 service people are classified as having `front line combat' positions. So the ratio of front line combat people to people in the stores and depot areas is 1:1. We do not think that is particularly appropriate. Obviously, there is a need to reform this area of Defence, and we have been calling for a refocusing of Defence effort on building up the combat forces. In this reference, the Public Works Committee will consider the development of the National Defence Storage and Distribution Centre. The development of this centre will result in the closure of a number of single service stores depots and the creation of tri-service centres. This should realise considerable savings, but there will be scope to go further than the defence logistics redevelopment project currently proposes to do in contracting the management of defence stores out to the private sector, and in making the management process more efficient.

Quite simply, this has to be done. It is no longer acceptable that such a massive proportion of defence manpower should be devoted to the stores area. We on this side of the House welcome this reference to the Public Works Committee because we believe that a more cost-efficient defence stores system will be the result. This is in line with our policy for defence, which will be to reduce as far as possible the defence support area and contract a good deal of it out, and to beef up our limited combat forces.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill presented by Mr Hand, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill gives legislative effect to a registration scheme for migration agents designed to improve standards of professional conduct and quality of service. I announced the proposed establishment of the scheme on 11 December 1991.

PARA.TAB: The registration arrangements are expected to begin operation in mid-September of this year. They are to apply to agents operating in Australia and involve defining a migration agent, establishing a Migration Agents Registration Board and adopting a code of conduct.

This initiative reflects the Government's concern over the level and nature of complaints made against incompetent or unscrupulous agents, complaints which would be familiar to many members of this chamber. It also recognises the fact that many of those who are likely to seek the assistance of agents are among the most vulnerable in our society, sometimes having a poor grasp of English, fear of authority or meagre financial resources. This is not to say that the great majority of agents are not honest and efficient. It is a sad fact of life that the activities of a minority have tended to tarnish the reputation of migration agents as a whole.

I do not intend to list comprehensively problems which led to the development of the scheme, but some examples include agents having been paid to lodge applications and then failing to do so; lodging applications without paying the prescribed fees, thereby not giving effect to the application; lodging applications tardily in a way which adversely affects the entitlements of applicants; and holding passports as `security and then demanding extra payments'. There are also examples of agents providing incompetent advice because they lack even a rudimentary knowledge of the Migration Act and regulations.

These problems are not new ones and there have been attempts by previous governments to find legislative remedies. Up to December 1989 a registration procedure existed which required persons wishing to practise as migration agents to notify the Secretary to my Department. This practice provided no real basis for regulating the activities of migration agents.

The Government sought to strengthen migration agent provisions in December 1989 when major amendments were made to the Migration Act, following its consideration of the recommendations of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, CAAIP. These amendments required migration agents not to engage in false advertising, to provide statements of accounts to clients and to not misrepresent their relationship with the Government and the Department. They were underpinned by appropriate penalty provisions.

While these were worthwhile initiatives, experience has shown that they have not gone far enough in addressing the problems. Accordingly, the Government had to look at formulating a more comprehensive means of regulating migration agents. This was not an easy task, given the complexity of the problems and competing interests involved. I also understand that Australia is the first country with a major immigration program to introduce regulatory arrangements of this kind.

The Government considered a range of options and carried out extensive consultations with the Migration Institute of Australia, ethnic community organisations, community based migration advice agencies and the legal profession. These consultations have been very fruitful and an important step in the development of the scheme.

The possibility of self-regulation was considered but rejected. This was because self-regulation assumes the existence of a well-organised and clearly identified group of individuals and corporations engaged in an activity. The reality is that there is a high level of fragmentation with professions organised into their own distinct associations, with a significant number of persons acting alone. Consideration was also given to a system where agents could practise unless specifically barred or, in more technical language, negative licensing. This approach was rejected for a number of reasons.

The Government was concerned that the lack of contact with migration agents involved in negative licensing would have posed significant difficulties. These included ensuring that people recognised when they were operating as migration agents, understood the code of conduct and the need to adhere to it.

The Government also took the view that migration agents should meet the cost of regulation because they were likely to benefit from the development of a more cohesive and reputable industry, in the medium to long term, and because of the need for budget discipline. Part of the revenue from the registration fees will be provided to community based migration advice agencies. Fee levels are dealt with in the accompanying tax Bills.

There was a need to minimise the risk of anti-competitive behaviour that might result from restricting entry into the industry. This has been achieved in a number of ways. Resources will be directed to the investigation of complaints rather than erecting in the legislation entry barriers at too high a level. The composition of the Migration Agents Registration Board has been deliberately mixed so that both industry and consumer interests are represented. Disclosure of interest provisions has been made.

I turn now to the details of the scheme. A central feature of the scheme is the establishment of a Migration Agents Registration Board, which will have the power to issue warnings, to suspend, to deregister and to refuse applications for registration. It will comprise ministerially appointed representatives from industry, the legal profession, the ethnic community, which has a strong consumer interest in the services provided by migration agents, and the Immigration Review Tribunal. It will be chaired by the Secretary to my Department or a nominee of the Secretary.

Applications and any consequential investigations will be conducted in the strictest confidence. The registration process has been designed to allow fast tracking of applicants by the Secretary to my Department. However, this can occur only in accordance with carefully specified circumstances involving little discretion. If any of a range of concerns are triggered, such as complaints being lodged against an applicant or questions of character being raised, then the board must deal with the case. Nevertheless, I consider that most applications will be able to be approved under the fast track route.

A registration process involving basic checks of integrity will be introduced. To be eligible for registration an applicant must be at least 18 years of age; be an Australian citizen or an Australian permanent resident; be a person of integrity; and meet certain other entrance requirements. The applicant also must not be an undischarged bankrupt and must endorse a prescribed code of conduct.

Members of the public will have the opportunity to lodge complaints within a six-week gazettal period before applicants can be registered. After registration the public will be able to lodge complaints at any time and will have the benefit of the code of conduct to guide their expectations of agent behaviour.

I referred above to a code of conduct. This is a critical element of the scheme. This document is still subject to refinement in the light of ongoing consultations. The code will go beyond a listing of general objectives often associated with such a document. It will delineate a range of unacceptable behaviour to provide a guide to agents and consumers alike. While the code explicitly does not seek to be exhaustive, its scope will be such that it would be difficult for those acting unprofessionally or unethically to claim ignorance as a defence. This should make it easier for the board to perform its functions and deter unacceptable behaviour.

The code will be prescribed by regulation. It will be capable of adjustment in response to input from migration agents and consumers alike. Decisions on registration have the potential to very significantly affect the livelihood of individuals. Accordingly, the Bill allows for appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, where agents are dissatisfied with adverse decisions by the board.

The Government has carefully considered the activities which should be regulated by this legislation. Broad definitions have been adopted to minimise avoidance. In essence, a migration agent is defined to be a person who uses knowledge of, or skill in, migration law and procedure to assist in the making of an application for a visa or entry permit or for refugee status. It extends to advice and assistance relating to adverse decisions on applications, whether in a court or before review bodies.

I note that the qualification of knowledge and experience is an important one because it excludes those providing more mechanical assistance, such as typists and interpreters. Because of the significant role played by solicitors and barristers in providing immigration assistance, those who provide such assistance will need to apply for registration. Clearly, a regulatory scheme which missed these members of the legal profession would be deficient.
There also have been concerns that serious complaints have been made against some members of the legal profession without its self-regulatory mechanisms responding with adequate timeliness or vigour.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't stop them giving legal advice, can you?

—The honourable member for Dundas has read the explanatory notes. He is aware of that. He was briefed for about 2 1/2 hours last night. Solicitors and barristers will not need to register in respect of their activities before the courts or if they are providing general legal migration advice unrelated to the completion and lodgement of applications. Registration will, however, be required in relation to the making of visa or entry applications under the Migration Act. The board also will be able to investigate complaints against lawyers arising from the provision of immigration legal assistance to allow cases to be effectively referred to professional associations for possible disciplinary action.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make one further point on the extension of this scheme to some activities of the legal profession. The registration arrangements proposed by the Government will be evaluated after two years. While there will be a range of issues that will need to be carefully considered at that time, the Government will closely examine any progress made by the legal profession in strengthening its self-regulatory mechanisms.

In the meantime, the Government hopes to maintain a close dialogue with the legal profession, which made some useful contributions to the development of the scheme, although it opposed any coverage of barristers and solicitors. Similarly, the Government will continue its close dialogue with the Migration Institute of Australia, which has already taken steps to develop training courses and a fellowship scheme that promises to lead to higher professional standards and improved self-regulation. The scheme is backed up by tough penalties reflecting the Government's concerns.

I would now like to turn briefly to a number of implementation issues. The Government has been concerned not to disrupt the activities of migration agents, many of whom offer a valuable service. This will be facilitated by the fast track provisions that I referred to earlier.

The transition provisions also have been framed to allow those who are currently practising as migration agents to lodge an application and to continue practising while their applications are being determined. This is because, like most such schemes when they are introduced, there initially will be a large number of applications needing to be determined.

In order that consumers and agents alike are aware of the scheme, extensive publicity is planned. Steps will be taken to provide agents with advance warning of changes to the code of conduct. In conclusion, this Bill arises because of problems that former legislative measures and self-regulation have not been able to remedy. Accordingly, the Government is taking on that challenge.

However, the introduction of this regulatory scheme may well act as a catalyst in drawing together migration agents in a way which will encourage self-regulation and provide future governments greater flexibility in addressing the underlying issues. This is reflected in the sunset provisions of the Act and my comments on the review of the scheme at the end of a two-year period. I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Hand, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to impose a levy on an individual's making of a registration application. The Bill exempts an applicant who proposes to give immigration assistance to entrance applicants only in a capacity as an employee of, or a voluntary worker for, a person or organisation that does not charge entrance applicants a fee, nor require any other reward from them, for the giving of such assistance.

PARA.TAB: This reflects the Government's view that, while there is a need for voluntary agencies to be subject to the code of conduct and other provisions of the Bill, payment of the levy by such agencies would be inappropriate.

The levy of $500 is imposed on an individual in the following circumstances. First, when the individual proposes to give immigration assistance in the capacity of an employee of a registered agent. Second, when the individual proposes to provide immigration assistance in the capacity of an employee of a partnership at least one of whose members is a registered agent. Third, when the individual proposes to provide immigration advice in the capacity of the employee of a corporation at least one of whose executive officers is a registered agent. In any other case the levy is $1,000. I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Hand, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to impose a levy on renewal of an individual's registration as a registered agent. The Bill exempts a registered agent who gives immigration assistance to entrance applicants only in a capacity as an employee of, or a voluntary worker for, a person or organisation that does not charge entrance applicants a fee, nor require any other reward from them, for the giving of such assistance.

PARA.TAB: This reflects the Government's view that, while there is a need for voluntary agencies to be subject to the code of conduct and other provisions of the Bill, payment of the levy by such agencies would be inappropriate.

The levy of $500 is payable by an individual in the following circumstances. First, when the individual whose registration is renewed and who gives immigration assistance in the capacity of an employee of a registered agent. Second, when the individual provides immigration assistance in the capacity of an employee of a partnership at least one of whose members is a registered agent. Third, when the individual provides such advice in the capacity of the employee of a corporation at least one of whose executive officers is a registered agent. In any other case the levy is $1,000. I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
