PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
SOCIAL SECURITY (FAMILY PAYMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992
VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Dr Blewett:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill concurrently with the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

—The legislation before the House is in a cognate form. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill contain a number of quite significant clauses. I should say at the outset that the Opposition does not propose to oppose the legislation because some of the changes it contains are definitely in the interests of the beneficiaries of the various payments contained therein. Nevertheless, we will be moving a second reading amendment in relation to our grave concern at the failure of the Government's economic policies over recent years and the massive social dislocation which they have caused, and recommending to the Government that it should introduce as soon as possible the Opposition's Fightback plan which will undoubtedly help to rebuild Australia and get Australian families back on their feet.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of items I would like to refer to briefly in terms of the two Bills, and I shall combine them for the purpose of the debate. The legislation contains a provision for the introduction of a telephone allowance. This we see as a step forward. There have been some problems with the previous system of giving beneficiaries access to telephone concessions which has resulted, regrettably, in many cases of misuse. The Bill introduces a telephone allowance which will replace the previous vouchers. The rate of the allowance will be $51.80 per household and the amount will be indexed yearly and made available on a regular basis to beneficiaries.

The second reform of some interest is the change to the bereavement provisions. The Department of Social Security currently grants a range of concessions where there is a bereavement and the Bill will implement a number of provisions in this regard. I should say, however, that the provisions contained are not as generous as those contained in the Fightback package where we have clearly enunciated the fact that where there are cases of financial difficulty we believe people should have access to an additional payment—that is, the combined married rate pension payment—for up to six months; whereas the Government is providing that payment only for a very short period.

There is a further change which has caused some concern to both ACOSS and the Welfare Rights Centre. I refer to the removal of the Job Search and Newstart training supplement under the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill. The Opposition is not opposing the Government in this area because we share with the Government some concern to ensure that the JSA payment structure does not introduce a disincentive for young people to undertake long term education.

The Welfare Rights Centre has put forward what I regard as a cogent case in this matter. It has raised a number of issues which perhaps need to be looked at in greater detail subsequently. For example, it claims that the policy assumes that JSA and Austudy have been equated in every respect and that there is now a nexus that cannot be broken without introducing inconsistencies and loopholes. It claims that this is incorrect, that only the rates of Austudy and JSA have been aligned, and that many other differences exist, especially in relation to income tests, which make such comparisons invalid. This is a matter which no doubt the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, will be prepared to explain to us in some detail at the cessation of this debate. The issues raised may have some substance although, as I have said, the Opposition supports the proposals at this stage because we do not want to introduce any disincentives for young people to undertake long term education.

The Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill contains a wide range of other significant changes to the system which we believe are an improvement. For example, the integration of family allowance supplement and additional pension and benefit results in a program totalling some $2 billion, assisting some 800,000 families or nearly 1 1/2 million children. In addition, the family allowance and the family allowance supplement will be amalgamated into a single payment, with entitlement calculated on a two-step income and assets test basis.

The advantage of the changes, apart from the fact that one could legitimately say that they are mainly really name changes rather than substantive changes, is that they take account of the fact that many low income families face the difficulty of receiving most payments more or less in one lot over a month period whereas, if they can break that into two payments of a substantive nature, that will help the families concerned to budget more effectively. We support that view. The additional family payment that will bring together the various income allowance supplements and additional pension benefits such as rent assistance, the guardians allowance and so forth, will certainly enable a second payment to be made during that period with considerable advantages.

The other major advantage in the proposal is that it ameliorates to some extent some of the existing poverty traps that exist in the system where recipients of income support perceive that they have little financial incentive to increase their income from earnings. This proposal, therefore, does go some way towards overcoming some of those real problems and therefore encouraging people, especially single parents, to go into the work force.

In addition, it is claimed by the Government that some 35 million families will receive additional family allowance as a result of the new data matching for families contained in these proposals. There is some concern, which has been voiced by some of my colleagues, about the extent to which the data matching of profiles will extend beyond the existing provisions. I understand that the Government proposes to make subsequent amendments to the appropriate legislation in this field. But overall, as I have said, while we will move a second reading amendment, we do support the proposals in this legislation.

The sad fact is that 1.4 million Australians now receive welfare benefits in the form of unemployment, single parent or disability pensions. We are seeing today, despite the commitment made by the previous Prime Minister that by 1990 no child would live in poverty, the simple situation that, according to ACOSS, over 600,000 children are directly affected by poverty caused principally by unemployment or serious underemployment. The number of children living in families below the Henderson poverty line rose from 400,000 in 1989-90 to 600,000 in recent times, and the prospects are that the number could well be increasing. For example, the Salvation Army alone is facing some 6,000 client families and is unable to meet the unprecedented demand. The inner city crisis centres experienced a 100 per cent increase in numbers over the last 12 months alone. The Smith Family recently announced a 35 per cent rise in numbers seeking assistance over the past year, and 70 per cent of the increase consisted of families who had never before sought assistance.

The Fightback proposals contain a very important additional support for welfare agencies in the private sector and for their clients. We will provide an additional $50m to welfare agencies so that organisations such as the Sydney City Mission, for example, will be able to directly provide additional places in their excellent training programs to help the many thousands of Australians who today face such serious economic and social hardship.

There is no doubt that one in five children now live in families which do not have an adult in full time employment. As I have said, the real fear is that that figure will tend to grow further. We now face the situation, according to the official figures, of nearly one million people unemployed, and it is estimated that a further 500,000 are facing underemployment. That represents 10.4 per cent of the full time work force in April. At the last election in March 1990, which was not very long ago, the number of people unemployed was 512,000. In April 1992 it was 886,700. That represents an extra 374,000 unemployed in 25 months—an extra 3,416 unemployed a week, an extra 488 unemployed a day, an extra 20 unemployed an hour and an extra one unemployed every three minutes. So, while the audience in this House has been listening to this debate, we have already added at least another 14 people to the unemployed list on the basis of these aggregate figures. Regrettably, youth unemployment represents three times the national average.

Is it any wonder, therefore, that in virtually every area of social policy facing this country, whether in terms of education, social problems caused by bankruptcy or family breakdown, the statistics are simply horrendous. We know that some 49,700 qualified young people missed out on university entrance places this year. That represents a shortfall of up to 70 per cent on last year. I ask anybody in this House representing the Government to give us a commitment here and now that we will not see an increase in that percentage at the end of this academic year.

Let us look at the problem of bankruptcy. In the December quarter 4,764 individual and business bankruptcies were recorded, which was an increase of 39 per cent from the December quarter of 1990. There were 13,700 in 1991, an increase of 50.3 per cent from 1989-90. In fact, the 1990-91 statistic represents the highest number of bankruptcies on record in Australia.

In the field of family breakdown, a large component of which is clearly the result of economic dislocation and failure of families to find work, 44,913 children were dependent on parents who were divorcing in 1990. In the same year 42,635 families broke down according to law.

In One Nation the Government has given families on incomes up to $60,000 a cash handout through the family allowance system. Why has it done that? Was it because it was sorry for the recession? Is that the best it can say? Surely that is not the way to get people back on their feet. What families are looking for today is some sense of hope and a belief that there is a plan in existence to lead this country forward and to give some prospect of a better future for themselves and their children.

Unfortunately, hundreds of thousands of Australian families, and especially their children, have become undermined and disillusioned not just by the recession, which is an absolute national disgrace, but by the fact that we have in Australia a government which is now in its tenth year in power. Despite all the hopes and expectations of the past, despite all the promises made by the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), especially on the nights when he stood at the dispatch box in this chamber and told us of the glories of what he had achieved and what he would achieve in the future, it has all turned to dust in our hands and we now see an economy that is no longer capable of employing its people, no longer capable of giving a decent education to its children and, above all, no longer capable of giving them a sense of future, a sense of pride, a sense of belonging and a sense of worth. They are the most damaging legacies which will be left to the Australian people by this Hawke-Keating Government and which we when our turn comes will have a difficult road to build up again.

Nevertheless, the Fightback package is based on the premise that we are prepared to make a commitment that we will put back into employment at least two million Australians by the year 2000. That is still not enough; we accept that. But to get it higher than that will depend on the success and implementation of our blueprint, our economic and social plans for Australia.

While the Government has fiddled around the edges with these amendments—that is really what it has done—the reality is that the stable door in so many respects has already been closed and, unfortunately, the horse of unemployment—and all the social dislocation and decay that it carries with it—has already bolted. So, while most of the amendments are worth while, regrettably they do not address the main problem, which is the social destruction caused to so many Australian families and their children by the recession. Regrettably, the Government is offering an unfunded conglomeration of half measures in the name of a One Nation package. We do not want fiddling at the edges. We want real answers and a real direction, and that is what is given by Fightback.

The economic plan, Fightback, will effectively create jobs. It is an active policy, not a reactive one. It will help people to help themselves. Australia needs an active plan, which clearly is not forthcoming from the Government despite the recession—nearly a depression in parts of Australia—created by its economic policies. In the welfare system, the unemployment policy of the present Government, in particular, is not working as efficiently as it should. Fightback will relieve most of the taxes on business, will reform the labour market and will create opportunities for employment to, above all, give employers a sense of confidence that they can employ more people, can develop markets, can create productivity and can cut their costs. That is why we have been prepared to make the commitment to create two million new jobs.

What have we heard from the Government? Not a word. There are no commitments in the so-called One Nation statement because the Government knows that it cannot build a successful economy on the ruins of the failure of the recent years simply by increasing national debt. Our role is to pay off our national debt and get Australia back to self-sustained economic growth as soon as we possibly can.

For that reason the Fightback package offers families significant personal income tax cuts, increases in family allowance benefits and increases in the dependent spouse rebate. It offers tax credits for private health insurance; superannuation reforms; significant reductions in the costs of fuel in terms of production as well as for the ordinary person using a car; a first home owners scheme; a tax free savings scheme; a tax rebate for child-care; and a zero rating in terms of GST on health and education, and some other services.

To us, jobs are a fundamental priority. This is the key to the Australian people regaining self-respect. It is the only way of ensuring that families have any sense of security for the future. We believe Fightback will create jobs by cutting $20 billion from taxes on business and reforming the labour market. The only real way that employment in Australia can be increased is to let the private sector feel that it has a future, that investment in Australia is worth while and that in the long term we can be a society that is better off and can look to the future with some confidence. I move:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its failed economic policies which have caused massive social concern and record unemployment and calls on it to adopt the policies laid out in the Oppositions's Fightback plan which will rebuild Australia and enable Australian families to get back on their feet".
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

—I speak in support of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill, the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. I have to say that I am somewhat bemused about how the Fightback package, which imposes a 15 per cent GST on the food and clothing of all families, would create inflation of between 4 per cent and 8 per cent and how $6 billion in cuts to government expenditure would somehow magically create a better atmosphere in which we can raise our families.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps those opposite can also explain how sole parents who have children over the age of 12 years will feed those children, since the sole parent benefit will be taken from them. I am at somewhat of a loss to know how those measures in Fightback will address the issues which appear in this package of social security legislation. It deals with a range of programs and offers families specific payments, and acknowledges the family and payments to the family as part of our system.

We did hear from the shadow Minister for social security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), about the dependent spouse rebate. That was yet again a further indication of how out of touch many of the people on the other side of the House are. It may be of interest were he to note that those families in Australia who have a male breadwinner, a female spouse at home and children, represent 19 per cent of all Australian households. The Arnott's biscuit advertisement with the picket fence and the male breadwinner does not even represent 20 per cent of Australian households.

Perhaps we should also ask why this great burgeoning of the dependent spouse rebate, which will help a mere 19 per cent of Australian households, is touted as some great and momentous occasion. When we look at the changes to the integrated family payment system which will occur from 1 January 1993, we will see that we are targeting all sorts of families which make up Australian households. We have recognised that these families exist. Such payments are an acknowledgment of the demands and the needs which children in our families have.

Of course, the rationalising of the family allowance and the family allowance supplement means that payments will be made weekly to families to enable them to make the kinds of commitments and the kinds of payments which they would like to make. The legislation also covers the rent assistance package and assistance for guardians. It will ensure that people understand the sorts of payments that are being made to them.

To date very many people in our community do not understand that they are in receipt of two payments for children, or that these payments are available to working families. This legislation creates a single visible family payment. It is that recognition of a commitment to families which for so long has been the hallmark of this Government. Our contribution is not just to families, but also to veterans and other recipients who are overseas.

Clause 81 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill amends section 1208 of the Social Security Act to provide that an agreement on social security between Australia and the Republic of Austria is a scheduled international social security agreement for the purposes of the Act. Because the agreement on social security between Australia and Austria had not been signed at the time the amending Bill was being drafted, it was not possible to insert the text of the agreement as a schedule to the Act.

The agreement on social security between Australia and Austria has since been signed and is expected to come into force on 1 October 1992. That agreement can now be incorporated into the Act by way of a schedule, which was the method by which such agreements were included in the Social Security Act 1991. Consequently, the Government proposes to move an amendment in the Senate to omit clause 81 of the amending Bill and insert the text of the agreement on social security between Australia and the Republic of Austria as a schedule to the Act. This will also accommodate the concerns of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It can be seen that our commitment to social security extends across the whole international sector.

Another part of these Bills addresses the veterans community. One of the changes which directly affects both the veterans community and the age pensioner community relates to telephone allowances. It might be worth reminding honourable members of our commitment to veterans. There are three rates for telephone allowance: the World War I rate, which is equal to the annual telephone rental charge—we believe our World War I veterans and mariners are entitled to that; the $51.80 per year rate for all eligible disability pensioners, war widows and single service pensioners; and the $29.50 per year rate for all eligible service pensioners who have a partner who is also eligible. We acknowledge the needs of our veterans community, but we also recognise that those needs vary.

The other interesting and important aspect of this change in the Veterans' Affairs Bill enables a pensioner who pays for access to a PABX telephone line in a nursing home to now be eligible for a telephone allowance. As honourable members would appreciate we have many veterans who are quite aged and in need of some special treatment and who live in nursing homes. Those people will now be able to participate in, and take advantage of, the telephone allowances scheme. That is surely a very important aspect of our commitment to our veterans' community.

The other group of veterans who were addressed under this legislation are those who are part of the peacekeeping force in Cambodia. All of us would recognise that the role of Australia's Defence Force in keeping the peace would seem to be a much more important role than in securing war. We take great pride in the commitment of those veterans. We recognise that service and so grant them their entitlements under the Act.

Ultimately these Bills acknowledge the role that is central to the Social Security Act, that of putting families, children and the care of children in a central focus. Indeed, I despair of the Opposition spokesperson, who said that Fightback was about helping people to help themselves. We know that and we know what it was like to try to help ourselves for all the years we worked and lived under a Liberal Party regime. We know that the reason that the Opposition intends to make payments to the Salvation Army and various other groups is that people are very often not able to help themselves and so have to rely and depend on those wonderful community organisations.

What the Social Security Act does, and what this Government does, is make a commitment to provide income support to people within our community who are in special need or deserving of the taxpayer dollar. It is in that context that we make our commitment to Australian families, youth, veterans and aged pensioners. It is with those people in mind that we make these amendments. We do not and will not charge them an extra 15 per cent for every sliver of food that goes into their mouths or piece of clothing that goes on their backs. That would grind them down. How it would help them to help themselves I have not worked out, but I am sure that various honourable members on the other side of the House will explain that 15 somehow equals four, in the words of Andrew Denton, or that a 15 per cent GST is definitely helping people to help themselves. On this side of the House, we are not so silly. We make a commitment to humanity, egalitarianism and a society in which everybody has a place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to take part in this debate. Initially, I would like to make a few comments on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. As has already been indicated, the Opposition supports this legislation, as most of it is of minor significance. The amendment to the Veterans' Entitlements Act to extend benefits to Australian Defence Force personnel serving in Cambodia recognises Cambodia as an operational area for the purposes of veterans' benefits. Clearly, Australians serving in Cambodia are at risk and we most certainly agree that they are entitled to commensurate benefits.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has consistently expressed concern for the safety of our troops in Cambodia. Unfortunately, until recently Parliament was not kept well informed about the full role of our troops there. Parliament must be kept informed—it is the Government's responsibility to ensure that it is kept informed—about the role of all our troops overseas if bipartisan support for our involvement in these vital peacekeeping operations is to be maintained.It is indeed a matter of some pride that an Australian, General Sanderson, is the military commander of the United Nations forces in Cambodia. I know that Australian soldiers there will acquit themselves well, as they have always done.

I turn now to the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill is ostensibly about helping families. To the extent that it does, we support it. We welcome, in particular, the Government's new approach to intra-family income distribution, particularly in respect of low income families. We support the Government's approach to concentrating benefits towards the primary care giver in low income families—and that, of course, is usually the mother.

The plight of families in Australia today as a result of this dreadful recession that we are experiencing is indeed serious. Many families are in dire straits. The legislation that we are dealing with here tonight does nothing substantial about this situation. This Government's policies, despite what we hear from it day after day, have actually destroyed many families. This Government's policies have created a situation where unfortunately it is almost necessary for both parents to work. For many families it is a matter of survival for both parents to have to go out to work. The social costs, particularly where young children are involved, will be enormous.

The Government's only solution to this, of course, is to rapidly expand the availability of child-care. Desirable as that may be, it is, in my view, second-best. The best child-care, particularly for young children, is parent care. But this Government's policies have put that beyond the reach of many families and the children of these parents are suffering and they will suffer in the future as a result of this second-best option for taking care of children in their tender years.

The Government has also created a situation where family allowances—however termed; whatever the semantics—are regarded these days generally as welfare and recipients of that assistance are treated as if they were recipients of welfare. This completely overlooks the original intention of family support and the real reason for it, which was, of course, to take cognisance of the special place of the family with children in our society. Yet this Government's policies have threatened those sorts of families. They have not encouraged people to have children and have made it difficult for people with children to survive as a family. I think that a legacy of this Government in that respect will be one that we will have to live with well into the next century as children grow up not having been properly cared for in their early years.

It is interesting, if we go into the figures, to note how significantly the value of family allowance has in fact declined under this Government over the past eight or nine years. Despite what we have heard from the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) here this afternoon, the Opposition has a real and measurable commitment to family. Of course, that is outlined in detail in the Fightback package. If the honourable member for Forde cannot understand or chooses not to try to understand the effect of the GST—she talked in glib terms about how 4 per cent could be 15 per cent—I am happy to spend time with her explaining in detail the effect—

TALK.START.PARA: —She is a slow learner.
—She is a slow learner.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: we will have to ask the honourable member to withdraw. I think that if the honourable member for Forde were here she would be very offended by that remark.
—I do not think she would be offended at all by being called a slow learner.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask the honourable member to withdraw.

—If the honourable member for Cowan thinks the honourable member would be offended, I withdraw the inference. But I make the point that if the honourable member for Forde has trouble understanding the implications of the goods and services tax for families and why the average consumer price index effect would be less than 5 per cent, I would be happy to spend time with her explaining it in detail to her.

PARA.TAB: In the few minutes remaining to me I just talk about the Opposition's commitment to family, that real commitment that is outlined in the Fightback package. I am proud to stand here as a member of a coalition government which is able to demonstrate to the people of Australia that we care about families. We care about traditional families. We want children to grow up being properly taken care of, ideally by one of their parents in their early years.

We have demonstrated that commitment in Fightback by proposing to double the family allowance where family income is less than $30,000 a year. That, of course, is a significant increase in family allowance and will more than take account of the effect of inflation over the last 10 years. For families earning between $30,000 and $40,000 a year, we will increase family allowance by 50 per cent. The dependent spouse rebate will increase from $1,379 to $1,679 a year for eligible families with children. Eligible families with incomes of less than $30,000 will receive tax credits of up to $400 to assist them with the cost of private health insurance.

Given more time, I would like to have gone on to deal in great detail with the other parts of the Fightback package which benefit families. I challenge members of the Government to refute in any cogent or meaningful way the fact that the Fightback package is demonstrably, clearly and overwhelmingly pro-family. I do not have any hesitation in saying that. I am particularly pleased to be a member of a Party which is pro-family and will attempt to repair the damage that this Government has done to families over the past nine years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a long time since I have heard such a patronising contribution to debate in this House. But I thank the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) for it nonetheless, because it shows quite starkly the difference between the Opposition and the Government on matters relating to families, women, working, child-care and taxes on food and clothing. I think it is extremely important that the House has had the benefit of the contribution by the honourable member for McPherson. Apart from his remarks about the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), his remarks on child-care were extremely interesting.

PARA.TAB: In my electorate—and I am sure my electorate is not that much unlike the honourable member's electorate—it is the people who cannot get child-care and who are at home looking after their children who complain about it. I am absolutely amazed that somebody in this House would go back to the stage of expecting women to be barefoot and pregnant and be asking women to stay at home to look after children just because he thinks that is the right thing for them to do. It is absolute foolhardiness to be telling women in the 1990s to stay at home and look after their children. If they wish to do that, they will do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe in choice; fair choice for women.
—We provide women with a choice. I stayed home and looked after my children—which I will bet is more than any other honourable members who are in the chamber at the moment could say.

PARA.TAB: Child-care, the family allowance supplement, and social security payments to families are important matters in the Australian community. I defy the honourable member for McPherson to go out into his electorate and tell all of those people who are receiving the family allowance supplement—which will now be a combined family payment, thanks to the endeavours of the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett)—that they are not entitled to that payment any longer; nor are they entitled to child-care any longer; or, if they are entitled to child-care, that they will now be paying a 15 per cent sales tax or GST on it, thank you very much.

I also think it is important that we understand that people in Australia who are receiving a family allowance supplement get that payment only if one or other of the members of the family is already in the work force. This is not welfare: it is a supplementation of the family's wage earning ability precisely so that one member of the family can remain at home to look after the children if that is the family's choice.

I have never heard such an ignorant patronising contribution to a debate in this House on something as serious, important and as crucial to families in Australia as family payments and social security are. I cannot believe—even though I know the honourable member for McPherson quite well—that he actually had the temerity to stand up in here and say those things.

The last time I remember anybody in this House talking about women being barefoot and pregnant—he did not actually say that, but he implied it—was when the previous honourable member for Maranoa spoke about it. He in fact made elegant and eloquent contributions to the House on many occasions, but on that particular occasion he was wrong. In fact, he created a furore with what he said.

TALK.START.PARA: —And lost pre-selection.

—Yes, he lost pre-selection—mind you, I think he probably wanted to at the time. That is okay; I would have wanted to as well if I had been a member of the Queensland National Party at that point in time.

PARA.TAB: I think this Government is doing exactly the right thing by combining the family payment so that it is a simpler and more effective system for people who need to have some support for their incomes—whether their incomes derive from working, or whether they are unfortunate enough, for one reason or another, to have to rely on the social security system for support. I have said before that when I was not a member of this House I implored one of the Liberal Ministers of the time to create a payment like the family allowance supplement. That, of course, did not occur. Our Government was the only government which had the nous to realise that if people were going to be better off on welfare than they would be in the work force, it was required of the Government to provide some supplementary benefit or payment which would attract them into the work force to earn a relatively low wage. I applaud the Government for its initiatives in this area and am very pleased that the Minister for Social Security, who is at the table, is bringing in this Bill at this time.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Connolly's amendment) stand part of the question.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: I take the opportunity also to say to the House that events in that region are very volatile indeed, whether in Burma, Thailand or Cambodia. We wish our forces well in Cambodia. TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Overseas Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to add to an answer to a question that I gave in Question Time today.
—The Minister may proceed.

—The answer to the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) is as follows: I am not aware of the facts relating to the allegations the honourable member for Kooyong made about the date of payment of $25,000 by Gregory Symons to his trustee. Further, I am totally unaware of Mr Symons's private financial affairs and I cannot speculate on what reasons there may or may not have been for his alleged financial transactions. However, I can inform the honourable member for Kooyong that the EMDG grant he refers to was paid to Mr Symons on 2 December 1991. This is some six weeks after the date when the honourable member alleges Mr Symons paid his trustee the amount referred to. Therefore, the EMDG grant was not directly used to discharge his bankruptcy.

PARA.TAB: In any case, these allegations and questions regarding Mr Symons's private affairs are irrelevant to the substantive part of the honourable member's question which related to the payment of EMGD entitlements to individuals who are involved in proceedings under the Bankruptcy Act. EMDG payments are an entitlement following eligible expenditure under the Act, just as a tax rebate or child endowment is an entitlement. EMDG grants are made available in the financial year after the eligible expenditure is carried out. The financial situation of any EMDG claimant may wax or wane after the eligible expenditure has been made. Anyone who has been in business knows this.

Regardless of any change in economic circumstances, an EMDG entitlement is still valid and must be paid under the Act. In the case of bankruptcy, liquidation or receivership, any EMDG entitlement constitutes an asset of the eligible EMDG claimant and may be directed to any purpose the claimant sees fit. As I pointed out to the honourable member for Kooyong in my letter of 26 May, yesterday, the EMDG Act was reviewed in 1989, and in 1990 the EMDG Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 was supported in both Houses by the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Deputy Leader of the National Party, I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1992 concurrently with the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1992. TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point again, as was made earlier today with the wool legislation, that this is very important legislation for one of the major agricultural industries of Australia and we have a guillotine in place that will provide less than an hour for debate. This is important legislation because it will carry the manufacturing sector of the dairy industry in particular through to the turn of the century and beyond—that is 70 per cent of the industry in Australia with over $700m of exports. It is the most significant regional industry in Australia, employing about 100,000 people directly and indirectly.

PARA.TAB: My electorate happens to be the most significant dairy production area of Australia particularly for the manufacturing sector and for exports. The Shepparton Kyabram Rodney Development Corporation prepared a report in relation to the Industry Commission recommendations indicating the significance of the industry to this part of Australia. It said that if the Industry Commission recommendations had been accepted in toto—which presumably means the State and city milk sector as well—it would have had an impact of $160m a year on the industry in that area. So that indicates the significance of the industry and the importance of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will refer to that in a couple of minutes. The dairy industry has also been very adept in changing its market strategy for exports from the old, traditional markets of Europe to Asia and the Middle East, and particularly Asia, where the majority of our dairy products are now exported. It is also the most significant agricultural industry with regard to value adding or further processing. I do declare an interest as I have a dairy farm and supply a cooperative factory.

PARA.TAB: This legislation replaces what has become known as the Kerin plan. It has been a basically successful five-year program which has given stability to an industry through the all milk levy and other components. At the same time there has been very rapid rationalisation and increase in productivity in that industry. People tend to forget that the Kerin plan bears very little relationship to Minister Kerin. The original proposal he brought to the Parliament was held up for 12 months and considerably amended by a combination of my predecessor, Ralph Hunt, the then honourable member for Gwydir, the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation and the Dairy Industry Council. I remind people that the five-year program owes its success very much to the Opposition as well as to the Government. The dairy industry has made it very clear that it does not want any delays to the legislation, and the coalition agrees with that.

If honourable members look at my electorate where there has been continuing significant investment, and I have eight major dairy factories in the electorate, they will see that it only needs the right signals in the market—domestically and internationally, with some stability and commercial relationships with exports—to realise that there is far more investment ready to take place in this industry.

As is the normal practice, whether it is a Labor or a coalition government in office, there was an Industry Commission inquiry into the industry. One of the major aspects of the Industry Commission's recommendations related to city milk. Of course, that is regulated by the States. The States said that they were not going along with that particular part of it. So that has been put to one side, as I think everybody anticipated.

In relation to the manufacturing sector, the Government has basically followed the recommendations or direction of the Industry Commission, with two exceptions. The Industry Commission recommended a phase-down starting with 20 per cent support through the all milk levy for the coming season and going down to 5 per cent by July 1986. The Government, through the legislation, has recommended a 12-month delay or holding at the present 22 per cent level, down to 10 per cent by the year 2000. As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has said, this is the equivalent of about a 5 per cent support arrangement because of the mix between the domestic market and export market.

I acknowledge that underwriting and the all milk levy, to a certain extent, serve the same purpose. That is, they can have a similar impact in the sense of providing stability in the export market. I suppose it could be said—that may be the reason the Government made that the decision; it is for the Minister to say—that to a certain extent they cancelled each other out and that the slower phase-down was the reason the Government did not proceed with underwriting. But it is for the Minister to say why that was the case.

The Government's decision is basically in line with general coalition policy, that is, that all industries should be down by the year 2000 to a negligible or 5 per cent level of tariff or its equivalent. I remind people that the Government, in this case, has actually treated the dairy industry harder than it has some other industries, for example, the textile, clothing and footwear industries and the motor vehicle industry. By the year 2000 they will be down to tariff levels of 25 per cent and 15 per cent in each case. The fact that the Government is not treating those industries in the same way as it is treating the dairy industry and many other industries adds to dairy farmers' costs. The dairy farmers of Australia are well aware of that. They know very well—I am not sure that many other people in Australia know very well—that there are absolutely no tariffs on imported dairy products, and there have not been for some time.

Even if there were tariffs on dairy products imported into Australia from other countries, the fact is that under closer economic relations with New Zealand there are no tariff restrictions on product from New Zealand; there are no dumping or countervailing procedures on product from New Zealand. New Zealand has, in overall terms, the most efficient manufacturing dairy industry in the world. I say that coming from the Goulburn Valley, which many would claim is the equivalent. But I believe that New Zealand has some advantages, particularly now that the New Zealand Government has undertaken some very significant industrial relations reform so that there is greater efficiency in its factories; greater efficiency in its transport; and particularly greater efficiency on its waterfront. It is said that the average New Zealand dairy farmer is $3,500 a year better off than he was before these reforms, purely because of the genuine reforms that have taken place on the waterfront. The Australian dairy farmer has not had that equivalent advantage.New Zealand dairy farmers also have the advantage of a goods and services tax, which reduces their cost of production and assists them with exports.

The point I am making is that the presence of New Zealand limits the ability of the industry, irrespective of any other arrangements, to increase the price of dairy products sold on the domestic market in Australia, that is, butter, cheese and so forth. There are absolutely no impediments to those products coming in from New Zealand. I know that some people would add other arguments that there are benefits for New Zealand because of its pooling arrangements and the special access it has to the European Community, still at quite a high price.

That said, I commend the dairy industry leadership in this country. I commend Pat Rowley, John Watson, Michael Taylor, John McQueen and others for the very positive and sensible way that they have negotiated this with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I commend the Minister because I believe that it is a successful negotiation and he has been prepared to listen and to learn. I make that point with regard to my area because I know that he came into it at the invitation of the industry. I think he visited the factory that I supply and it was one of a number. I make the point that I believe we have a good example of an industry leadership that has worked its way through government in a sensible and pragmatic way.

The major feature of this legislation is the all milk levy. It provides the stability with regard to export assistance or incentives, which maintains the stability on both the domestic market and the export market. That is paid for by every dairy farmer in Australia. It is not paid for by government under any budgetary arrangement. The maximum is 45c a kilogram fat and the maximum level of theoretical assistance was 30 per cent, but it is at 22 per cent at the present time and I have indicated that it is coming down over those next five years.

The dairy industry has suffered more than any other agricultural industry in Australia from unfair trade practices internationally. The European Community got to a surplus position with the dairy industry over 10 years ago. It was well ahead of the grain industry, the sugar industry, the beef industry or any horticultural industry. In fact, there have been countervailing actions against those European export subsidies for quite a few years. At the same time as we have given this unlimited access to European cheese, provided it is on a fair trade basis, the EC has restricted our access, to a far larger market in Europe, to 3,000 tonnes a year with a 24 per cent common external tariff.

In 1986 the countervailing action that is still in place was undertaken against not just the European Community but other European countries as well, and it was not the first action that had been taken. At that time, through its subsidised exports, it had gained about 20 per cent or more of the domestic cheese market, and the Government reached agreement with it after the EC had been proven to be dumping—perhaps that is not technically the right term where there is an export subsidy; it shouldould be `export subsidisation'—and settled for a tariff quota. That was a pretty soft decision in favour of the European Community. For 11,500 tonnes it was required to pay a tariff of $96 a tonne. For anything above that, it was $2,100 a tonne, which more correctly recognised the very extensive level of export subsidy that is provided. If one multiplies the difference between $96 and $2,100 by 11,500 tonnes, it means that the Europeans have been gaining, if you like, $23m better access in the sense of what they have not had to pay one way or another. We, through Customs collections, have lost. So they have got out of that pretty well.

I am pleased that the Government has accepted the advice of the Senate Committee and, after pressure from us, has now changed its previously absurd three-year sunset arrangement when there is any dumping or countervailing action to a five-year arrangement, which allows for the case to be looked at again to see that, if subsidisation is continuing, the countervailing duty also continues. The industry does have a dilemma: does it go back to trying countervailing again or does it stick with the current arrangement? That is a difficult decision for the industry.

I make the point too about the pressure being on the dairy industry longer than on other processed agricultural industries in Australia. It was probably the first to be put under pressure by the supermarkets for generic or home brands. That has been coupled also with pressures on imports by some of the supermarket chains. It is one of the problems that the industry faces at the moment, in spite of improvements to the fair trade procedures. In a coalition government, as we have indicated publicly, we would have far tougher criteria on this question of material injury, which would allow a shorter time span before an application was made and then halve the time after that application was made for both tentative and final duties.

There still is a problem, and I think it is something that we in the Opposition and the Government have to face up to. It is not just unique to the dairy industry and the case it has with Dutch Edam, which definitely is being export subsidised and sold at far less than a normal selling price here in Australia at the moment. The pig industry and other industries face it. Even when one has a wider ability for an industry to make an application—that is, one that is affected, such as the farmer with dairy or the pig producer with pork—unless the processing sector is prepared to provide the necessary information on costs and, therefore, work through to a selling price, et cetera, or unless the supermarkets, if they are the straight importers, are prepared to provide that information, there still is a difficulty in really making the application and reaching a just decision.
Both sides of this House still have to face up to that, and I hope they do.

Food standards is another area in which the dairying industry was probably subjected to some of these problems earlier than others. The States have been very lax in their determination of these standards. Preservatives which have been banned in Australia because they are supposedly cancer forming have been allowed in imported cheeses. We are never told publicly about the degree of listeria that is uncovered in tests on imported cheese. I am pleased that we now have a National Food Authority and are making progress. I acknowledge that it is up to the States, as the component parts of the National Food Authority, to push a damn sight harder than they are at the present time.

Another factor in relation to this legislation is underwriting. The Industry Commission recommended that underwriting be continued. It was the Industry Commission that invented this in the first place, quite a few years ago. The underwriting for dairying is very market-related. There is an eight-year trend line and then 85 per cent of that, and then the IC also recommended a $22m ceiling. I personally support that because I believe that underwriting, when it is in a market related form and whether it is for dairying or for wheat or whatever, is a sensible thing to have in place to provide stability when something happens unfairly in the international market.

It is recognised that a black hole could occur, and therefore government—whichever it is—should be required to act. But usually that is not as immediate or as automatic as if we have something in place. The industry has recognised that, although it would like underwriting to continue, it is not possible to successfully amend the legislation. We could move an amendment, and if it went through the Senate it would mean that the termination date was not proceeded with. But that does not require the Government actually to implement underwriting. The industry, as I said, was aware of it.

The industry has made it very plain that it is not prepared to accept the stage management of moving amendments by certain political parties in the Senate to pretend that they are doing something to assist the industry when in reality they cannot, and that it wants the legislation through.

Underwriting has been triggered only once in the last five or six years—at the $22m mark in 1991. That was the year in which the Europeans increased their export subsidies, and the bad year for grain. That would have provided a maximum of $4,000 for Victorian and Tasmanian dairy farmers, who are the major beneficiaries of underwriting because they have the greatest export exposure. Let us compare that with the coalition's Fightback policy on reducing costs to farmers by the removal of fuel excise, payroll tax and sales tax. Every year farmers will have their costs reduced by $8,000, and it will not matter whether they are Victorian dairy farmers or Queensland dairy farmers. That is the positive that puts us far ahead of Labor when it comes to total policy.

We are also committed to implementing a far better income equalisation deposit scheme. I hope the Government itself is doing that because, although there is stability in relative terms in the dairy industry compared with some others, there still should be better incentives to encourage farmers to take out their own self-insurance.

The Minister has obtained the approval of the industry for an increased promotion levy. I know that the industry wants to tread very cautiously with that because there is still very restricted access to Asia for branded and value added products. There are bans on UHT milk in some countries. Companies cannot do their packaging in Australia with their own brand and gain access to some of those markets. There are also higher tariffs. I hope that the Government and the Minister will be sensible with regard to putting pressure on the industry with increased promotion levies, and will work very hard bilaterally as well as through the GATT to overcome some of the restrictions on access to those markets.

The Minister has acknowledged that he is prepared to do some work with regard to getting some uniform State cooperative legislation. I fully support him in that because I have also been having discussions with some of my State colleagues. Cooperatives are essential, I believe, in both the horticultural and dairy industries to provide some leverage and reasonable power for producers. The State restrictions we have at the present time do not allow cooperatives to become national in a sensible way. We all know some of the examples of State legislation having prevented sensible amalgamations of cooperatives from taking place.

The coalition parties support the legislation because it provides further rationalisation of the industry in the sense of moving to a more internationally competitive position in relation to what it is producing. But we recognise that if anything like a level playing field develops internationally over the next few years—whether it is for a commercial price for dairy products as distinct from the corrupt price at the present time, or for access on a fair basis to those markets—the dairying industry in this country has a very great future as an expanded industry and one which will play its part in further exports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), really gave a fine example of flexibility in his speech. The Leader of the Opposition and Leader of the Liberal Party (Dr Hewson) has continually expounded the view of eliminating tariffs, yet in his speech the Deputy Leader of the National Party was able to say that our policy and this legislation fitted in with those views. Of course, it does not. This legislation does not contain the idea of elimination of tariffs or assistance, or any of those other measures that would be there if the National Party were in power.

PARA.TAB: The Dairy Produce Amendment Bill and the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill are focused on the means by which the dairy industry is best able to progress in coming years. They provide a framework for the industry to become more productive, to become more competitive on an international basis and, indeed, to become more aware of and focused on opportunities for the industry to export.

There is little doubt that the dairy industry has made significant progress in recent years, particularly since the introduction of the Kerin plan in 1986. The aim of that plan was to reduce the level of assistance and to encourage the industry to become more efficient and more competitive. The great majority of people connected with the dairy industry would support the view that the Kerin plan has been greatly successful. National production has increased at the same time as productivity has increased. There has been a moving of the focus of the industry away from bulk commodities into the marketing of more value added products. This gives the industry greater protection from the peaks and troughs of world prices and enhances greater price stability for the products of the dairy industry.

Although great progress has been made, to say that the status quo should remain is really to say that further progress cannot be made. Further progress towards greater efficiency, productivity and competitiveness can be made. The Government's continuing objective is to develop a more efficient and profitable dairy industry, an industry which is able to respond quickly to changing market conditions and to changes in technology. Only by way of this type of strategy can Australia hope to have a dairy industry that is as large as possible, whilst at the same time viable at an acceptable rate of industry assistance.

We need to aim our development at both the domestic market and the export market. The local market needs a system that maintains the dominance of the Australian dairy industry through improved competitiveness. In the export market there needs to be a direction that expands our exploitation of the profitable export markets. On the same basis, it means that there must be an ability to identify those export markets which are not profitable in the net sense and turn away from those.

These Bills give the dairy industry the direction and the certainty—and they do so with clarity—by which it can attain that progress that will maintain its position as a very important and integral part of Australian industry generally through the 1990s. One of the very important aspects of this legislation is that it has been arrived at through negotiation and cooperation with the dairy industry. That process has been noted by the hard work put in by the industry leaders, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and other members of the Government.

In the Minister's second reading speech, he compliments the Chairman of the ADIC, Pat Rowley, for the work he has put in. On 7 May in Queensland Country Life, Pat Rowley said that Mr Crean deserves recognition for his support for an industry which is extremely efficient by world standards, provides consumers with low cost products and is Australia's biggest exporter of processed foods to Asia.

I also know that the Caucus primary industries committee met on many occasions with dairy industry representatives from many parts of Australia. I myself met on a number of occasions with dairy industry representatives from the north coast of New South Wales and brought their interests and views to the Minister. The Minister also met with those north coast representatives of the dairy industry at both Casino and Grafton. The ability to negotiate, to give reasonable weight to the just arguments of the industry, was only possible because the Government was not tied to the Industry Commission report.

The industry itself was not able to live with the Industry Commission report. In fact, the Industry Commission report scared the hell out of the industry people whom I spoke to on the north coast of New South Wales. The Government says, as it now says with the Industry Commission report on sugar, that this is not a report which the Government sees as a benchmark or a way of going. The Government said that the Industry Commission report is a document which, while it needs to be considered, should only be considered with reference to and consideration for the way the industry sees itself progressing.

The Government did not lock itself inextricably into the Industry Commission report. That the negotiations were successful does credit to the response the industry made to it. The result of those responses is this legislation, which few in the dairy industry have a problem with. Certainly, it has been welcomed by the dairy industry. On the north coast of New South Wales, that welcome is no different from that received from the industry generally.

On 8 May in the Northern Farmer, the deputy chairman of the far north coast dairy industry welcomed the announcement made by the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy after fears he had that the industry support could be scrapped in line with the Industry Commission report. He said that the plan provided the breathing space, but that it was up to the industry to make use of the next seven years to tune its own marketing skills.He said:
It is a new era for the dairy industry and now we have been given the perimeters, it is up to producers to get on with building an industry that can go further into the future.

SPEECH.PARA: He did express some concerns about underwriting. The Government's position on that is that the Commonwealth has contributed to the underwriting of export returns of traditional dairy products when the annual average export price for the product is less than 85 per cent of the trend price for the product.

PARA.TAB: Underwriting is a conservative mechanism. It has only been used once in the six years of the Kerin plan. Underwriting provides little protection from world price changes as exporters continue to face substantial price movements. Benefits from the new package far exceed those that were given under underwriting. The policy direction of the package is to maintain and promote the health and development of the dairy industry rather than to insulate a few inefficient parties from extreme conditions. Discontinuing underwriting is consistent with Government policy for rural industries exposed to export price variations to take responsibility for their own risk management.

The details of the measures in these Bills have a bearing on both assistance and market development. There will be no reduction in market support for another 12 months. There will then be a lowering of market support in equal instalments up to the turn of the century. The market support in that time will be reduced from 22 per cent of parity to 10 per cent of export parity. That is a long way from the figure which was set by the Industry Commission and which is expounded by the Leader of the Liberal Party towards eliminating tariffs, to which the Liberal Party and the National Party have nailed their future.

I am sure that the dairy industry has taken note of the Industry Commission report recommending that the cheese tariff quota not be renewed when it ceases on 30 June 1992. The Industry Commission report also recommended that assistance be reduced from its current rate of about 22 per cent above average export price to 5 per cent in 1996. These Industry Commission recommendations are a good distance from the legislation and are much more in line with how the industry sees itself making progress. Of course, those are the things that would have been in place had the National Party and the Liberal Party had their way, tied as they are to the Industry Commission report and to zero tariffs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member is talking absolute rubbish. As far as the tariff quota and dumping are concerned, our position is far harder and better than the Labor Government's position. The honourable member should stick to the facts.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —On top of that, the dairy industry would have to cop further competition from the products that have a confectionery base and at present are subject to a sales tax. That wholesale sales tax on the major competitors of the dairy industry would be dropped by the conservative parties and a 15 per cent GST would be slapped on all the products that the dairy industry produces.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is total fabrication. There is already a sales tax on flavoured milk. The honourable member is misrepresenting the facts.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—All those dairy industry products are used throughout the nation on a daily basis. The products are a staple and a healthy part of the diet of all Australian families. That alone would result in a drastically reduced market share by the dairy industry. Coupled with the intention of the National Party to bring in the recommendations contained in the Industry Commission report, it is no wonder the dairy industry is scared that the National Party might ever be in power.
