SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quorum was called because the honourable member for Page (Dr Harry Woods) misrepresented the Opposition's position on tariff levels in the dairy industry. I will refer to that later in my speech.

PARA.TAB: The dairy industry faces a very positive future with strong leadership, aggressive marketing by those people involved, and a balance between the domestic demand for milk products and the export potential. After all the debate, the dairy industry in Australia has managed to limit its production to 6.5 billion litres. There have been dramatic changes over the last decade at both the farm and the processing levels.

It is interesting to note that when the Kerin plan was introduced in this House in 1986 a similar situation occurred then as is occurring now. The debate was run at the last minute and the guillotine was applied. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who is at the table, has allowed that to happen again, six years later. This important debate is being guillotined yet again. On the previous occasion the Minister kept putting off the arguments and brought up the legislation at a late stage of the parliamentary sittings. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) has a great interest in these matters and is unable to make a contribution to the debate. There are many dairy farmers in his electorate and they are interested in his views. The Minister at the table has ensured that very few speakers will have a go in this debate.

The Bonlac Cooperative, which is an important dairy manufacturing company based in my electorate of Corangamite and the electorate of Wannon, comprises a number of small cooperatives which have merged over the years. Between 1960 and 1980 the Camperdown, Cobden, Glenormiston and Colac cooperatives joined together to make a more efficient operation. Shepparton, Stanhope and Ibis combined in the northern part of Victoria with Amcal to make their operation more effective in that irrigation area.

In 1986 all those cooperatives combined under the one banner of Bonlac Cooperative. This meant that they had the productive efficiencies of western Victoria, the irrigation area and Gippsland. I note that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) is in the House. The advantages of these cooperatives—the weather, rainfall, irrigation, proximity to the fresh milk market, the pooling of management resources and the vigorous marketing approach of Bonlac overseas—have been to ensure that Bonlac is a force in the dairy industry in Australia.

The industry has changed dramatically over the last decade. It has been subjected to many political influences over the last 30 years—it has now moved away from that—and government subsidies. The fresh milk market pricing debate which had been going on around capital cities has been sorted out to a lesser or greater degree. There has been a remarkable change in the industry. In 1970 there were 43,000 farms; in 1980, there were about 20,000 farms; and in 1991 there were 15,000 farms working very efficiently. In 1970, production was about 7 billion litres and, in 1991-92, 6.5 billion litres. The industry was hoping to achieve a balance between domestic demand and overseas export possibilities. There are bigger operators in the industry, there is more productivity, there have been improvements in breeding and there have been dramatic improvements in the processing technology at the various cooperative plants.

Dairy products are worth about $1.7 billion. Victoria is a key part of the dairy debate, as the Minister at the table would be aware. It accounts for 60 per cent of the production and 12 per cent of that goes to the fresh milk market which is mainly in the metropolitan area of Melbourne. That has always been a threat to the Sydney fresh milk market. To a lesser degree there would be a threat to the Brisbane and Adelaide markets if the market arrangements broke down.

Victorian producers are world efficient—as the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), has indicated—because of the climatic conditions. One interesting feature is that members of the Victorian and Australian dairy industry do not house their cows for 4 1/2 months a year as their European competitors do. That is something which we tend to overlook in Australia.

The Europeans require these massive subsidies to compete at anywhere near the levels of the grass fed animals in Australia. Our new modern processing plants are also making the Australian dairy industry more competitive. Eighty-eight per cent of the product in Victoria is processed into butter, cheese and buttermilk for both the home market and the export market. The Australian industry has been very aggressive in exporting its product overseas and, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy said in his second reading speech, 67 per cent of the product is being exported to Asia, Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan and Singapore in an aggressive fashion.

The important feature for members of this House and the dairy industry to note is the problem of world pricing because of the massive influence of the subsidies of the European Common Market. There are 23 million head of dairy cattle in the European Common Market, a similar number to the total cattle population in Australia. The European subsidies create the world export price and Australian manufacturers are competing with this price. That is the basis of our problem.

Other speakers have alluded to the fact that it is important to note that the Australian dairy industry has no tariffs on any imports to Australia. Sometimes in the debate the fact that there is no import tariff quota is overlooked. The base price is created by the very efficient New Zealand industry, which is well organised and has some interesting comparative advantages in terms of rainfall, soil type and the productivity of its dairy herds.

The key argument relates to the market milk price for domestic consumption and the way in which it is set and the world price of manufactured products which is dominated by the EEC arrangements. The argument then revolves around the all-milk levy of 43c per butterfat kilogram paid to exporters who aggressively sell their product to these markets which have been corrupted by the EEC's operation in setting the world price. The Victorians gain most from this all-milk levy. The counterargument is that the all-milk levy ensures that the Victorians will not predatory price into the more lucrative fresh milk markets in New South Wales and, possibly, other capital cities.

In this debate six years ago, the Kerin plan tried to achieve an annual Australian production of 6.5 billion litres. That is a balance between the amount of milk for domestic demand and the amount of milk that can be exported at this stage at a reasonably profitable level. The 43c butterfat figure represents about a 22 per cent tariff support price which will be reduced to about 10 per cent by the year 2000. We have had a vigorous debate about this in the past few minutes. That is compatible with the coalition's negligible tariff levels by the year 2000. That is our policy, and the Minister agrees with it. The coalition has been quite up-front on its position about tariffs in other industries. The Minister made it very clear in his speech that the tariff arrangement is compatible with our position.

The industry requested some underwriting that would give it catastrophe cover. However, that underwriting was utilised only on one occasion in 1991 when $22m was required to ensure that the subsidies of the European Common Market which caused a dramatic fall in the world price were used up. We on this side of the House agree that there is no real need for underwriting because, hopefully, the industry will have its house in order, so to speak.

I have had a number of discussions with the dairy farmers in Victoria on the fresh milk pricing arrangements. There has always been a major debate about the mechanism for setting the fresh milk price and the contract system which has been removed in Victoria but remains in New South Wales. A statutory authority fixing the price of fresh milk is a problem that will be resolved over time by a more market orientated mechanism.

However, the fact that the Victorians became more efficient and had a chance to put pressure on the interstate milk market is demonstrated very well by Mr Davey from the New South Wales Dairy Corporation in his paper to the National Agricultural and Resources Outlook Conference 1991 entitled, `Responding to challenges in the fresh milk market'. I believe he summarises the whole argument with these words:

SPEECH.PARA: The Victorian challenge is inseparable from other challenges and pressures on the NSW dairy industry that began developing in the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: Most pressing are the demands from retailers and other interested parties for a more flexible system of supply and pricing. Supermarkets' early demands for house brands, 2-litre plastic containers, refrigerated deliveries, centralised billing and volume discounts have been met: they still desire direct access to processors and more flexibility in pricing, and thus support deregulation of zoning and pricing.

On a wider perspective, the federal and NSW State governments' thrust for microeconomic reform and deregulation has undoubtedly been part of the impetus for planning more flexible systems. This is clearly the greatest `policy change' that the industry, for so long regulated and protected, must face over the next few years.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that summarises the arguments that have been going on between the State and Federal Ministers on the balance between fresh milk pricing in Victoria and New South Wales, and the pressure on the threat to changes that were brought about in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the cheese quotas and tariffs, other honourable members have presented our position. We agree with the Government's view on the matter. I draw the attention of the House to the difficulties that the dairy industry has in raising a countervailing duty claim for processed cheese. I make the observation that the whole arrangement where we are competing with the highly subsidised cheese products of Europe and the difficulties of the industry in running these countervailing duties makes it very difficult to handle the products. I also agree with the shadow Minister that the labelling and health standards make it very difficult for the Australian industry.

The dairy industry faces a very good future, in my view. It has an aggressive marketing attitude in selling its product overseas. It has an attitude that it needs to look after the customer, unlike the wool industry where there is an attitude of mind that those people who buy the product are the villains in the piece. I do commend the dairy industry for its attitude.

The on-farm productivity has been raised dramatically. We now have a situation where there are 300-cow farms and where productivity at the farm level has, as I say, increased dramatically over the past 10 years. We have world standard processing plants that are up to date, that meet standards in hygiene and processing and that will compete with anyone in the world. We have less government involvement. By the year 2000 under this legislation we will have no government involvement at all, and the industry will be standing on its own two feet—hopefully, profitably, efficiently and viably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that some time has been left for some Government members to respond to some of the comments that have been made in the debate tonight. I am quite pleased to join in this debate on the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill and the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill. The dairy industry, I guess, goes to the very heart of my electorate on the far north coast. These changes that have come in have been welcomed by the industry. Following my election to the seat of Richmond, the dairy farmers there were one of the first groups to come and compliment me on the action and the results that the Kerin plan has brought to the industry—the steady nature of the industry and the way it functioned during the time the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, then the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), was overseeing it.

PARA.TAB: What the dairy farmers did also point out was the fact that the Kerin plan was going to run out very shortly and they were very concerned about the changes that might come in and destabilise that industry. There is no doubt that they were concerned when the Industry Commission report came out and they were most concerned about its recommendations. My colleague the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) and I managed to communicate quite a deal with the dairy farmers and the industry leaders on the north coast. I would like to say that we took the message very strongly to the Minister, and I am very pleased that the Minister was able to take on board very strongly the concerns of that area. After all, the north coast dairy industry does face different situations from those faced by the rest of the dairy industry, particularly the Victorian industry of which the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), is part.

I would like to say that the changes are not all the doings of the north coast industry, though in particular I must say that the changes that have occurred there have essentially been the result of the State governments as it is the State governments throughout Australia that control the marketing of the bulk milk section of that industry. The Victorian industry is essentially organised around the manufacturing side of it and has balanced its industry along those lines. The north coast industry at one stage was written off, much to the chagrin of the dairy industry on the north coast. The one-time Leader of the National Party simply told the industry back in the late 1960s or early 1970s to get big or get out. That was the kind of support that the dairy farmers got.

What saved the industry up on the north coast was the State Labor Government with Don Day as the member for Casino who actually got the north coast dairy industry into the Sydney bulk milk market. The industry was saved in those days by the State Labor Government and certainly the industry takes on board that in fact the group of people that has responded again to its interests has been a Labor government, in this case the Federal Labor Government and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who is at the table.

I would just like to read out a few comments from Alan Hoskins, the General Manager of Norco, a major employer in my electorate and the electorate of the honourable member for Page and a great survivor in terms of an employer in the industry. He is a very innovative marketer and certainly a leading light in terms of value adding industries in the dairy industry. Alan Hoskins's comments were printed in the latest Norco Bulletin, some of which I will pass on to the Minister and the House:

SPEECH.PARA: Industry leaders agree that Mr Crean deserves recognition for his support to an industry which is extremely efficient, which is of major economic importance to this nation. From the industry's standpoint, however, special recognition and thanks must also go to Mr Pat Rowley who has worked tirelessly to drive industry into developing proposals for the Minister.

Mr Rowley and other members of the dairy industry have been paid due recognition by other speakers tonight and I would like to pass on my compliments to the leaders of the dairy industry for the way they have responded to the IC report and the way that they have put their proposals. I am glad that the Government has been able to take these on board. Certainly the strategies involved here are different from what is involved in the IC report. I would like to pass on the comments of dairy farmers in my electorate, as did the honourable member for Page from his electorate, and their compliments for the way the Government has reacted to this. It has not brought in zero tariffs. It listened to what the industry was after. The industry certainly does retain some fear about the removal of the underwriting—that being taken out—but it is certainly prepared to live with that, as it has said. It is pleased that the retention of support is there. The comfort clause obviously has been removed but that is something that it is prepared to live with.

PARA.TAB: The Deputy Leader of the National Party also made the comment that the tariffs on cheeses are being removed. To save my getting telephone calls and so forth tomorrow or later tonight from concerned dairy farmers, the tariff at $96 a tonne or the equivalent is to be retained, which is about 2 1/2 per cent. He also mentioned that the cheese tariff quota on overquota cheese, of over the 11,500 tonnes, at $2,100 per tonne, is to be retained.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have the grand total time of two or three minutes to try to address this very important and complex Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Amendment Bill before the House. If any of the thousands of dairy farmers in my electorate of Gippsland ask me how much attention the Parliament paid to the most fundamental change to their industry in the last few years, I will tell them that the Government allowed 60 minutes. The Government has allowed 60 minutes for the most structural, fundamental changes to the dairy industry for several years. The Government's contempt for the dairy industry, as for most of the rural industries, is very obvious. Earlier today it allowed 50 minutes for debate on the wool tax.

PARA.TAB: Here we have an export industry of $700m per annum, encompassing some 15,000 dairy farmers. It is shameful that a mere 60 minutes have been allowed to publicise many aspects of the dairy industry that need airing and need the attention of the Parliament. The dairy industry gets precious few opportunities to dominate the agenda of the Parliament in the way that is presented by this legislation. It is a tragedy that that opportunity is being lost.

This legislation represents a tremendous change for the dairy industry, but the dairy industry is used to that; it is nothing new. The dairy industry more than any other industry that immediately springs to mind has been determined to restructure, to become more efficient and to be able to compete on world markets. It has had no choice, naturally, because, if it had not rationalised and restructured, quite frankly it would not be able to compete in the way it is required to do. So there has been a drastic change in the last 15 years or so to the dairy industry, and much of it very painful.

There ought to be a recognition by the national Parliament that the dairy industry is at the forefront of changes that will allow it, firstly, to adopt international best practices and, secondly, to compete on a world market. After all, it was the Industry Commission itself that made the point that the most significant source of price competition comes from New Zealand. New Zealand, as we know, is the most efficient manufacturer of dairy products in the world. As there are no tariff or anti-dumping restrictions between our countries, that means that our domestic dairy products are limited to the import parity of the New Zealand product.

If time had allowed it, the coalition would have tackled those other worries of the dairy industry, such as the fixed costs. Some 70 per cent of a dairy farmer's costs are beyond the farm gate over which he or she has no control. So it is no good just tackling the legislative framework within which the dairy industry must operate. There is also a need to lower the input costs, whether they be in transport and handling, on the waterfront or on the factory floor itself.

The coalition, which will abolish $20 billion of business taxes, will provide that low cost environment within which the production side of the dairy industry, beyond the farm gate, can cope with the competition, particularly from world markets. So the legislation before the House is supported by the coalition, as it is by the dairy industry. It is a hard-won victory for the dairy industry and is a testimony to its determination to press on legislators the need for this legislative framework. Nonetheless, there still remains the critical factor of what happens beyond the farm gate. Nothing in this legislation will tackle that. Indeed, nothing in the much touted One Nation package, or any other action by this Government, will do anything to increase the profitability of the dairy farm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill. I will deal with the health aspects of the Bill and some of my colleagues will address the other issues a little later, sadly not in depth because of the restraints put upon us by the guillotine.

PARA.TAB: A number of issues related to the health portfolio are addressed in this Bill. Many of them are fairly straightforward and have our support. For example, we certainly accept the payment of an increased fee for longer and more complex pathology services. It means that people in intensive care units, for example, will get much better care, something for which we have been pushing for some time.

The changes in the regulations about the ordering of radiology services and the investigation of this to reduce overservicing, fiddling and rorting have always been part of the principles that we would want to reduce the number of fiddlers in the system, the people who waste our money, the people who utilise taxpayers' money for no good purpose. We support these initiatives.

The financial penalty on pathologists who fail to advise referring doctors about the fact that their services do not attract Medicare benefits again is something that we have been pushing for and we are happy to accept the legislation as it is proposed. There are some technical amendments which acknowledge health funds now as registered health benefits organisations, which, of course, are fairly straightforward.

But we need more detailed discussion on some of the issues raised here, some of them fairly straightforward, some more complex. One of the straightforward ones, again a victory for the coalition, is the extension of the PBS safety net card to cover pharmaceuticals dispensed by States in their public hospital systems. Previously, individuals could face two safety nets and pay up to $255 before the safety net came in. As a result of this legislation, which is consequent upon pressure from the coalition, pensioners will now pay up to $135, obviously a more sensible figure. The integration of State and Federal safety nets is something which should have occurred months, if not years, ago.

Some changes refer to the Baume report recommendations. As I think the House is aware, we have generally supported the Baume recommendations. We have been a bit critical lately about the speed of implementation of the recommendations, but we are glad to see that the Government to some extent has listened to some of our criticisms. For example, the redrafting of the TGA regulations followed more or less our suggestions. These relatively minor amendments are quite worth while.

We support the availability of an AAT appeal if the evaluation is not done in time, but we are still concerned about the relatively poor state of the evaluation process and the times involved in this. For example, a number of drugs are still creaking very, very slowly through the evaluation system, in spite of the recommendations in the Baume report. I could list probably a dozen or so without any trouble at all, but let me focus on two particular issues and one general area.

I have raised in this House before the question of neupogen. On a previous occasion, I mentioned that this drug allows cancer treatment to be much more effective—indeed, it can be potentially life saving—and the fact that it had a very slow progress through the TGA bureaucracy. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) actually accused me of waving the shroud. Let me say that neupogen has now been approved—there are at present no funds for it, but at least it has been approved. Sadly, however, it was too late for the lady that I mentioned in the House, Janty Nicholson, who had breast cancer and needed the drug; she was unable to get it via the system and had to bypass it. Janty died about two weeks ago as a result, indirectly, of not being able to get access to neupogen. With great sadness I inform the House of Janty Nicholson's sad death and offer my condolences to her lovely family.

Another issue is the question of Intron A. Intron A is a drug which is the only available treatment for hepatitis C. It has been approved in some 17 other countries and in many countries has been available since 1988. The application to Australia's ADEC was made in December 1990, over 365 working days ago. That far exceeds Peter Baume's recommendation that the evaluation of this class of drugs should take 195 days; so it has taken over twice as long as recommended and still there is no completion in sight.

It is even worse because Intron A has been approved for a number of other conditions—hairy cell leukaemia, Kaposi's sarcoma, genital warts and basal cell carcinoma—so there is no question about the drug being safe; it is a perfectly safe drug, but the bureaucracy cannot plough through it quickly enough to approve its use for a condition where it is clearly indicated and for which there is no alternative treatment. Something like 100,000 patients in Australia are currently suffering from the condition, which may in many cases be a potentially fatal disease.

The cost of the drug is something like $2,500 or $2,800. That may seem expensive, but the cost of not treating the disease is much higher. The cost of a liver transplant, for example, is $70,000 or $80,000. One of the things we should insist upon is that Intron A be listed for consideration at the next ADEC meeting.

There are very strict criteria for genotrophin, a synthetic growth hormone. A young boy in my electorate called William Somadelis has had trouble with access. He is a short child, but he does not satisfy the strict criteria. Although all his doctors believe he is a genuine candidate for genotrophin growth hormone, he does not satisfy the wording of the criteria. His parents have found the resources to pay over $5,000 for a course of this drug. Fortunately at this stage he has had a good response to it. He is starting to grow and his height may become within the normal percentile, but it is very sad that the guidelines in this particular case are so restrictive that his parents, who are not well off at all, have to find thousands of dollars and indeed in this situation are having to face mortgaging their house to raise the money to make sure that their child reaches normal height. This should not happen under any health system, particularly under one vaunted by the Government as being good for the whole population.

Another issue in general terms is the question of therapeutic devices. The device manufacturers tell me very categorically that since the recent changes in the introduction of fees the processing time for their approvals has actually increased, it has actually deteriorated in many cases. On top of that they are now being faced with increased fees over the next couple of months. I understand, if my information is correct, and I understand it is—it comes from a very reliable source; it certainly does not come from the Government, which never takes the trouble to inform us of these proposed changes—that the Government is proposing in some categories a 200 per cent fee increase for the approval processes in different categories of therapeutic devices. So in effect they are paying 200 per cent more in some categories and an increase in most categories for a worse service. Our view and the view of the industry is that it is happy to pay increased fees if it gets a better service. Sadly in this situation they are not only getting a worse service, they are also having to pay more for it. That is entirely inappropriate.

With respect to the Australian Hearing Services Authority, we have no problems with protection of the acronym NAL, but we have some minor complaints about the removal of the necessity for borrowings to be tabled in Parliament. We believe that the right of Parliament is to scrutinise and examine such borrowings, even though it may be tedious and tiresome for the Hearing Services Authority to prepare the documents. We believe that the rights of Parliament in this case should be paramount. We would oppose these changes.

The main issue, however, is of course the question of the co-payments. I do not have to deliver the details of the saga about the co-payments to this House. Honourable members are fully aware of the humiliating somersault that has been forced upon the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. The Minister said early in August that Medicare was `unsustainable'—I use his own word—without these changes; that the co-payment was indeed the cornerstone of the Government's reform; yet he has had a humiliating backdown, a policy somersault, forced upon him by the new Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as part of the deal for his ascension to the Prime Ministership.

There are some great ironies here because the factional deals involved an assessment by many in the Labor Party that the public would so much abhor a fee for service and the absence of free medicine that there would be an electoral backlash. The AGB survey figures indicate that 70 per cent of the public actually supported a contribution, and 61 per cent specifically supported the $2.50 charge and thought it was reasonable. Thirty-four per cent thought it was unreasonable, but 69 per cent of pensioners thought it was reasonable. This is an indication of the common sense of the general public in Australia. The other problem to the Government is that this humiliating backdown, this policy somersault, which is one of the last nails in the coffin of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, will cost the taxpayer $707m by 1995. Just think what could be done with $707m.

In another interesting AGB survey report, 53 per cent of those surveyed and 73 per cent of pensioners reported that there was no increase in the fees charged by GPs after the appropriate time. Most people reported no increase or a very small increase. A significant number of people said that the charge was only a little less likely to make them go to a GP for a minor illness.

There are some other myths still being propagated which are not being addressed in this Bill. The Medicare levy provides for only about 18 or 19 per cent of the costs of health in Australia. There is an appalling lack of funds. There is a major crisis in the Australian health system. At the recent Australian Health Ministers Advisory Conference there was a revolt by both Labor and Liberal State Health Ministers in regard to that. The three conservative Ministers for Health refused to support the principles of the Medicare agreement. Keith Wilson, the Minister for Health in Western Australia, was critical then and was even more critical at a meeting in Melbourne today. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Seriously sick Australians are daily unable to gain access to needed hospital treatment.

The tragedy is that the people who are most affected are the aged and those on low incomes with chronic disease. What we are seeing is the growing failure of Hospital Medicare to protect the most vulnerable members of the community—the exact opposite of the original objectives of Medicare.

He pointed out that the number of people on Perth teaching hospital waiting lists since 1988 has grown by more than 40 per cent. Currently 11,500 people are waiting for treatment in those hospitals. He says:
The truth is that hospital Medicare is not the fair and just system that it promised to be, and has not been since its inception.

This is not some right wing propagandist; this is not a right wing think-tank or a Liberal or National Party member; this is the Labor Minister for Health in Western Australia, supported by his own Department and by his Premier. It is very interesting that the Minister for Health apparently tried to silence Keith Wilson and put pressure on his Premier to prevent him from attending today's conference and making those very comments.

PARA.TAB: What else is happening that is worrying? There is a campaign by the Private Hospitals Association against the current system. More interestingly, there is a campaign by the Public Hospitals Association and the AHA, the Australian Hospitals Association. It has about 650 members, about 620 of which are public hospitals. The Labor Party now says that we need to emphasise private health insurance, that we need to encourage people to look after themselves. This, of course, is the very thrust of Fightback in general and of our health policy in particular. We will remove the pressure from the public system and increase the occupancy rates of the private system to the benefit of both systems.

The recent AMA conference, not entirely attended by AMA members, supported the coalition's health policy very strongly. Something like 90 per cent of the attendees of that conference supported the principles of the coalition's health policy: that there should be a pricing on it; that there should be a review of the medical benefits system and that there should be incentives for private health insurance. There seems to be little doubt that the right way to go is the way in which we have pointed. There should be an indication that there is an incentive for taking out private health insurance to look after oneself, to take people off the waiting lists, and to move them away from the overcrowded public system into the private system.

The AHIAA figures indicate that there is about 82 per cent public support for rebates for private health insurance premiums. I am sure that those honourable members in marginal seats will be very aware of the fact that their policy gives no encouragement to take out private health insurance at all. Yet even amongst Labor voters, the support for those rebates was 79 per cent. It certainly gives one food for thought.

Eighty-eight per cent of the people surveyed believed that more people would take out private health insurance if tax rebates were offered. Clearly, that is the case. That is the direction in which to go. It will be to the benefit of the public system and the private system. Yet nothing in this legislation addresses those issues. All we have is more blunders from the Minister for Health; we have a litany of blunders.

We had a memorable press conference about the coalition's health policy. The Minister was out by $2 billion in his figures and he could not work out where he was wrong. He left the conference to walk into the closet, which was probably the appropriate place for him to walk into. He blamed the incorrect figures on his Department when that was clearly not the case; he just did not understand what was going on. He subsequently put out press releases on the wrong figures. He has had a backdown on the black box in pharmacy. There has been another backdown on radiology.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of your shadow Ministers knew what they were talking about.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! The honourable member for Fowler might cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Labor Party dominated Senate committee itself told the Minister to withdraw his own regulations—a committee dominated by your Labor Party supporters.
—How many shadow Ministers have you had on the other side?
—The honourable member for Fowler will cease interjecting.
—How many decent Health Ministers have you had on your side? Not one.
—We have had two.
—Not one!
—Oh yes, we have.

—Brian Howe is a joke. Come on! The Department laughs at him behind his back. His Deputy Secretaries tell me that he is not going to last. The whole thing is falling apart around his ears. One could not have many more humiliating somersaults and policy reversals than Brian Howe has suffered. He said that the whole thing was unsustainable—that he was forced to make it unsustainable. How can you justify that? How can you survive with that one? I guess the answer is that he survives only because he is Deputy Prime Minister and because the Prime Minister needs the support of the Left. That is the only possible reason why he is still there. He is not there on merit; there is no question about that. He had to back down on radiology. A Labor Party dominated Senate committee told him to withdraw his own regulations. How humiliating can you get?
—I raise a point of order. I feel that the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) has contravened Standing Orders far enough in casting aspersions on the excellent Minister for Health.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER—I do not think there is a point of order, but the honourable member should be careful that he does not cast any aspersions on any other members of parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has also failed to take any action in regard to the ridiculous and extreme comments of the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) about nationalisation of the health system, which is clearly on the agenda. The only question is how long it is going to take this Government, if it is allowed to stay in government for long enough, to actually nationalise and socialise the whole health system. Thank goodness there is going to be an election in the near future and we will be able to rescue the health system from the disaster it is facing.

PARA.TAB: In general terms we are opposed, therefore, to two issues: one is in regard to the tabling of the borrowings by the hearing authority; the other is, as is sensible and as the Minister for Health himself would want to support, the opposition to the reversal of the co-payment scheme. We will certainly indicate our unhappiness and displeasure with those two aspects of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand in strong support of the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, which incorporates significant aspects of housing, aged care, Medicare and health services in Australia. My colleagues will touch on some of these issues. I will address one of the most important facets of this Bill—the reforms and forward planning arising out of the Disability Services Act, adding another major step to those taken in recent years to correct the century long neglect of people with disabilities in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Since taking office in 1983, the Government has been instrumental in making Australia's commitment to the rights of people with a disability a reality. Sweeping reforms have been introduced to enable people with disabilities to have exactly the same rights, opportunities and freedoms as those which are generally available to the Australian public. These have been a direct response to increasing calls from the community for a greater focus on individuals and greater control over how services are delivered and public resources used.

In 1985, the report of the handicapped programs review, entitled New Directions, set out a range of proposals for the improvement of services for people with disabilities. This was followed in 1987 by the enactment of the Disability Services Act, along with its principles and objectives.

The introduction of the Disability Services Act has led to the development of services which not only provide basic support for people but also, by law, enhance the dignity and worth of individuals. The Government's commitment to social justice and human rights demands that we begin to shape systems to fit the needs of individuals rather than try to shape individuals to fit the systems.

In the past 12 months the focus of the disability services program has shifted, quite properly, from a concern about how services and supports are provided to asking what individuals with a disability need and want, and how they might be assisted in meeting their own goals. As well as providing better chances for people with disabilities to gain employment, the disability reform package makes certain that people with severe disabilities, those who may have more limited job prospects, will receive adequate and secure income support. The employment initiatives developed under the disability reform package are the surest way out of poverty and social marginalisation for people with disability. They are also the most effective and image-enhancing way of removing barriers to participation and enabling people with a disability to play an effective and valued role in the society's work force. This will surely enrich the whole society.

I will highlight some of the changes. The reform is designed to provide income support for those who are unable to participate in the labour market and every encouragement and opportunity for people with a disability to participate in society and to enjoy a reasonable standard of living. The employment services funded under the Disability Services Act are an integral part of the reform package. The package includes 4,000 new employment places in Commonwealth funded services and 4,500 new places under the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service over the three years ending 1993-94.

In February 1990, minimum standards for all services, known as minimum outcomes, were established. These minimum outcomes are designed to ensure the protection of fundamental human and consumer rights in the areas of grievance mechanisms, privacy safeguards, individualised planning, decision making, choice and employee rights. Over 99 per cent of services have now said either that they now meet the minimum outcomes or they will meet them by 30 June 1992. The Government welcomes this news. This represents a significant increase in the overall service quality over the last 18 months. For those few organisations that have not met the minimum outcomes by that deadline, it is important that they know that they will not be closed down. Rather, departmental officers will work closely with the organisation to help it establish the framework for the changes.

The drafting of the second stage, which builds on the minimum outcomes, was commenced last year. Again, the families, carers, advocates and service providers will be asked to express their comments. Services will be assisted to meet the second stage of standards, set for 30 June 1995. This process reinforces the Government's confidence in service providers, their abilities and their commitment to providing the best possible services for their consumers. The Government remains committed to increasing the quality of service for people with a disability and to a broad quality assurance approach. The introduction of service standards and ways to check whether services are meeting these represent only the core elements of an effective and comprehensive quality assurance system that protects the rights and the quality of life of people with a disability and drives for continuing improvement. This is a key element of the Government's ongoing social justice commitment in the area of disability.

I would like to comment about sheltered workshops. In spite of the Government's achievements, the Opposition has tried on a number of occasions to amend the Disability Services Act in ways which would reduce the opportunities for people with a disability and which would waste the resources set aside for supporting people with a disability. One example is its insistence on specifically including sheltered workshops as an endorsed model of service delivery under the Act.

The Government recognises that for some people, such as those who have been working in sheltered workshops for over 20 years, the transition to employment is very difficult. Such people will not be left without a service or forced into an employment option against their wishes. However, to suggest that resources should be directed to providing more sheltered workshops is wasteful. Against any measure, open employment services are a far better investment of Commonwealth moneys, especially considering that sheltered workshops and open employment services assist people with a similar support-need profile.

Cost efficiency helps no-one, least of all the people with a disability for whom services are provided. For instance, according to the 1991 census of disability services, the Government provides an annual average of $1,800 per consumer placed in open employment service and $2,400 per consumer in a sheltered workshop. But the average weekly wage for persons with a disability in open employment, the cheaper service, is some $217, whereas in the sheltered workshops, the dearer service, it is around only $41. While the Government's assistance is for support costs and not for wages, it is interesting to note that, for every dollar the Government provides for assisting someone into open employment, there is another amount for—excuse me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't the Minister type it properly?

—No. The Minister did not type this. For every dollar the Government provides for assisting someone into open employment that person receives, on average, $6.26 in wages. I am sorry, I lost that figure for the moment. Yet for every dollar given to sheltered workshops the consumer receives an average of only some 88c in wages.

PARA.TAB: For existing sheltered workshops, the Government wants to work with them to continually improve service quality. The Government is not about closing down or defunding services and consequently leaving people with a disability without support. Neither, however, is it about locking service providers into a particular method of service delivery which is not appropriate to the needs and aspirations of people with a disability. New employment services should ensure the rights which we all enjoy and expect as Australians: a fair day's pay for a fair day's work; a safe working environment; and respect for labour.

Any employment service, regardless of the model of service delivery, which meets the standard and the principles and objectives can be funded under the Act. The Government is not about dictating to individual services what particular model or approach to service delivery they should adopt. However, the Government does have clear expectations about consumer outcomes.

So what does the Bill do in the area of standards, quality assurance and equity? Despite the massive increase in funding in past years, demand for disability services still exceeds supply. Given this, it is vitally important that services are accessed by those most in need and that the resources of the disability services program are allocated as equitably as possible. The existing submission based system of allocating resources has resulted in an unequal distribution of disability services across regions and among social groups.

The consumer focused funding approach, CFFA, and needs based planning are two initiatives which are being developed to address this inequity. Needs based planning involves the collection and analysis of information on where people with a disability live, what their needs may be and the existing supply of services to meet those needs. This information, in conjunction with community consultation on needs, will give the program a better idea of those areas which have the greatest need for resources. Under CFFA, the level of funding for new service providers is based on an assessment of the type and level of support required by each individual using that service. Funds may not be used for any other person and may transfer to another similar service if the person with the disability chooses to receive assistance from another agency.

It is important for me to note that the Government recognises that there are needs for people 18 years of age and over. There are other needs outside those which we are addressing. It is important for to us fill in the gaps of neglect that have existed over the years. We are doing so energetically on a one-to-one basis.

This package of reforms continues the original vision of the Disability Services Act. The amendments build on the foundations that have been laid and move forward to the full implementation of that Act. The Government remains committed to social justice for people with disabilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and particularly on the amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986. I am very pleased to be following the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) because later I will touch on some of her scurrilous accusations about our amendments. I believe it would be useful to run through some of the background to the proposed amendments to the Disability Services Act and to give the coalition's position on the Act since its implementation in 1987.

PARA.TAB: The Disability Services Act was passed in December 1986 with the support of all parties. The Act replaced the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974. The Disability Services Act was accompanied by a statement of principles and objectives, setting out the right of people with disabilities to individual respect, freedom of choice and fulfilment of their individual potential.

The Act came into effect on 1 July 1987. The key element of the new program was integration of the disabled into the community through increased independence and greater employment opportunities. It was proposed that implementation of the Act would take place over a five-year period to 30 June 1992, during which time consultations would take place with all people concerned with disability services.

As far back as 1988—just one year after the Act came into effect—the coalition, particularly the then shadow Minister for community services, my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), cautioned against too quick a change. He said that for some it would take time to adapt. That note of caution was not heeded by the Government, and it is pleasing to see some of that concern being addressed in this Bill. In 1989 the honourable member for Dawson spoke about the concern and confusion among relatives of people with a disability and service providers during the transition period of the DSA.

The implementation of the Act presented considerable difficulties, not least because of the inflexible interpretation of the Act by the bureaucrats, their insufficient depth of understanding of the legislation and their lack of skills to implement the requirements in both the government and non-government sectors. Other reasons included the uncertainties of funding during the transition period; the fact that changes in concepts and principles have created fear and confusion amongst parents; the lack of communication and understanding between governments and the non-government sector; and the fact that the Department for Health, Housing and Community Services has undergone almost continuous and massive restructuring since 1984, which has created considerable tension with the voluntary organisations, and a lack of continuity and consistency of departmental decisions. Also it has tended to leave the departmental staff less professional than required.

Since 1989 the coalition has attempted to provide solutions to these problems. In November of that year the honourable member for Dawson presented a draft Bill to Parliament proposing amendments to the Disability Services Act. In November 1990 he presented a private member's Bill proposing similar amendments. In September 1991 he again presented this Bill proposing the same amendments, but the Government provided no opportunity for its fuller debate and acceptance. In April this year he presented the Bill yet again.

For almost three years, on behalf of people with disabilities, parents and service providers, the coalition has been pressing the Government to accept the fact that the 1986 Act was not immutable, that change was needed and that a greater degree of certainty and compassion is required in the administration of the Act.

It is intolerable that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has allowed so many carers and people with disabilities to suffer for so long the stress of not knowing whether their services will continue after June 1992 and what service guidelines will follow. As the architect of the Act, the former Senator Don Grimes, said as recently as February this year:

SPEECH.PARA: The principles and objectives that were set out in the disability services legislation in 1986 are as clear and as sensible as can be found in most places. But I must remind those involved, as I used to at the time, that they are but standards and guidelines to help in the development of programs to assist people to fill their developments in society. They are no more than that.

But the Government, the Minister and the bureaucracy have set their own agenda, creating uncertainty and risking the lifestyles of so many disabled Australians. The coalition has continually urged the Government to amend the Act to provide more flexibility and more certainty to people with disabilities, their families and their service providers. We proposed that guidelines be formulated and brought before Parliament for debate, and amended if necessary, so that the criteria for funding of services would be clearly laid down.

PARA.TAB: We also proposed that the transition date, the period in which financial assistance for prescribed services and for upgrading prescribed services is payable, be extended to give existing services more time to adapt to the requirements of the DSA. Our amendments also provided for security of contracts between the Government and the service provider, and an appeals procedure. We also proposed that the service-type `supported employment services' be amended to include specifically work crews, small businesses, enclaves, individual supported jobs and sheltered workshops.

The Disability Services Act has opened up new options for people with disabilities, and this the Opposition applauds and approves. However, we believe that there is still a need for services such as sheltered workshops, hostels, nursing homes and activity therapy centres to be able to coexist alongside the new service.

The Minister has stated that he and his Department are examining alternative services for people with severe disabilities who will never be able to participate fully in the open work force. Until an alternative service is in place, we strongly believe that, if sheltered workshops were not an option, it would be denying many people with disabilities the right to work, the right to training, the right to gain living skills and the right to a choice. They would be sentenced to an existence of boredom and frustration at home, with the consequent stresses on their families and carers. The honourable member for Lilley said that our amendment does not address this problem and that we would be denying these people access to those services. That is quite wrong.

Last November the Minister outlined his blueprint for action for disability services. He stated that he would amend the Disability Services Act. He told the ACROD conference that the transition date of 1992 would be removed but that he would require all types of services, including sheltered workshops, activity therapy centres and large accommodation services, to meet certain standards by 1995 in order to continue to be eligible for funding.

The Minister also stated that he would formulate and table the section 5 guidelines. One of the major amendments proposed in this Bill recognises that the five-year transition period was not long enough to deal with the complexity of change required. The Bill removes the transition date and provides ongoing funding to prescribed services—that is, services in existence pre-1987, such as sheltered workshops, accommodation services and activity therapy centres—provided they meet minimum standards.

Parents and disability service providers welcome this amendment. Section 14(1)(a) of the amending Bill provides a safeguard for those who believe that this amendment will take away any inducement on the part of services to progress and offer greater educational and training opportunities to people with disabilities. This section provides that the Minister may terminate funding to a prescribed service—presumably, if it is not meeting required standards.

The Bill removes the restriction on funding for profit organisations. This allows the Minister to fund, on a case by case basis, services that are provided by other than non-profit organisations. Some organisations in the voluntary sector are concerned about this amendment and believe it to be unnecessary. The Minister states that it will assist in the provision of attendant care services.It has been pointed out that under existing legislation there should be no reason why non-profit organisations approved by the Minister should not engage in private for profit attendant care services in meeting service delivery needs in accordance with their contract with the Government. I should be interested to hear the Minister's comment on that.

Voluntary organisations such as the Endeavour Foundation provide immeasurable support to the disabled and their families. The Endeavour Foundation is 76 per cent self-funded; the Government's contribution amounts to 24 per cent. This figure reflects the determination and commitment of the volunteers and representatives of the Foundation who tirelessly coordinate continual fund raising projects. I cannot speak highly enough of all such voluntary organisations.

The Bill amends the objects of the Disability Services Act to clarify that the disability services program and the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service are assistance programs that operate within budget constraints. For any government there is only so much money available, and there will never be enough to fund all programs to everyone's satisfaction. Much as we would like the disability services program and the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service to be entitlement programs, in reality they are not, and cannot be.

However, we would request clarification of the new subsection 5(g)(2)(b) which states that due regard must be had for the need to consider equity and merit in accessing these resources. We hope that this applies to the actual services provided, and that all people with disabilities requiring a service will receive a service, but that those services for people with severe and multiple disabilities that may require substantial resources are still able to have access to those resources.

The Minister has stated publicly that he will formulate and table guidelines under section 5 of the Disability Services Act. However, they are not included in this legislation. The coalition has stressed that these guidelines must not be tabled as disallowable instruments. They must—and I stress must—be introduced into the Parliament for debate, amended if necessary, and approved.

I foreshadow that we will be moving an amendment to this effect in committee. We shall also be moving other amendments proposed in the private member's Bill of the honourable member for Dawson. In conclusion, I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge the exceptional contribution made by the honourable member for Dawson and his staff in the area of community services and aged care prior to his resignation from the shadow Ministry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in entering the debate on the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill. This is an omnibus Bill which makes a series of amendments to a raft of legislation in the areas of health, housing and therapeutic goods. Included amongst those amendments are important amendments such as giving legislative base to the agreement between the States and the Commonwealth about the safety nets to achieve a joint Commonwealth-State safety net for pharmaceutical drugs. This is important from the aspect of clarifying for the patients—the consumers—how they can go about getting proper treatment, and not leaving them to worry about which sphere of government has the constitutional responsibility for the institution from which they are getting treatment or drugs.

PARA.TAB: Like the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) and the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), I wish to discuss the disability services aspects of this legislation. May I say from the outset that yet again the honourable member for Maranoa, in leading for the Opposition, has used the type of tactic that we see often in discussions on disability services matters and matters of aged care policy, where we take what is perceived to be a vulnerable group and use that sort of scare tactic in discussions in that area.

If we go to the basis of the Government's actions in the disability services area, what has to be remembered is that this Labor Government has brought with it into office a vision for social justice; a vision for a fairer, more prosperous and just society in which every Australian receives a fair share of the nation's wealth. This vision remains unaltered. It is the light on the hill that the Labor Party has worked towards over the past 100 years. It calls for a society with an equitable distribution of economic resources; equality of civic and legal rights; fair and equal access to essential services such as housing, health and education; and the opportunity for every member of society to participate in community life.

One measure of our maturity as a society is the extent to which disadvantaged groups are encouraged and are able to share in the responsibilities and benefits of society. In this context this Government has done more for people with a disability than any government before it. The Disability Services Act of 1986, which was introduced by this Government, is regarded internationally as a great step forward in legislative support for people with a disability and the services that support them.

Against many other competing priorities, the Government has increased funding for disability services since 1983 from $104m to $279m and will increase this further to $383m by 1996. This represents an increase of over 60 per cent in real terms, and an almost fourfold improvement in dollar terms towards the provision of practical support for people with a disability. The introduction of the Act has seen an unprecedented number of people with a disability receive support under Commonwealth funded programs and services.

The Department's 1991 census of disability services reports that there are more than 94,000 consumers of Commonwealth funded disability services. This is a 173 per cent increase over the 1986 census. Ultimately, we are striving towards social justice for all Australians so that people with a disability can participate fully in economic, social and political life and can determine and control the direction of their own lives.

Let us now contrast this with the Opposition's vision and an Opposition agenda which wishes to save money. This Government's achievements and vision stand in stark contrast to the Opposition's proposals. While the Government sees the achievement of human rights for people with a disability as a necessary investment for Australia, the Opposition's agenda appears to be to return Australia to its inefficient and paternalistic past—as the honourable member for Lilley put it earlier in the debate, a century of neglect.

The fact that the Opposition wants to spend less on programs for people with a disability is a matter that is on the public record. For instance, the explanatory memorandum relating to the private member's Bill introduced by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), the Disability Services Amendment Bill 1989, says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . expenditure . . . would not exceed current intended expenditure, and may well be less.

The honourable member for Maranoa in his contribution tonight even confirmed that and suggested that more funds are unlikely to be put towards disability services. Not only does the Opposition want to cut expenditure on programs for people with a disability; it also wants to put unworkable administrative arrangements in place. For some time now the honourable member for Dawson, in his former capacity as the Opposition spokesperson in this area, had been proposing amendments to the Act concerning the details of funding agreements between the Commonwealth and service providers. The proposed amendments would limit the areas which may be covered in such funding agreements. Whatever the intent of these amendments, their outcome would result in the maladministration of Commonwealth funds. The Opposition's proposals would prevent the Minister making terms or conditions of grant to cover those situations where the welfare and safety of service users is jeopardised.

PARA.TAB: While the great majority of service providers are working in the interests of the service users, unfortunately there have been occasions where service users have suffered abuse. In such a situation, the Government needs the power to terminate the grant and transfer the funding to another agency in respect of the service users. Under the Opposition's amendments, the Government would be bound to continue funding the abuse of people with a disability.

Not only would the Government be unable to address a proven case of abuse, but the Opposition's amendments would also prevent the Government from reviewing what is being achieved through the financial assistance it is providing. Departmental officers would be unable to inspect a service, organisations providing services would not be required to take out appropriate insurance, the Commonwealth would not be indemnified or protected from misrepresentations and so on. Such provisions in funding agreements are the backbone of sound financial management. One can easily imagine the outcry if a similar legislative requirement were placed on all commercial contracts. Why, then, place it on the Commonwealth?

Some people with interests in this area have expressed concern about the consistency of decision making under the disability services program and have suggested that decisions under the Act be made subject to review by the AAT—the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The introduction of administrative guidelines and clear objective standards under the Act will result in fair and consistent decision making. In addition, the Government's Bill will establish an independent disability standards review panel to provide an independent merits based review. This will apply in those situations where the Minister plans to sanction a service provider that he or she considers is not meeting the applicable standards.

However, with respect to funding decisions, the Attorney-General's Department has identified a number of situations where an AAT review is inappropriate. These situations include decisions which grant financial assistance to States or Territories and decisions made against a finite or limited amount of money where a review decision to give money to one applicant would affect the decisions to grant money to the other applicants. Grants under the Disability Services Act can be made to States and Territories, and funding decisions are made against a fixed amount of money. Consequently, AAT review is inappropriate for funding decisions under the Act.

The Opposition's amendments go beyond proposing AAT review of funding decisions. They propose both AAT review and review by the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act of decisions made in connection with the administration of part 2 of the Disability Services Act.

The sheer burden of this requirement would smother productivity. Written statements of reasons could be sought or appeals lodged over any administrative action: for instance, `Why did the departmental officer not visit my service?', `The departmental officer did not provide me with enough assistance in writing a funding application', `Why does the Government not review my service every six months?', and so on. As a consequence, departmental officers could spend all of their time dealing with appeals and statements of reasons. No time would be left for assisting people with a disability.

In order to achieve meaningful and enduring reforms, there must be cooperation and participation in the reform process at all levels of society. In Australia an unprecedented partnership between people with disabilities, their families, all spheres of government, service providers, employers and unions is resulting in a significant change in opportunities for people with disabilities.

This Government is committed to providing people with disabilities with the same rights and opportunities as are available to other Australians. The Government's reforms are not isolated initiatives which will have only a transitory impact on the lives of people with a disability. They are the foundations of this Government's vision for a fairer and more just society in which people with disabilities are equal participants. The Government's amendments to the Disability Services Act will continue this vision of justice and fairness.

It is the responsibility of all Australians to work together to achieve a society in which people with disabilities are accepted as ordinary citizens with the same rights as all others in the community, in which they can gain and hold meaningful employment with wages and career opportunities which reflect their abilities, and in which control by people with a disability over their own bodies, lives and futures is assumed and assured.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill in relation to aged care and nursing homes. First of all, I pay tribute to my predecessor in this portfolio area, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who is present in the House and who put forward a private member's Bill in the area of disability services.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) has seen fit to make a number of party political points relating to proposals put forward by my colleague. The honourable member for Dawson has discussed these matters quite extensively with the providers and the consumers of services in this disability area and has not taken a partisan political view on these matters. As everybody knows, the Government's proposals in this area—and, more particularly, the way they have been administered by the Department, with particular views taken in the Department—have been a matter of considerable difficulty. Anyone listening would not understand from the speech made by the honourable member for Scullin that the proposals put forward by the honourable member for Dawson had overwhelming support from those actually involved in the delivery of services.

I am not going to take a party political view on the proposals put forward by the Government within the area of nursing homes. In fact, the Opposition will support these. The problem of care of the aged is a national problem, one on which there has been quite a deal of agreement across parties. It is an area which I know reasonably well, having had the responsibility for administering nursing homes as Minister for Health in the Fraser Government and understanding the difficulties we had with the 1973 legislation and the changes that had to be made after we left. It was a pity there was a gap of about two years after we left in which virtually nothing was done and we lost a lot of ground.

The first of the specific proposals in the Bill to which I wish to refer relates to pre-admission leave for nursing home residents. Currently, nursing home residents have the capacity to take 28 days of recreation leave a year without the proprietor of the nursing home losing any nursing home benefits. Unfortunately, none of these days of leave are available to the person on immediate admission to the nursing home. This means that, unless a person is able to take up immediate residence when notified that he or she is able to go into a home, there is a loss of income to the proprietor. This proposal quite sensibly says that they can take some of the 28 days—I think up to two—getting themselves ready to go in. It is a perfectly sensible proposal, which we support.

The second item refers to the disclosure of information to prospective purchasers of nursing homes. If a person is about to buy a nursing home, he really needs to know something about it. Currently the secrecy provisions of the National Health Act prevent the disclosure by the Department of information relating to a nursing home to a prospective purchaser. This Bill, quite sensibly, makes that information available. Obviously, if a person is going to buy a nursing home he does not want to buy a pig in a poke. He needs essential information from the Department, and this allows that to happen.

I would like to draw to the attention of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) a very important concern of purchasers of nursing homes relating to validation problems. The system of validation means that, after the expiry of a particular period of funding, the Department is called upon to examine the accounts of the nursing home to see whether the moneys which have been advanced have been properly expended. It can call upon the nursing home to return moneys which are not properly acquitted. Because of backlogs and so on in some cases it will be a number of years before this takes place.

Under the present arrangements the purchaser of a nursing home is held liable for moneys which need to be returned following a validation which has been unsatisfactory from the proprietor's point of view. This seems to me to be a problem that the Government ought to look at. It seems somewhat unfair—even after this disclosure, which we support, has been put in place—that there could easily be information which would not be available until after the validation has taken place. It is probably more equitable if the original proprietor were liable for the shortfall rather than that being applied to the incoming proprietor who may have had no knowledge of the underlying circumstances of that shortfall. I ask the Minister to look at that particular matter.

The third point relates to records to be kept by the former proprietors for 12 months after sale so that they can be inspected. That is a perfectly reasonable provision, again which we support. The fourth item relates to the transfer of nursing home beds. When approval in principle for transfer of beds from one nursing home to another is asked for, it will be subject to a condition that the proprietor of the home yielding the beds continues to comply with nursing home conditions of approval. I am a little at a loss to understand why this is necessary because the Department can impose these conditions anyway. It has to supervise the standards of nursing homes and it can withdraw approvals for them if standards are not right. In this case, I suppose it gives extra leverage. If a person wants to dispose of a nursing home, he is prevented from doing so if he does not fully comply with nursing home conditions. One would think that, if he was not complying with those conditions anyway, other action can be taken. Nonetheless, we support this particular measure.

The fifth item relates to the divulgence of information to receivers or liquidators. Again, the secrecy provisions of the National Health Act prevent the Department from letting receivers or liquidators know very important information about the operation of a particular nursing home. Similarly to the second provision on disclosure of information to prospective purchasers, it would seem that the Department should make this information available to receivers or liquidators.

I am interested in the fact that this item has been put in at a time when the Minister is denying that receivership or liquidation is very much a problem for nursing homes. At the moment because of the funding arrangements and the inadequacies of the SAM component, if I can use a technicality—the overhead component of nursing home funding—a number of nursing homes are in serious threat of receivership or liquidation. Some of them are already in that position. The Minister is denying that that is the case. Nonetheless, it is interesting to note that there is this particular provision in this Bill.

In speaking on the fifth aspect of the Bill, I would like to draw attention to the fact that there are serious inadequacies in the present funding proposals. They are still unresolved after a very long period of negotiation between the nursing home associations and the Government.

A number of nursing homes in three States are in dire straits because the matter has not been resolved. We think that the Government is looking at it. I will be very interested to know exactly how the Government will deal with this matter. It strikes me that the underlying reasons for this difficulty are more complicated than the Government is prepared to admit. I am not sure how it is going to deal with it within the present framework of funding for nursing homes. I merely advise the House that the Opposition expresses grave concern about the inadequacies of the SAM component of funding and that it is quite sceptical of claims made by the Minister that the matter is truly under review and will be dealt with as soon as possible.

People are on the very verge of bankruptcy. The major problems seem to be in the State of Victoria, although there are problems in two other States, as I am informed. I press the Minister, in his reply, to give some information as to the progress of the inquiry because people really are at the abyss in this respect.

We are not taking a highly partisan view on this extremely important matter of care for the aged. Generally speaking, the proposals for change made by the Government are practical and sensible ones. Unlike the honourable member for Scullin, we do not seek to make political points but support sensible changes—as the Opposition is always prepared to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —As other speakers in the debate have mentioned already, the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill that seeks to amend a number of Acts in that portfolio area. For instance, part 2 of the Bill makes a number of amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986 which are designed to improve the standard of service provided to disabled people by Commonwealth-funded organisations. I note that my colleague the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) spoke on that matter earlier. I also understand that the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) spoke about the aspects of the Bill which deal with disability.
