PARA.TAB: Part 4 covers amendments to the Health Insurance Act to discourage excessive ordering of diagnostic imaging services by practitioners, more broadly defined; and part 6 extends the safety net arrangements contained in part VII of the National Health Act 1953 to enable medication supplied through outpatient departments of State public hospitals and repatriation hospitals to be counted towards the threshold for the issue of concession and entitlement cards.

However, it is part 7 of the Bill that I want to concentrate on this evening. I note that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) also referred to it when he discussed the administration of nursing homes under the aged and community care program. I am delighted to support the measures in that part of the Bill.

The Government's record of achievement in aged care is outstanding. We inherited a system that was lopsided, inequitable, costly and ineffective. It is no accident that we now have a network of aged care services that is the equal of anywhere in the world and better than in most other countries.

In a few short years this Government's aged care program has been able to develop the type of care that most frail elderly people need and want—and indeed the families of most frail elderly people would want such care for them—that is, the care to help them remain in their own homes for as long as possible. The home and community care program has enabled vital services, such as home nursing, home care, meals on wheels, home maintenance services and transport services to expand significantly.

Since 1984, expenditure on the home and community care program has increased by a massive 240 per cent. I point out to honourable members in the House—although I am sure that many of them are aware of this—that the home and community care program is very popular in the community. Although some old people who live in their homes are not aware of all of the services that are available—the home maintenance service, for instance, which is often available through local councils—this is because the council has not publicised the service sufficiently, not because the service is not available or not being funded.

I also note that there are now small hostels in the community where people who are suffering from senile dementia, for instance, are able to be looked after and supervised but not treated like invalids. That is the distinction which used to be made—they were either treated as mentally ill or as invalids. Neither of those forms of treatment were very suitable for a person who was frequently hale and hearty physically but not always able to remember and, in a continuing fashion, not able to function as well as they previously could.

One of my constituents, who is a blind man, has a wife with senile dementia. He has to try to look after her. It causes him considerable anxiety. He is comforted to know that should he ever require her to be placed in a hostel to relieve the stress on him, that would be possible. I commend the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) for the changes and the improvements that have been made in that area of home and community care and in hostel care.

The success of the program has enabled the pressure to be taken off nursing homes. Many frail aged people are now able to stay at home rather than go to a nursing home when they do not really need to. That is a much more appropriate care for the person, as well as being cheaper in terms of the cost to the community at large. Nursing home care is now more readily available for the seriously ill or disabled older person who genuinely needs around the clock nursing care. It is horses for courses; the right sort of care for the person's needs.

The aged care measures in this Bill are particularly concerned with nursing homes. Not long ago our society regarded such homes as places where people went to die. One euphemistic description which was used was `God's waiting rooms'. We all now believe—I think we always should have—that our aged citizens deserve much better than that. A person who enters a nursing home should be able to do so in a dignified and self-respecting manner. A nursing home resident should be able to maintain as normal a life as possible and still be able to feel that he or she is part of the wider Australian community. Often, this means that residents will need help from the home's staff, their families or friends. It also means that the resident will have to feel secure in their new home and free to move between the nursing home and the wider community as they desire and as their frailty allows. This is definitely improving. This Bill helps that course of action.

In recent years, the Government has introduced several important initiatives to ensure that the care that our older Australians receive in nursing homes is of the highest standard. Many of these initiatives have seen Australia leading the world in this most important area. For instance, from 1987 outcome standards have been introduced to see that the quality of care is of a uniformly high standard. I recall that Senator Pat Giles was very involved in a Senate committee which undertook a study in this area. The quality of care in Australian nursing homes was not uniformly good, but legislation is now there to ensure quality of care. I think that all people who have elderly parents or elderly relatives would be relieved to see that that occurred some time ago.The assessment is now available. With staffing levels being improved, nursing home staff can ensure that all residents with the same level of dependency receive the same level of care.

In introducing its program of aged care reforms, the Government has also been aware that the final decisions as to how to deliver the care should be made only by those in the best position to do so. The people who should make these decisions are, of course, professional and very dedicated people who staff nursing homes and the residents themselves. It has been easy in the past for people not to consult with residents in nursing homes and to believe that they are somehow incapable of deciding, or are disinterested in, their own welfare.

The Government's aged care program is designed to allow nursing homes and residents as much flexibility and freedom of choice as possible. It is also designed to allow residents to enjoy a life that is as close as possible to their previous life outside the nursing home. I point out to the House an example in my electorate—I am sure that other members would have similar examples in their electorates—of an Italian nursing home called Villa Terenzio where almost all of the residents in the hostel or the hospital speak Italian and many of the staff also speak Italian.

The family visiting arrangements and the open days at that nursing home and hostel are wonderful to see. These people take great care of their relatives and constantly attend the hostel and the nursing home to make sure that the feeling that the residents have of the nursing home is as close as possible to the feeling they have for their own home. That is a very good thing for people who are old and who do not want to be treated as though they no longer matter.

The current leave arrangements for nursing homes allow residents to go on leave from the nursing home to receive treatment in hospital or for personal and social reasons. That is an improvement which the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has overseen in recent years. Residents are able to take this leave to return to their families for special occasions or even just to have a break away from the nursing home. While residents are on leave, the Government continues to subsidise the nursing home for their beds, which must be available when they return. This is a sensible arrangement that was not always available. That meant that frequently people were afraid to go out of the nursing home—even for serious problems that required hospitalisation—because they feared that their bed would not be available when they returned.

In March 1990 the Government introduced unlimited hospital leave for both nursing home and hostel residents. This is in addition to an entitlement of 28 days each year for social leave. This latest government initiative to allow residents two days of preadmission leave represents a further enhancement of the leave arrangements for aged people in residential care. I believe this Bill, whilst being an omnibus Bill containing a lot of other aspects of legislation, covers some very important territory in the areas of nursing homes and aged care, and I commend it to the House, without amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleagues have already pointed out, the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill makes a number of changes to a range of Acts which fall within the Health, Housing and Community Services portfolio. Because of the large scope of the Bill and the limited time available in which to discuss it, I intend to confine my comments to those provisions relating to the Disability Services Act and the First Home Owners Act.

PARA.TAB: When I read the proposed amendments to the Disabilities Services Act 1986 my thoughts automatically reflected on a group of parents within my electorate who have been in constant contact with me over the past three years. The parents, all of whom have children with intellectual disabilities, came to see me initially not because they objected to the Act itself, but because they were frightened by the big brother attitude of the Government, an attitude which I might add appears to be at the point of forcing the closure of sheltered workshops Australia-wide.

The parents argued that unrealistic guidelines were being rigidly enforced without proper consultation or consideration of how difficult it would be for sheltered workshops to comply. These guidelines had not been asked for by those with intellectual disabilities or their parents or their service providers. Indeed, the vast majority of those who were directly involved in community services had neither volunteered nor been asked for their views. While the parents felt that their objections would probably make no difference to a government that could not be bothered to ask and rarely ever listened, they resolved to give it a go.

As it transpired, my constituents were not the only ones prepared to stand up and be counted. The parents in my electorate were joined by hundreds more from all over Australia, and a powerful lobby group was eventually formed. There is no doubt in my mind that the amendments before us are as a result of the actions of this group. Changes to the disability services require time, patience and an open-minded approach in order to succeed. Clearly, any plan to integrate disabled people into society, where they compete for jobs on the open market, cannot under the present economic climate succeed.

With close on one million people unemployed, jobs are scarce and competition is fierce. Employers can pick and choose from a bottomless pit of applicants. Only the best qualified can hope to win. Did this Government seriously intend to force our intellectually disabled, who are totally unprepared for such a change, to compete in such a climate? Did the Labor Party's ideals, which seek to control every aspect of our lives, override commonsense and social conscience?

These amendments go part of the way towards the apology due to this particular section of our society. They represent a clear backdown by this Government, an admission that its high-handed attitude has backfired. I note that this Government has also yielded to Opposition pressure for amendments in a number of other areas. In particular, it has yielded to our calls for an appeals procedure, for full consultation with service providers and receivers and for more flexibility in its guidelines.

Dealing firstly with the provisions of an intermediate level of service standard and attainment, the establishment of so-called transitional services, I would be interested in learning how many funded services will actually meet the guidelines set down by the Government by June of 1992. I suspect it will be very few indeed because, realistically, as the Government was warned repeatedly, the guidelines were too rigid to be attainable. In spite of this, I welcome the amendments which will give valuable breathing space to sheltered workshops, which feared their funding would be cut at the end of June.

In considering the Government's intention to incorporate an appeals procedure, I hope that the proposed disability standards review panel comprises a balanced cross-section of service providers and receivers. Similarly, we must be sure that everyone concerned with this section of society is given the opportunity to have a say in the future moulding of services for the disabled. This is not only a courtesy; it is also a necessity if our disabled are to be provided with the best possible lifestyle.

There is a world of difference between government assistance and government interference. There are a number of first-class sheltered workshops operating throughout Australia which would undoubtedly benefit from assistance. Instead, they are struggling to cope with interference. It is the Opposition's view that efficient services which provide the best practicable lifestyle for particular people should be left in place. Most importantly of all, we must be absolutely certain that these amendments are not designed to create a false sense of security.

I note that the Minister retains the power to determine clear and objective standards. In other words, he can, to a large extent, still pull the strings. I would therefore like to pass on to the Minister, as a gentle reminder, the views expressed to me by that group of parents three years ago. They told me they never had any concerns with the Disability Services Act as legislation. However, its implementation had amounted to `bureaucracy gone mad'.

This Bill deals with a second group of people who also deserve some consideration from the Government: young families, especially those on low incomes who are struggling to buy their own homes. To this extent, part 3 of the Bill makes an amendment to the First Home Owners Act 1983 to provide for the reinstatement of payments to beneficiaries under the first home owners scheme once they have supplied their tax file number.

Before I move in to discuss this particular amendment in more detail, it is appropriate that I outline to the House a little of the background of the scheme. The first home owners scheme, known as FHOS, was first introduced by the Hawke Government in 1983. It replaced the three programs put in place by the Fraser Government to encourage home ownership; namely, the home deposit assistance scheme, the special tax rebate for first home owners and the general tax rebate in respect of interest paid on housing loans.

Collective annual expenditure on the Fraser Government's programs was around $360m compared with the $120m spent by the Government on FHOS during its last full year of operation. Regardless of this, FHOS was successful in the early days in helping young families into their own homes. In 1984-85, for example, the scheme provided funding for around 88,000 young individuals and families.

Following a tightening of the eligibility criteria, the Government's consistent refusal to index the eligibility threshold and a reduction in the grant provided, the impact of the program fell off significantly. Indeed, the number of families assisted dropped from 43,000 in 1986-87 to 36,000 in 1988-89 and finally to 25,000 in the year 1989-90.

The culmination of all of these changes and the dramatic reduction in the numbers assisted was, in the end, the Government's decision to abolish the program on 21 August 1990. In fact, this decision, plus the deliberate high interest rate policy of the late 1980s and the subsequent decline in housing affordability, signalled the end of the Government's commitment to home buyers. Significantly, along with the impact of poor economic policies, it also illustrated its lack of commitment to the building and construction industry.

It is interesting that the Government has maintained the status quo in regard to housing policy over the last couple of years. This is in spite of the growing power of the Labor Party Left—its social conscience—and all of the hand-outs and pork-barrelling contained in the One Nation statement. In fact, from where I stand, the Government's only initiative in the whole housing area has been the creation of the national housing strategy, a hugely expensive bureaucratic extravagance.

It has been the coalition which has retained its commitment to Australia's young families and to helping them realise their dream of owning a home. More importantly, we have had the courage to demonstrate our commitment by putting in place tangible measures to assist home buyers. To start with, the coalition will reintroduce the first home owners scheme. Low income families will receive a one-off payment of $2,000 to help with their first home purchase. Home buyers will be given access to their accumulated superannuation funds for use as part or all of the deposit on a home. They will also be able to earn up to $2,000 interest on their savings completely tax free, while their housing affordability—that is, the buyer's capacity to pay off a home loan—will be dramatically boosted through massive cuts to income tax rates.

The Bill we are debating this evening does not address these issues or any other relating to home ownership in any way, shape or form; nor does it outline the Government's intention to give more young families access to their own homes. What the Bill does do is correct an anomaly created by previous legislation which had the effect of depriving FHOS recipients of their benefit.

Following the introduction of the Government's data matching program, FHOS recipients were given 60 days from the date of request to supply their tax file numbers. If the tax file number was not provided within the nominated time, payment of the benefit was cancelled. However, an unintended consequence of the amendment was that benefits could not be reinstated once the tax file number was supplied. This legislation corrects that anomaly by providing for the restoration of benefits. It also brings the treatment of FHOS recipients into line with that of other welfare pension recipients to whom data matching systems apply. As such, this amendment will restore payments to some 500 FHOS recipients who inadvertently or for some other reason did not furnish their tax file numbers within the required 60 days. The Opposition welcomes the restoration of these payments and hence will not oppose this section of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill to talk specifically about community services, although it could be just as accurately said that I could address myself to some of the aged care concerns that came up with the Bill. What I say at the beginning is that I regret the manner in which two Government members have addressed themselves to this Bill, to really put at risk those people who are the most vulnerable within this community—the disabled. To suggest that the Opposition at any stage has considered using the disabled as political pawns in an argument is quite mischievous, it misrepresents the situation, and I would expect any honourable member who is doing his job in this House to check the facts.

PARA.TAB: I have continually said that the aged and the disabled within the community should not be subject to any political manipulations. If there is one thing in this House we should come together on, it is the interests of the aged and the disabled because they have no other forum to appeal to than the parties that form this Parliament.

To suggest that the amendments that we have had placed on the record in the past two or three years, begging the Government's intervention to pick them up and do something with them, were of a political nature is something which I resent most thoroughly. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) and the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) came in here and made speeches that could have been prepared from within the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services or, if not from within the Department, from the office of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe). It reflects poorly on those members that they did not check the facts beforehand.

The present Minister was invited by me nearly two years ago when he first took office to adhere to the principle that the Opposition was not in this for politicking but for the interests of the disabled and that the Government should pick up these amendments and talk about these things in a calm and comfortable fashion. That offer has not been taken up. Why is it that now, two years later, we have rushed into this House a series of amendments—some of which follow our suggestions—without any time to debate them?

If the Minister, the Government and those in the Department consider this to be social justice for those people who are estranged and in most need of care, then I think they ought to redefine social justice. The two members of the Government who have spoken tonight talked of social justice and equity—a fair return from an inequitable society. They are the people who have denied social justice to these most needy persons within the community. They have denied it in many ways.

They talk of the number of people who have been helped through the programs to date. They do not talk about the number of people who have not been helped. Unfortunately, as medicine improves and society's expectations grow, we will have more of these disadvantaged people within the community to look after, yet the program has been administered—as good as the Act was—by people who have no reaction and no feeling for what happens out in society; in other words, they are not grassroot operators. They are people who are secure in the Public Service, in a secure job with the Department, but who know nothing or very little about the reaction of people out in the workplace.

It horrifies me to think that the Minister and the people within the Department who are making these decisions are on record as saying in some cases that they do not know what a sheltered workshop is about; they have never visited one. That is the absolute truth and I can verify that; I would not say it unless it were the truth. During my time as a shadow Minister, I continually went around and saw what happened within the sheltered workshops and the efforts of the volunteers who are doing their best.

The people within the industry who stand over the providers and authorise the payments and adjudicate the contracts have never had their fingers soiled. In fact, it would not be a bad idea for public servants to have a two-year leave of absence from the security of their jobs so that they can get out into the workplace and find out how the industry works. If they did, they would understand the stress on an industry provider who has been denied a contract or who has been contracted only for 12 months. They are subject to guidelines which are so flexible they change from one moment to another. It is on record that programs have been approved within the period of a month or two months only to be rescinded by the same people who approved them or to be discovered in Canberra that permission was not granted. It was not granted on the basis that the program was not good enough; it was disregarded on the basis that the funds were not available within the Department for that particular allocation of the program because too much was taken up in other areas.

I take umbrage at the suggestion that the Opposition would defund the programs. How that assumption was made really beats me. We have said in Fightback that the two areas in which there will be unaltered financing are aged care and disability services. We have gone further: we have said that any savings effected within the administration of the Department would be returned to the services, not used in some way to reimburse the Treasury, which is functioning at this moment with a severe deficit.

To make those two suggestions—firstly, that we are playing politics with the aged and, secondly, that we would defund the programs—is quite mischievous and misrepresents the situation. It is interesting to note that the two honourable members who made those allegations are no longer in the chamber. I believe those two speeches were prepared within the Minister's office.

It is time that the Australian people saw disability services for what they are. It is an opportunity for each of us to consider those people who have a disability and to do something about it. It is interesting to note that this Saturday McDonald's is conducting a nationwide fundraising campaign the proceeds of which will go back to disabled children. In that regard, I think it is worthy of the assistance of all Australians.

It is true that not only have these amendments been on the public record in this House for the last 18 months to two years, but also they have been thoroughly canvassed by people in the field. It is interesting to note that one of the honourable members who spoke tonight—the honourable member for Lilley—is on record as having attacked the work of the volunteers from the Endeavour Foundation in Queensland. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Johns), who is at the table, might indicate whether I am incorrect, but I believe he is also on record as having attacked some of those voluntary organisations.

I think it is time that we came to realise that these people should not be subject to the politics of the day. They should be given some security, and the amendments we proposed were in that vein. The Act has been in place for five years, and for five years the Government has said that there should not be any changes. Yet for five years we have been waiting for guidelines, the laying down of principles. None have come before the House. This is only because the Minister and his Department have sought to use them as a flexible way of funding some programs and not others.

The Minister has already said that he would not defund any of the sheltered workshops. That is not true. A sheltered workshop within my area was defunded and could remain in funding only by going to an alternative program under HACC. Yet the organisation which was funded in its place is draining scarce dollars from the other organisation's pocket and also that of another organisation in the same region.

I think it is time for this Parliament to operate as the auditor of the affairs of the Department. I believe those guidelines should come before this Parliament, not as regulations which have to be approved or disapproved in total, but as guidelines which can be debated to show the people of Australia that we in this Parliament do consider that there has to be some social justice for those people out there—and social justice includes being able to get a fair deal from the Department and the Minister of the day.

We have laid down in the amendments, which we will be debating later on, the need for guidelines to come before this House because we have not had any for five years. I ask the people within the Department: why has it taken five years to set down the guidelines?

We have been beseeched to not include in those amendments the laying down of the program for sheltered workshops. Do honourable members know why we are doing that? It is because the Government has come to us at this late stage, with no guidelines laid down and without any idea of where it is going, and said, `Trust us; we'll do these things'. As far as the Opposition is concerned, we have given too much trust to the Government in the administration of this Act.

It has been said by somebody that if he were writing a history of the Disability Services Act of Australia, he would claim that it was the most mismanaged Act of any Act within the Commonwealth. That speaks for itself. Why should we not have the parliamentary purview of it? Why should we not have an appeals mechanism? Why should we not have certain contracts? Only at this late stage have we removed the threat of transition by June 1992. That stress has been playing on many of the clients in Australia, many of the advocates, many of the parents and many of the industries which service this disability area.

In the limited time I have left I would like to say that I believe the services function only because of some well meaning and well trained volunteers in the field who have changed with the times. They now provide a service in Australia—not because of the DSA, but because of themselves—which is superior to anywhere else in the world. It is not a time for us to be bogged down in the pedantics of the Department, making decisions on which it does not follow through. That is why we have proposed our amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments are almost a replica of the amendments we laid on the table in this House about three weeks ago just to keep our position on the Notice Paper and to keep faith with the providers and the clients of disability services in Australia. They are complete, except for one matter which has been taken up by the Government in the form of the transition date being extended beyond 1992. We had suggested that the extension be granted in various phases to 1997. The allegation was made in the debate on the second reading that we had done this with a view to turning back the clock for a century as far as disability services are concerned.

PARA.TAB: I readily remember that, when we suggested an extension of the transition date, we did it with the view that there should be a discipline within the Act to maintain the pressure on people to try to bring these clients to a level or standard of service to which they could aspire. We did not suggest at that time that the transition date was there as a protection, a cover or security for those people who did not want to change.

We were quite specific on that, and that is why we chose a date of transition so that the services would still have the pressure on them to raise the quality and standard of the service for the individual client who could aspire to something better. On this occasion the Government has said that it will remove the transition date and impose as a form of discipline a monitoring of the outcomes, yet we have not seen specific guidelines for these outcomes. However, if the Government chooses to remove the transition date, the Opposition finds nothing wrong with that. I just wanted to stress yet again that we were not letting the service providers off the hook completely; we want them to be able to assimilate that action over a longer period.

The other aspect of these amendments is specifically to formulate guidelines. Right at the commencement, the Minister was to formulate guidelines and set out the principles and the ambitions that he and the Department had for disability services. As I have said, we have seen an abuse of that principle, because the guidelines have been so flexible that they have changed from one month to another and approvals have changed from one person to another. We are suggesting that the guidelines should be cemented within the legislation of this Parliament, and not by regulation, which gives the Parliament only two options—

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill, incorporating a number of changes to tariff rates, many of which have been introduced by customs tariff proposals. It includes the imposition of a proposed $12,000 per vehicle tariff on second-hand car imports. Because the Government cannot manage its own legislative program, just as it has not managed to run the country over the last few years, I will not have time tonight to debate many of the changes proposed by this Bill, particularly as one amendment proposed by the Government represents a major shift in policy. That change—the proposed $12,000 additional tariff on imported used cars—deserves a full debate by itself.

PARA.TAB: Before moving on to that part of the Bill, however, I will quickly skip through the coalition's position on some of the amendments. We support the full extension of the automotive export facilitation scheme to component producers so that they can use export credits directly. The coalition, I might say, is not a member of the facilitation cheer squad, exactly. In fact, it is my view that, whilst encouraging exports, the scheme is also equally encouraging imports and that some Australian part manufacturers will disappear as a result of the scheme. But we consider that, as it is in place, it should be allowed to continue and wind down in tandem with the tariff cuts.

Secondly, the proposal to allow state-of-the-art capital equipment to enter Australia duty free is welcome—and a welcome recognition of the costs imposed on producers by the tariff system. The same principle is apparent in amendments which allow all aircraft parts, materials and test equipment for use in the manufacture, repair and the maintenance of the same to be imported duty free. In addition, there is duty free entry of certain chemicals and textile fabric for use in chemicals, plastics and bookbinding industries, and that will assist these sectors to become internationally competitive.The tariff on a number of steel products will be reduced from 10 to 5 per cent to ensure that Australian producers have access to competitively priced steel in the wake of BHP's takeover of New Zealand Steel.

These changes, if nothing else, demonstrate how greatly the edifice of protection has hindered rather than helped many of our industries to become world competitive, and demonstrate precisely why we must continue to phase down all tariffs and other protective structures for all industries.

Schedule 3 of the principal Act is amended to redefine off-road and passenger vehicles. The new criteria are supposed to be more straightforward, but they will mean that more vehicles attract higher duty rates of 35 per cent. The coalition requests that these changes be monitored to ensure that genuine commercial vehicles are not subject to the passenger motor vehicle rate of duty. A number of other changes in the Bill are essentially housekeeping: the insertion of tender quota rates for duty for TCF goods for the final year of quotas, the lifting of the so-called footwear price line, and an amendment to ensure that the same duty is paid on the so-called short pack bicycles as complete bicycles.

As a result of the tragic situation in Yugoslavia, changes have also been made to the developing country schedules, not without some problems, which I understand the Government intends to rectify in another place. The coalition has circulated an amendment which makes it absolutely clear that the former Yugoslavian republic known as Macedonia has not been recognised as an independent state of that name. My colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) will elaborate on this part of the Bill in his remarks.

Finally, I come to the proposed additional $12,000 per vehicle tariff on second-hand motor vehicles. The coalition regards this part of the Bill very seriously; the Government clearly does not, giving me realistically not more than five minutes or so to debate this Bill, or this part of it at least. This decision seemed simply to come out of the blue last December. There was no consultation with anybody as far as we can gather. No information was provided so that we and other people could make a proper judgment—absolutely nothing.

The coalition and the car buying public—or not so car buying public these days because cars are expensive and the public are broke—are presumably meant to meekly and mutely accept this new arrangement. On the basis of such contemptuous treatment alone, the measure should be opposed. But the coalition has spent a lot of time since the announcement trying to ascertain some facts on which to make a response. All we found was that nobody in government or the industry has done the work to find out whether such a measure should be introduced. We believe, therefore, that the Government should agree to hold a full Industry Commission inquiry to look at all aspects of the issue before any action is taken.

I remind the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, that this is what the Government is required to do under its own legislation—the Industry Commission Act, section 10, subsection (1). We all know that this subsection does not render tariff changes illegal, but certainly the imposition of a $12,000 tariff flouts the spirit of the law which was intended to ensure that decisions were based on the facts and that people had an opportunity to put their view. Senator Button is apparently unmoved. He is on record as saying that he would increase the $12,000 tariff if it proved inadequate to stop these imports. That is all very macho of him, but it does not make for cool decision making.

We are asking for no more than is required by the Government's own law. There are a number of matters that need to be clarified on this issue before anybody can make a sensible decision on the matter. First, whether car registration and arrangements for road worthiness in Japan accelerate the depreciation of older vehicles, thus depressing their resale value, and the extent perhaps of any effective subsidy involved to the Japanese car producers; second, the potential impact of second-hand imports on the Australian automotive industry most certainly needs to be looked at; third, the potential impact on car prices, car safety and car emissions; fourth, the impact on Australian consumers; fifth, whether imported used cars under the current arrangements meet all the design, safety and consumer requirements imposed on local producers and dealers; sixth, whether the import of used cars from Japan creates value-adding jobs in Australia; and, finally, whether the import of used cars from Japan is likely to replace new cars from Australia or, perhaps more likely, old cars from Australia or even new cars from Japan. Who knows the answers to these questions?

Most certainly the Government does not know. Most certainly the Department did not know in the Senate Estimates hearings on this subject. Our senators asked questions of the Department, and gave the Department ample opportunity to provide information at those hearings last month. Quite frankly, the replies from the Minister's Department were quite pathetic. I will read from Hansard of 9 April. It states:
SENATOR BISHOP—. . . you have done a study of what happened across the Tasman in New Zealand. I wonder whether you could tell me when that work was done.
Dr Bell—My comments were really just intended to help the Committee. There was no study done . . . I was simply informing the Committee of the situation of which we are aware.
SENATOR BISHOP—Dr Bell, you said, `We found when we looked across the Tasman'. If you found it, presumably you did a study. Did you?
Dr Bell—No, you just have to look, Senator. You do not have to do a study.

SENATOR BISHOP—. . . What I would like you to go and find out for me, Dr Bell . . . is who compiled a report which may or may not have contained information from the Department of Commerce in New Zealand. Was it a result of an inquiry from DITAC? What date did this occur and what was done with the information?
Dr Bell—Nobody made a visit. There was no report. We have a file with some information on it that has come in from various sources, including the Department of Commerce.

SPEECH.PARA: The written responses to questions taken on notice are even more revealing. Amongst other things they said:

There has been no detailed analysis of the relative impact on balance of payments, employment or value-adding of importing a new Mazda compared to imposing a second-hand Mazda . . . Given that the actual level of all future imports—
of second-hand cars—
could not be identified precisely, a detailed cost benefit analysis could not be undertaken .
Yet it was said:
The Government considered that, on the strength of information available—
what little there was—
to it there was sufficient reason to know before an unmanageable problem arose.

In other words, the decision was made on a large polyglot of statistical vapour, a factual vacuum: plenty of emotion and no facts. Whilst we are on the subject of facts, I might say that the accuracy of the facts that we have been presented with from the automotive industry sadly, I have to say, leave much to be desired. The only documentary evidence available has been supplied by the importer, Taiyo Corporation, which shows an FOB value ex Japan for Mazda Capellas of around $2,200, freight of $1,000, duty and sales tax of $1,300 and modification costs to comply with ADRs in this country of around $3,000, a total of some $7,500.

PARA.TAB: I think that there has been shaky reasoning, but that is not the only problem. There is no reason blindly to assume that what has happened in New Zealand would happen here. We have a completely different range of Australian design rule compliance procedures which are not imposed in New Zealand. I am concerned that the Department itself may be releasing misleading information about the number of used cars currently entering Australia, and I would ask the Minister to provide details to the House of the numbers of high volume used cars that are coming in. I would also ask him to explain the definitions of high volume and low volume. There is no definition in the Bill and there seem to be a few variations floating around.

There is also the question mark about the timing of the $12,000 tariff announcement. Apparently the day that the Taiyo Corporation complied with all of the things that were requested of it was the day on which this announcement was made. We want to know the facts. We really want to know as well, as I mentioned before, whether any of the arrangements in Japan effectively subsidised its exports of new and/or old cars into this country. It might be useful to know.

We want to know whether such imports might reduce the age of the Australian car park, where the average age of the private fleet is currently running at 17 years. Surely this information is absolutely essential. I therefore urge the Minister to withdraw the relevant amendments in this Bill and agree to a full inquiry.

Overall, the coalition will not oppose this Bill. But if the Government does not agree to an inquiry into the second-hand car issue, I will be moving an amendment—that is, if we can have a committee stage—to delete all reference to the additional $12,000 per vehicle tariff.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992 contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Schedule 1 is operative from 1 July 1990 and subtracts the customs duty component from the New Zealand rate of duty for tobacco products of chapter 24—an amendment to that part. The amendment is made in the context of Australia's obligations under the 1988 closer economic relations protocol.

PARA.TAB: Schedules 2, 3 and 4 contain amendments to concessional items in schedule 4 of the principal Act. In particular, schedule 2, which will operate from 1 January 1991, amends item 41A. This will allow motor vehicle component manufacturers to directly use import credits which they earn under the motor vehicle export facilitation scheme.

Schedule 3 will have effect from 12 March 1991. Item 56 will allow certain capital equipment which is technologically more advanced, efficient or productive than equipment available from Australian manufacture to be imported duty free. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) said, that certainly makes sense; it is a very good move.

Schedule 4 will take effect from 1 October 1991. The provisions of item 31 have been expanded to allow all aircraft parts, materials and test equipment for use in the manufacture, repair and maintenance of aircraft to be imported duty free. The only exceptions are goods which are used for servicing aircraft. Again, this affirms our objective to develop and maintain an international competitiveness for Australia's aerospace manufacturing and aviation industries.

The sunset clause has also been removed from item 36B, which allows certain chemicals to be imported duty free for specific end users. Item 57 has been created to allow certain chemicals and textile fabric to be imported duty free when used in the chemicals, plastics, bookbinding and allied industries. This action will also assist the international competitiveness of these industries.

Certainly item 57 is important to me. I have a very successful company in my electorate in Bundaberg known as the Bundaberg Bag Co., which is doing extremely well. This item will allow it to be more competitive in using some of these products and to value add and sell the finished product not only to the Australian market but also to the expanding Asian market. Indeed, I was very pleased to discuss with the management of the company only recently the output and the way in which the company is going economically. I am pleased to say that, in 14 years of operation, the last quarter is the best quarter that it has ever had, and that will make a great contribution to management's understanding of and cooperation with all its employees from management down and the progressive and loyal way in which it puts Australian industry and, particularly, Bundaberg first.

Changes to schedule 3 of the principal Act involve the treatment of motor vehicles. The definitions of off-road and passenger motor vehicles in additional notes 4 and 5 to chapter 87 have been amended. Item 57 in schedule 4 has been altered, expanding the range of raw materials and intermediate goods available as duty free imports for the chemicals, plastics, bookbinding and allied industries. As I said, this creates a more competitive market for our manufacturers and producers.

Schedule 8 will operate from 1 July 1992. It concerns the duty on cold-rolled and clad, plated or coated and flat-rolled steel products of tariff headings 7209, 7210, 7211 and 7212. They will be reduced from 10 to 5 per cent. For specified products this represents an acceleration of the phasing down of general tariffs announced in the 1991 industry statement. The tariff rates for goods from Hong Kong, the Republic of Korea, Singapore and Taiwan province will be maintained at 5 per cent in line with measures also announced in the industry statement. We all recognise that these Asian tigers certainly do not need the preference they had in the past.

There is one controversial aspect in regard to both our side of the House and the Opposition side. That is in regard to the imposition of a duty of $12,000 per vehicle in addition to the duty already in place in relation to high volume imports of used or second-hand passenger motor vehicles. There is a concern—I know that the previous speaker touched on it, but not with the same point of view—which I certainly share, about the high volume of imports of motor vehicles from Japan through the importer Taiyo Corporation. In my view, and in the Government's view, that would flood the Australian market and cause massive dislocation of the Australian motor vehicle industry.

I do not think people in Japan would be able to quibble, given the high tariffs they have in industries such as the rice industry. I think that, by putting the Australian motor vehicle industry first, we have done the right thing. I know from speaking to the dealers in my area that they are very supportive of that fact. They have indicated to me that it is the best thing we have ever done for the motor vehicle industry. I will conclude now because of the time limitations and because there are other members who wish to speak on this Bill. I am hopeful that the Opposition will support these Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —My purpose was originally to speak against the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, inasmuch as it would have granted de facto recognition by Australia of the former so-called Yugoslav republic of Macedonia. I am extremely pleased that, following my letter to the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall), the Minister has seen the error of his ways and decided to amend his own amendments. In sum, although it may be embarrassing for him, the Minister has had to make arrangements to ensure that Australia does not grant recognition to a former Yugoslav republic such as Macedonia in an underhanded and unjust way.

PARA.TAB: The said amendments would have had Australia, for the purposes of its customs procedures, incorrectly treat so-called Macedonia as an official political entity. It would have bestowed upon the former republic centred on Skopje the same status as that enjoyed by other former Yugoslav republics, such as Croatia, Slovenia and Bosnia-Herzegovina. Essentially, these amendments sought to pre-empt any officially completed diplomatic procedure and/or Government decision to grant recognition.

This House knows well that, largely on a bipartisan basis, Australia grants recognition only after both a careful analysis of a given country's fulfilment of the internationally accepted criteria and a thorough assessment of our own national interests. To the great disappointment of many, this norm was completely deviated from by the content of these customs amendments, which took it on themselves to grant recognition by virtue of bureaucratic fine print rather than established practice and public debate. Clearly, these amendments were procedurally wrong. They were also in direct contravention of the public policies of both the Government and the Opposition—policies determined to protect Australia's national interests.

Perhaps unbeknown to the Minister at the time, both the Government and the Opposition have outlined the parameters for the recognition of the former Yugoslav republic in question. Firstly, the name issue must be resolved by the Skopje leadership. The usage of the term `Macedonia' by it creates tension in the region and does not bode well for the neighbourly cooperation its young state would need. Secondly, Greece's real concerns about future territorial claims on its northern province must be resolved by Skopje. Thirdly, Skopje must satisfy the international community on the question of protection of ethnic minorities such as the Albanians.

From my own perspective, I believe that there is an overwhelming historical case to be made against Skopje's use of the name Macedonia and overwhelming foreign policy arguments in favour of standing by our long-time ally Greece, with which we have such strong political and cultural ties. As I have said before and will continue to shout from the mountain tops, Macedonia was Greek, is Greek, and should remain Greek. I am grateful that I have been able to play a small role to ensure it.

It is difficult for me, however, to surmise why the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs would have tried to slip in this de facto recognition of an entity called Macedonia against both the tide of established practice and our policy approach. I do not know whether the Minister was poorly briefed, too busy to read his own legislation or just plain incompetent; or whether he did not read the fine print of the amendments prepared for him by the Government bureaucrats and inadvertently let the recognition of `Macedonia' slip past, or did not bother to check with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) as to his own Government's position on the question of the recognition of the former Yugoslav socialist republic.

In a letter to me today the Minister claims that Macedonia is added in this legislation under the section dealing with places, not independent countries. Sadly for his argument, however, the three other additions as so-called places rather than independent countries are Croatia, Slovenia and Bosnia-Herzegovina, all three of which have been recognised by Australia as independent countries. Why put Macedonia in this group unless it is an attempt to subvert the process and admit recognition of Macedonia by backdoor means? Or does this nonsense mean that the true Macedonia—the northern province of Greece—should be treated as an independent developing country?

Whatever the reason, the fact that these amendments came before this House and are to be corrected only at the eleventh hour remains unchanged and is unpardonable. It is an example of truly bad law making. The Minister is responsible for nearly sneaking by us all a foreign policy blunder. He may well have committed our Government to major embarrassment overseas and perhaps even worse consequences.

With the proposed changes, the Government only suffers the deserved disdain of all Australians. The Minister should be brought to account for what has nearly happened and nearly tragically transpired in this House. I call on him to immediately and publicly state how these amendments came to be in the first place and why they were allowed by him to proceed so far down the track. If he tries to put the blame on his public servants he must answer why he is being run by the bureaucrats rather than doing his job and running them. Contrary to what his Government would like to think, he cannot fool all the people all the time.

Sadly, because of time constraints imposed by this Labor Government, I cannot go into this matter more deeply at present, but I will certainly take the opportunity to do so on a later occasion. I wholeheartedly support the coalition's amendments which are to be moved in the committee stage, the first of which will omit the word `Macedonia' and substitute the words `the former Yugoslavian republic known as Macedonia'. This amendment, together with two other amendments to be moved by the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), have my wholehearted and complete support.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been mentioned, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992 is designed to cover a number of issues, some of which have been referred to by previous speakers. First, I wish to refer to the amendment under schedule 7, operative from 1 April 1992, which amends the definition of an off-road vehicle. This is an attempt by the Government to be more specific, considering how many vehicles of ordinary passenger style are four-wheel drive. Considering the additional safety that these sorts of vehicles provide, it seems a pity that they will be taxed at higher rates.

PARA.TAB: The real point that strikes me is that the Government is still grappling with the definition of a four-wheel drive for duty purposes. It still grapples with it for sales tax purposes. I guess any of us who have any remote association with fishing communities in particular know that there has been a constant outrage from fishermen that they are denied the right to sales tax exemption on four-wheel drive vehicles while those on farming properties, which I also represent, have had that right.

This is in stark contrast with the circumstances that will apply when the coalition is in government and its Fightback policy applies. It will not matter then—be they fishermen, small businessmen, farmers or anybody else who is a registered GST taxpayer—because they will pay no wholesale sales tax on these sorts of vehicles since it will not apply. By the year 2000 they will pay no customs duty on these vehicles—this legislation is still struggling with that—and they will pay no GST because they will be able to deduct it from their collections.

I want to stress the word `collections'. When addressing the responsibilities of the business community under the GST there is too much talk about what they will pay. They will pay nothing. They will collect taxation in the course of their business and they will deduct from that any amounts that they have paid. As there would normally be a surplus, they will send the balance to the Commissioner of Taxation.

It is interesting that, whilst the Government still struggles with a new definition of a four-wheel drive, it is certainly not the first for Customs purposes. They will not be problems under the proposals that will be put forward by the coalition when it is in government. I am sure that will be of considerable interest.

Secondly, I refer to schedule 8, operative from 1 July 1992, which phases down tariffs on certain vegetables, including potatoes. There is no opposition to this proposal from this side of the House. I am reminded—and I think it is worth putting on the record—that we heard the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at Question Time today screaming off again the list of the various achievements of his Government from time to time.

However, he overlooked the fact that these proposals were frequently opposed by the Australian Democrats and supported by the Opposition. In other words, we gave him the opportunity to achieve reform in this country in areas that we thought were appropriate and proper—something which, from my recollection of the period that I sat in this House in government, he never afforded us once. The question was never the national good; the question was always: how much can I screw out of this politically? It was interesting to note, in terms of excise and customs duty, his original reaction when certain additional taxes on fuel were opposed. He accused us of making every bowser a tax collector and later refused to lower excise when there was a substantial drop in the international price of fuel to which a certain number of those excises were paralleled.

It is a fact that the Opposition parties will give support whenever it is appropriate to measures of this nature. I have within my electorate a number of potato growers and a processing works called Southern Processes—it is just outside my electorate—which services potato and pea growers. They come to me constantly complaining about the level of import competition they are now receiving from New Zealand. It is not a matter of considerable concern because I would imagine that under the CER arrangements these tariffs in their reduced form would not apply to the trade that we have with New Zealand under CER. However, it is worthy of note that those people complain to me that they are having severe competition from the New Zealanders because their waterfront is more efficient and their currency is of a lower value. They are, in fact, more efficient producers.

This is interesting because we hear from day-to-day in this place what a dreadful place New Zealand is. We hear that the New Zealand work force is being ground into the ground. Yet New Zealand's Statistician has just announced that real wages have grown by 1.3 per cent. This is how tough things are for the New Zealand work force under the new arrangements: it is getting real increases in wages, confirmed by its own Statistician. We also read recently that the New Zealanders have just achieved their first trade surplus for 20 years. It was only $80m but, when one compares that with a typical Australian trade deficit of $700m, $800m, $1,000m and $1,200m, it appears that they are doing something right over there.

The honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) referred to the Government's attempts to impose a duty on the import of second-hand cars. In fact, it had nothing to do with imposing a duty on the import of second-hand cars; it was just a crude mechanism to determine that it did not happen. I have had representations on this matter over a couple of years and on every occasion the people concerned seemed very determined to do things properly. They have never argued that they should not have to meet Australian design rules. They were treated very flexibly originally and the Government obviously thought that it could keep to its principle of low tariffs. I think that at that stage the Prime Minister was arguing for the abolition of tariffs altogether. That is my recollection of what he said on the John Laws radio show. That was one of his principal platforms. The Government clearly did not want the embarrassment of being found, at a time when its rhetoric was all built around minimal or no tariffs, to be applying a tariff to second-hand cars, so it threw the Australian design rules book at these importers and the net result was that most of them gave up.

Members of this group, some of whom reside in Western Australia, did the right thing. They are people I have known, the Moores. In fact, I remember them when they were involved in the whaling industry in Carnarvon. They had the testing and everything done. They were able to prove that at least one of these vehicles could be imported.

There is another interesting aspect of this. They were basically offering a low cost, low mileage, relatively young, second-hand vehicle at a very reasonable price. I would have thought that the people most interested in such a vehicle would be those on salaries substantially below average weekly earnings—those people who traipse off every morning to those sorts of jobs and regularly vote Labor when the elections come around. I would have thought that if any government was interested in this particular proposal—considering its constituency and its needs to get reasonably priced transport—it would have been the present Labor Government. I would have thought that it genuinely wanted people to be able to purchase cars at a reasonable price. Here is a once in a lifetime opportunity.

From my observations, because of the very nature of Japan and the concentration of vehicles, cars spend more time on idle than at speed. That is what makes them very low mileage and very under-utilised cars. They should be able to be imported to Australia. This Government, having attempted to avoid this situation of imposing a tariff, was confronted by people who met its other requirements. It has now turned around and will impose a flat $12,000 duty on each of these cars—it does not matter what it is.

The honourable member for Barker has quite properly raised concerns about this. We want to know what real effect it might have on the industry and a few other things in this regard. It is quite improper to bring this proposal to the Parliament without some consideration. Most importantly, it is quite improper for the people of Wills and the people of the Deputy Speaker's electorate to tell them that this opportunity will be denied them, as will cheap petrol. Those opposite do not give an unemployed fellow the opportunity of a cheap motor car and cheap fuel so that he might be able to drive a bit further to look for a job that they have destroyed. The Government does not want to do that; we do, we want to give those people a go. Many of the proposals that we have in our policies will help them.

We will not accept that the Government will deny people this sort of vehicle at that price unless it produces the evidence. The honourable member for Barker was quite correct in demanding that this matter be withdrawn until the Parliament is properly informed of what is going on or whether it is just another call from Bill Kelty or the President of the Vehicle Builders Union saying, `Fix it. Jump—and as high as I tell you'. That is the situation. As there is an agreement for some time to be allowed for discussion in committee, I conclude my remarks at this time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I do not want to delay the House because I have agreed with the shadow Minister for consumer affairs, the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey), that there will be a committee stage.

PARA.TAB: I wish to correct a few points made by the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), particularly in relation to the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia. To correct him, he did not bring this matter to my attention, it was the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr McLeay) and the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton). I clarify the fact that when this proposal was first introduced as from 1 January neither Croatia nor Slovenia was recognised as a country by Australia; they were recognised on 1 March 1992. Bosnia-Herzegovina was recognised by the Government on May 1992. That is why they are in the Bill.

The Government has recognised the fact that there is a degree of sensitivity. No-one understands that more than me as I am married to a Greek and I am very much aware of the sensitivities of the Greek community. I am very pleased that the shadow Minister raised this issue with me. The Government will be moving amendments in the Senate because of the restrictions placed on us by the Macklin amendment. We will also oppose amendments Nos 2 and 3 moved by the Opposition.

The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Schedule 5, page 12, proposed amendment 4 of Schedule 1, omit "Macedonia", substitute "The former Yugoslavian Republic known as Macedonia".
(2)Schedule 8, pages 63-84, amendments 57-64, omit "and $12,000 each" (whenever occurring).
(3)Schedule 8, pages 90-91, omit proposed amendment of Part III of Schedule 4 (new Item 59).

My colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) has spoken eloquently about the first amendment which is to make sure that the wording with regard to the former Yugoslavian republic known as Macedonia is corrected in the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill.

PARA.TAB: The other two amendments really come together and concern the omission of the $12,000 punitive tariff to which we have referred a few times in this debate. It really is quite unconscionable that such a tariff be put on cars. There is absolutely no doubt that it is supposed to be a preventative tariff and that no studies or work have been done on this matter. I have set out a number of points that I hope the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) will take into account. Not the least of these is whether, in doing some of the work in bringing these cars into Australia, the value adding would provide work for Australians; and whether it would mean the removal of old cars from the bottom end—the older end—of the car park, as it is referred to, where cars are 17 years old in the private fleet.

I draw a number of other matters to the Minister's attention, not the least of which is that it is patently obvious that the Government has done no work on this matter. It is simply a knee-jerk reaction. As was pointed out in this debate by a Government speaker not long ago, there have been lots of representations made, of course, by the car industry. However, I might point out that the Automobile Association of Australia, representing 5 1/2 million car drivers, opposes this $12,000 tariff. It is on that basis that I move these three amendments.
Question put:
That the amendments (Mr McLachlan's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
