DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (TARIFF CONCESSIONS AND ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Mr Beddall:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill with Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill implement changes to the tariff concession system, broadly as recommended by the Industry Commission, and also implement changes to anti-dumping and countervailing procedures announced by the Government last December. Overall, the Bill represents an improvement in both these areas, but in the anti-dumping and countervailing areas, in particular, the Government has a long, long way to go to ensure that adequate remedies are available to Australian producers against unfair trading practices. I will come to that part of the Bill later.

PARA.TAB: The first part of the Bill is concerned with the tariff concessions system which allows goods not produced in Australia to be imported free of duty. There have been complaints for many years from local producers that they cannot obtain tariff concession orders to import special equipment duty free because the local manufacturer objects on the ground that he or she could produce the item, or something similar, but seldom manages to produce it.

The proposed changes to the TCO system should make for more balanced decisions where a local producer will have to demonstrate in the future a capacity to produce the items in question. Of course, as protection winds down, the use of the TCOs will also decline.

Specifically, this Bill firstly introduces a new definition of substitutability between goods, replacing the current goods serving similar functions test. Secondly, it provides that where no substitutable goods are produced in Australia in the ordinary course of business, or are produced in the ordinary course of business but the granting of the TCO is not likely to have an adverse impact on the market for these goods, a tariff concession order may be granted. These changes weaken the current tests, thus making it easier to obtain a TCO. Thirdly, the ordinary course of business test is also expanded to ensure that local producers must do more than merely claim they could produce the items in question. For example, they will now need to show that the items have been produced at least two years before the application was lodged or that they have been produced and held in stock and that they are prepared to accept such an order.

The processing time limit of 150 days is introduced. New limited and definitive grounds for the revocation of TCOs are introduced to address concern amongst users of tariff concessions about possible arbitrary revocation. Applications must be lodged by producers who claim to be producers of substitutable goods. The Industry Commission actually recommended the removal of the revocation option and the proposed changes represent a compromise position. The Comptroller is given greater powers to investigate applications for TCOs and applications for revocation.Finally, new internal review mechanisms are established and the so-called merits review process is two-tiered involving, firstly, internal review and, secondly, review by the AAT. These changes, as I mentioned earlier, should make for fairer decisions under the tariff concession system and I sincerely hope they will at least help producers importing specialist capital equipment and parts.

The next part of the Bill implements changes to anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements announced by the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) last December. As far as they go, the changes mostly improve the current arrangements, but they do not go anywhere near far enough. Briefly, the Anti-Dumping Authority Act is amended to allow reviews of measures in place to determine whether the measures should be extended. At least eight months before the new five-year time limit is reached the ADA must publicly announce the forthcoming expiry date and invite interested parties to apply for continuation of the measure within 60 days. The ADA then has 120 days to make a recommendation to the Minister. This measure was proposed by the coalition more than a year ago and its eventual adoption by the Government is welcome.

The life of the ADA is extended until 2001. As well, the Minister, rather than the Comptroller, will now have power to decide whether a processed agricultural food is related closely enough to the raw agricultural goods so as to give the agricultural producer good standing to bring a dumping complaint. Effectively, this change will give the Anti-Dumping Authority the power to review a decision by the Comptroller on this matter.

This amendment flows from the changes made last year for all material injuries suffered by producers of raw materials which are being dumped in a processed form to be taken into account. That move was welcomed by the coalition, but it has been brought to our attention by pork producers that it remains virtually impossible for raw material producers to launch a successful complaint without support from processors. I raise this matter with the Minister so that he is aware, as he may well be, of these concerns and I seek his advice as to whether the changes introduced last year are working adequately and effectively and whether that situation could be reviewed. As well, new procedures are introduced dealing with the lodgment of anti-dumping and countervailing complaints to speed up inquiry times. For example, applications may be faxed. That is a productivity increase which I am sure the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will report to the House tomorrow. We could surely do a little better than that.

We then get to the point about the maximum time period for the processing of claims to the prima facie stage. I notice that the Government is reducing the time from 35 to 25 days. I believe this represents a negligible improvement at best, and it is not good enough. I will be moving an amendment later to bring the prima facie inquiry period into line with the coalition policy—that is, five days.

Under this Bill, Customs is now permitted to use information not contained in the application to determine whether a prima facie case exists. Presumably, this will help to speed up inquiries. However, we are concerned to see that there is a facility for applicants to be advised of just what this other relevant information is. Applications received by the Customs Service must be presented in a way which facilitates rapid processing. This will be achieved via up-front assistance through the customs business liaison units.

The period of time for which a dumping duty notice or countervailing duty notice or an undertaking remains in force is extended from three years to five years—again, in line with longstanding coalition policy. I am glad to see that the Government has taken up this suggestion.

The Act is amended to facilitate findings and remedies in cases where both dumping and subsidisation exist and which jointly are causing material injury. The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992 implements complementary amendments to effect this particular change.

Last year and again in January this year the coalition set out a new anti-dumping and countervailing system. Amongst other things, that system will significantly reduce the inquiry period for anti-dumping and countervailing cases. Five working days will be allotted to determine whether or not a complaint meets formal requirements—whether or not there is a case to answer. If it does, a preliminary investigation of up to 60 days, with provision for up to 30 days extension in special circumstances, will ensue.

After the preliminary investigation, provisional measures will be imposed or undertakings can be accepted if dumping or subsidisation is found. This finding will be either confirmed or rejected in a final investigation of up to 90 days. These changes will ensure a maximum total investigation period of 155 days and 185 days in exceptional circumstances, compared with the current 255 days.

Secondly, we would make the Australian Customs Service responsible for determining whether or not dumping or subsidisation is occurring, whilst the Anti-Dumping Authority would be responsible for determining the extent of material injury. The Customs Service will be responsible for establishing a causal link between the two. These investigations will be conducted concurrently within the proposed investigation time limits, which of course facilitates the closing of these times.

Thirdly, we would help to ensure that the proposed time limits are achieved by implementing procedures to allow exchange of confidential information between representatives of the principal parties—a circumstance which obtains in some parts of the legal system at this time. Fourthly, we would extend the existing three-year sunset period for anti-dumping and countervailing measures to five years, with reviews to be held before the expiry of such measures—a measure which, as I have just said, has now been adopted by the Government.

Fifthly, we would ensure that material injury tests do not require virtual decimation of the local industry before remedial action is considered necessary—which I have to say, under the Government's arrangements to date, has been the case for some time. Sixthly, we would provide adequate human and capital resources to the Australian Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority to facilitate speedy and fully informed determinations. As well, we would simplify the informational requirements imposed upon local complainants, whilst bearing in mind the need to deter vexatious and frivolous complaints.

The coalition is committed to implementing this policy when in government and urges the current Government to do Australian industry a favour and steal all of our policies in full. To assist in this regard, I have circulated a second reading amendment outlining what the Government should do.

I have to say that the Government's history on anti-dumping and countervailing policy is not one that it should be proud of. It has chopped and changed and it is slowly but surely being dragged to foreshorten these procedures so that those complainants have a chance not only to get up an appropriate anti-dumping or countervailing measure but to do so without running out of financial resources beforehand, which is one of the problems that people have when these things take too long, as they do at the present time. The Opposition is offering the Government an opportunity to get it right once and for all. I urge the Government to agree to this amendment which has been circulated in my name. I now move:

That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that, in addition to the amendments to anti-dumping and countervailing procedures contained in the Bill, the Government should move immediately to make the current inadequate procedures faster and more effective:
(1)by reducing the prima facie hearing stage to 5 working days;
(2)by reducing the preliminary inquiry stage to 60 days, thus enabling the imposition of provisional measures after 65 days instead of the current 125 days;

(3)by facilitating much speedier hearings by running parallel inquiries by the Anti-Dumping Authority and the Australian Customs Service into the extent of inquiry and extent of dumping or subsidisation respectively;

SPEECH.PARA: thus ensuring that Australian industries are not immeasurably disadvantaged by unfair trading practices before remedial action is taken'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in seconding the amendment and reserve my right to speak at a later stage.

—This Bill is an omnibus measure and proposes a series of amendments to the Customs Act 1901, the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 and the Customs Tariff Miscellaneous Amendments Act 1987. At the outset I wish to make a couple of very relevant points. Firstly, we are very fortunate that we have an outstanding Customs Service in this country and it should be given full credit. The other point that should be made is that we have one of the fastest and best anti-dumping systems in the world. That goes without saying.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that tonight the Opposition moved an amendment which basically appeals to the National Party which is running away and running scared on zero tariffs. The National Party has been peddling in its own areas the protectionist attitude that has been prevailing upon it for the last hundred years. The McEwenism is still there; the monkey is still on their backs in the bush. This is an attempt to try to placate the League of Rights, the voodoo economists and the tunnel vision backwards regulators who reside particularly in the electorate of the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss)—from where the biggest load of rubbish has come out about the dumping of peanuts and food products.

I would like the honourable member for Wide Bay to set the record straight with clowns like John Cameron, the editor of the South Burnett Times, who has not printed the truth and who would be responsible for the loss of billions of dollars of exports of Australian farm products if his ignorant attitude were instituted. I suggest to those clowns in the National Party in the honourable member's electorate that they tell people the full facts and the truth. The biggest problem we have is getting the message back out to the farmers. There is a challenge on the honourable member for Wide Bay to get the facts out. I am not for one moment saying that he does not tell the truth, but I am saying that he has an obligation to get the message across, because the League of Rights is running a very strong campaign in the South Burnett area and has been getting away with nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jeremy Lee was in your town last week.

—Jeremy Lee is the classic example. The interesting thing is that he does not want the GST either. I find it strange that on one occasion I am in agreement with the League of Rights—the only one ever.

PARA.TAB: A few points need to be made about these amendments. First of all, the attempt to bring the prima facie hearing down to five days from the 25 days that we introduced and, secondly, the proposed reduction to 60 days to reach a preliminary finding. We have put 100 days in the legislation. But I point out at the outset that Australia has a total of 245 days for a final conclusion at the end of the Anti-Dumping Authority's hearings, Canada has 261 days, the United States 280 days and the EC 390 days. Those are the facts. I ask the honourable member for Wide Bay to tell characters like John Cameron that fact. He might print in his paper what the honourable member says, but he will not print what I say.

Under the Opposition's amendment an increased burden would be placed on Australian industry and interested parties to raise the quality and timeliness of applications and submissions. It is like telling the police force it has two days to arrest a bank robber.

Customs experience to date has been that this is unlikely to be achieved. Insufficient time to properly weigh argument is likely to result in frequent rejection of applications because they lack sufficient evidence to justify initiation of inquiries. Can one imagine telling Elliot Ness back in the 1930s that he had a week to catch Al Capone? No consideration has been given in the 60-day proposal, either, for the special circumstance surrounding allegations of subsidisation. These consultations are effectively denied and the proposal would therefore seem to be in contravention of the GATT. That is again something that the National Party does not understand—the general agreement on tariffs and trade. It has been very difficult for us, with our hands tied behind our backs for a long time in this country, fighting overseas while the National Party is ratting and running away and still hiding behind the walls of protection, particularly the Queensland branch of the National Party, which is still supporting protection even today in 1992.

The current 25 days available for this are critical. That is why the period needs to stay at 25 days. At day 60 under the Opposition's proposal, the majority of findings are likely to be negative. Under the GATT rules, interested parties are to be given at least 30 days to make submissions, as well as another seven days to allow for delivery of documents. This leaves 23 calendar days for Customs to make its preliminary finding. It does not leave sufficient time for Customs to conduct on-site verification of responses.

Experience shows that exporter responses are often better prepared, more persuasively argued and more effective in refuting claims made by Australian industry in applications. Customs will therefore be forced to rely on this unverified information to make decisions.

In the absence of a positive preliminary finding, the GATT codes do not permit the imposition of provisional measures. Options available to Customs are therefore to find negatively or not reach a finding and so allow the second stage to operate. If no finding is made, the Opposition's second stage envisages that it will take a further 90 days from the preliminary finding to final finding.

This time frame would permit Customs to undertake its on-site inquiries, which were not possible in the previous 60-day period. The Opposition's proposal means that if this finding is positive, and results in the imposition of dumping duties, Australian industry will have had to wait 155 days rather than the present 125 days. So the Opposition's 60-day proposal will not provide assistance to local industry. It will cost it. I think that is the valid point that needs to be made.

I can only come to the conclusion that the Opposition is proposing this amendment, as I said at the start, to try to placate the National Party, which is terrified of the Liberal Party's scorched earth policy—terrified. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) is chained to the GST—it is like an albatross around his neck—and as he goes around Queensland, he gets put under more and more pressure by the Queensland State branch and certainly the New South Wales State branch. So it is obvious that this amendment is put there to try to hold the line. One cannot hold a line on a false premise. Members of the National Party will never accept zero tariffs; they will never accept the scorched earth policies. At the end of the day they are backward regulators, they are agrarian socialists. They are going to break ranks and start to run away, regardless of the sops that are put to them. Certainly, this is not going to help agriculture. At the end of the day they are going to do what they did in 1987. They have a great history for ratting—that is one thing they do know well—and they will rat again on this occasion.

In conclusion, we have a very dedicated team of people in Customs. We should be very proud of them. I am disappointed by the nonsense and rhetoric from people like Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee, who have spread misinformation on trade over the last two years, particularly in the last 12 months. That is un-Australian and it disadvantages Australian farmers. What all farmers want to know is the truth and the facts. The facts are: 245 days; in Europe, 390 days; in America, if a person wants to lodge an anti-dumping claim, that person needs 10 tonnes of paper and is still sent back and told it is not enough information—and $1m to boot.

The problem is that the protectionists are still trying to use this as a means of holding up barriers that have cost us in the past. If all politicians told the truth on this matter and put Australian agriculture first, and told the clowns, the ratbags and the League of Rights the facts, we would not have these problems. And the Leader of the Liberal Party would not have to bring in a ridiculous amendment, which is not practical and will not work, just to please the backward regulators in the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the dumping of various products on the Australian market has, in recent years, emerged as a highly controversial issue. A number of well publicised cases have served to illustrate the dimensions of the problems and the detrimental impact that dumping has had on a wide range of domestic industries.

PARA.TAB: The Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill and the cognate Bill, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill, are an improvement but they need to go further, as the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) has indicated. While most people are familiar with such highly publicised instances as the dumping of primary products, such as bananas, tomatoes, orange juice concentrate, dried apricots, canned peaches and so on, they are often unaware of the manufactured goods which are also dumped on the Australian market, often with devastating effect on the local industry.

There is no doubt that over the years Australia's trading fortunes have suffered enormously from the cumulative impact of our failure to control dumping and the disastrous consequences of the nation's structural uncompetitiveness, particularly its antiquated industrial relations system. The causes of the nation's slide into poverty are not difficult to identify. In addition to the ones already mentioned, they include high transport costs, communication and power costs, high business input taxes, high costs of capital, poor labour relations and low productivity, an inward focus encouraged by decades of protection and pervasive anti-business and anti-development attitudes.

The Business Council of Australia estimates that these major structural impediments cost Australians more than $40 billion each year, while businesses cost between 20 and 25 per cent higher than the nation's overseas competitors. This figure includes the impact of much of the government sector burden on business—payroll tax, wholesale tax, excessive and complex regulations, wasted expenditure and the estimated 10 per cent cost disadvantage caused by protracted environmental approval procedures.

Against this background of a hostile business environment, most local primary producers and manufacturers are in no position to defend themselves against the onslaught of dumped and subsidised products from overseas competitors. It is hardly surprising, therefore, that in these circumstances the time and cost involved in mounting a dumping case is, in all but a few instances, absolutely prohibitive, and the present system still favours the people dumping products on the Australian market. Who is in a position to challenge them? Certainly not the huge number of primary producers and small businesses that are most effective. Clearly, their resources are limited and most are directed to the day to day cost of just staying in business. In contrast, the importers' problems are negligible; they have only to handle the finished goods and a couple of invoices.

In the context of this debate, however, a more serious problem is that of the bureaucracy and the governments generally—particularly this one over the last 10 years. The problem is that, irrespective of the effects of its decision on business, the bureaucracy will continue to exist even if all products are imported and nothing is produced in Australia. It is my contention that, if Australian industry and the nation's primary producers are to survive, the decision-makers in the bureaucracy should not be even-handed. They should err on the side of local industry. Australia needs legislation and regulations which are fair and which protect local industries from the unfair competition of dumped goods from overseas.

Australia needs to establish a situation and an attitude that care for Australian industries and recognise the problems that ensue when local producers are faced with unethical competition from overseas competitors. In this context, I believe that there are four main areas worthy of consideration. Firstly, I would place the onus of proof on the importer by having the goods withdrawn from sale until the importer proves that they are not being dumped; secondly, when the goods are imported, documentation must also indicate that the Australian design standards of safety, quality and performance are adhered to; thirdly, packaging and labelling requirements need to be strengthened; and, finally, all primary products imported into Australia should comply with Australian quarantine regulations.

I believe that the adoption of these important provisions would do much to assist those Australian businesses threatened by unfair competition from dumping. At present, under current legislation, the Government has implemented a two-tier system involving Customs and the Anti-Dumping Authority. As the system operates, the Australian Customs Service screens all complaints within a statutory time and determines whether a prima facie case exists. In the event that a prima facie case does exist, Customs investigates the case further and makes a preliminary finding. If there is a positive preliminary finding the case is transferred to the Anti-Dumping Authority, which then conducts an inquiry and makes a recommendation to the Minister. The official time taken in dealing with each case amounts to 270 days, or nine months.

Meanwhile, the affected industry is hardly in a position to withstand the economic consequences of continued importation, particularly since during the time taken to investigate each case the importer is not placed in a position of responsibility. Indeed, it is the Australian industry which has to prove the case of material injury while the importer may continue to import goods under countervailing conditions, or continue to dump goods on the Australian market to the detriment of the local producer.

I imagine it will come as no surprise to honourable members to learn that in the European Community the time taken to prove a dumping case is only a matter of days. During 1990 there was much publicity surrounding the importation and marketing of primary products which contravened the Anti-Dumping Act. The consequential destruction, or at best weakening, of various Australian industries received much publicity. The citrus industry is one case which has been on the verge of collapse for some time. Not surprisingly, this industry is facing impossible difficulties due to the importing of orange juice concentrate. Other instances involve the importation of frozen potatoes, canned asparagus and pork. Unlabelled canned peaches from Greece and unlabelled canned pears from China are two other examples. Australian industry, by world comparison, is often vulnerable due to its size and the relatively small capacity of the Australian domestic market.

As a result, when a product is dumped or brought in under countervailing conditions—that is, subsidised in the country of origin—the Australian production is placed in a perilous position. In order to support Australian industry, I believe the onus of proof should be reversed so that it is incumbent upon the dumper to prove that dumping has not occurred. At the same time it must be recognised that the time taken to finalise each case is far too long and, irrespective of the time taken, the opportunity exists for an importer to continue importing goods to the detriment of the local producer.

Australian industry does not, and should not, rely on tariffs or import quotas as a form of protection. Therefore, another form of preserving our industries must be implemented urgently. Under the coalition's Fightback program the delays would be minimal, as the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) has already indicated. Moreover, I would argue that all imports should meet the Australian standards. Consumers in Australia must have confidence in the quality of all products and goods purchased in Australia, whether they are produced locally or imported.

In general, Australian standards are quite high and are the result of a consideration of international standards as well as domestic requirements. However, we must be constantly aiming for the competitive edge in quality, and that includes cost. Australian standards are compromised when poor quality imports impact on the local market. Living standards are threatened, while unfair competition from cheap, subsidised, poor quality imports is hardly in the nation's interest.

With respect to the question of packaging and labelling, Australian consumers have quite justifiably demanded more truth in labelling in recent years—a trend I fully support. However, there still exists the opportunity for ambiguity and deception. Let me illustrate my point simply with the example which concerns orange juice concentrate.

The current regulations permit the contents to be labelled as `Product of Australia' when in fact it is only the water that is Australian. In reality, there are some importers who use their own brands and have been known to supply mischievous or misleading information. When both the product and its package are totally Australian, the label should state that.

On the other hand, if any portion of the contents are packaged or imported, the following information should be included on the label: an accurate description of the product and a statement of its ingredients; the manufacturer's or processor's name; the importer's name; and the country of origin of the contents. The labelling should be in letters and numerals should be clearly visible and easy to read.

The quarantine code should be an effective means of preventing the dumping of primary products on the Australian market. Regulations must offer an effective system of protection to our own industries so that it will be an uneconomic proposition to dump cheap subsidised goods in Australia that would simply not be warehoused or admitted under quarantine periods. I understand that the GATT agreement prohibits the use of quarantine regulations to control imports. However, the reality is that in some instances the regulations positively favour the importer. It is this aspect of the dumping problem that needs to be addressed.

I was involved in a case last year concerning a local mushroom farm in my electorate of Dunkley. The business imported six containers of production equipment from the UK. It was all steel, manufactured and packaged in the Midlands of the UK, nowhere near a farm or potentially hazardous pests. On inspection at the wharf in Melbourne, timber packaging was discovered. The business was informed that it had to be fumigated at considerable cost. My constituent was in real trouble; he needed the equipment and he had organised installation people. Worst of all, the supervising engineer from the UK had other commitments and could only spare a few days. Many alternatives were offered, all to no avail. My constituent was forced to suffer, and suffer he did.

The absolute farcical situation is that if he had imported mushrooms from a farm in Indonesia that were packed in wood, no fumigation was necessary because it would have contravened GATT and they could have been brought in duty free. These sorts of situations are nonsensical and overtly favour the importer against the Australian producer. The honourable member for Barker has outlined adequate anti-dumping measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1992 propose measures in relation to customs which will be of great interest to the people in my electorate of Oxley, especially the primary producers in the Lockyer Valley. In fact, I am sure that all primary producers will be interested in the measures that are being proposed here tonight. They are also of great interest to the Government.

PARA.TAB: The anti-dumping measures proposed to be put in place are amongst the quickest anti-dumping measures in the world. The time it takes to get a preliminary decision in Australia will be around 125 days, which compares very favourably with between 141 and 186 days in Canada, between 160 and 200 days in the United States and up to 270 days in many of the European Community countries, which have not been referred to by the Opposition here tonight.

The Government has been quick to act on instances of dumping when it has found it occurring. Only last month, the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) took action when canned tomatoes were dumped and subsidised into Australia from Italy, Thailand, China and Spain. This followed the lodgment of a complaint by Australian producers with the Australian Customs Service that the imported tomatoes were damaging the profitability of Australian tomato growers. Within four months of the tomato growers lodging their application for anti-dumping measures, provisional measures were introduced, which is a substantially smaller timeframe than exists in other OECD countries.

These changes follow last year's review of the anti-dumping system by the Federal Government. As a result of this review, the time that the Australian Customs Service has to decide whether dumping allegations warrant investigation has been reduced by 10 days, down from 35 days to 25 days. The proposal of the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) tonight to introduce a timeframe of five days, which obviously would be impossible to achieve, appears to be just another of the Opposition's attempts at one-upmanship such as occurred with its tariff policies.

Following this, Customs will have another 100 days to make a preliminary judgment as to whether dumping has occurred. Finally, the Anti-Dumping Authority will have 120 days to undertake a final inquiry and recommend what dumping duties are to be imposed. Overall, the entire process will take about 245 days from start to finish. Once again, this overall time limit compares very favourably with those that exist in other countries. In Canada, the process takes at least 261 days, in the US it takes at least 280 days and in the European Community countries it takes some 390 days.

The key point is the time taken to reach a preliminary finding. In addition to this reduction in investigation time, the actual length of time that the anti-dumping measures will be in place has been extended from three years to five years. Also, an interested party in a dumping case will be able to make a request to the Anti-Dumping Authority for a continuation of the anti-dumping measures that have been put in place. Such submissions will have to be received by the Authority no later than eight months before the expiry date for the measures in order to ensure that there is sufficient time for an inquiry to be made before the end of the five-year period.

If it is decided that the measures should continue, it will be up to the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs to decide whether the measures are to be of the same type or magnitude. As well as the changes to the anti-dumping procedures that will occur as a result of this Bill, the life of the Anti-Dumping Authority itself will be extended until August 2001.

While the Government has introduced a strong anti-dumping framework, it has made it clear that it will not use the anti-dumping legislation in any way as a form of industry protection. It remains committed to the liberalisation of international trade to ensure the efficient use of our national resources. But, unlike Captain Zero—as the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is often referred to—and his henchmen opposite, this Government will achieve this through negotiations at an international level through the GATT processes and the Cairns Group and not by unilateral action of the type proposed by the Professor, who proposes simply to say to Australian producers, `Right, you have zero tariffs; now get out there and compete'.

In addition to the changes that will occur in anti-dumping procedures, the Bills before the House also propose changes in relation to tariff concessions. At the moment, imports that have no effective alternative good that fulfils similar functions and is made in Australia are allowed duty free entry into the country under the existing commercial tariff concession system. The aim of this arrangement is to ensure that industries which use such products do not have their ability to compete in any way impeded by the tariff system.

When tariff concession orders are granted to importers, they are able to import their goods free of import duty. The changes to tariff concession arrangements that will occur as a result of this legislation are a consequence of dissatisfaction with the present system. All the tariff measures introduced by this Bill complement the trade reforms this Government has introduced over the past nine years. We have worked constructively with industry and the trade union movement to open up Australian industry to competition in the international marketplace while keeping the social dislocation that is associated with structural change to a minimum.

Whilst the Leader of the Opposition and the economic vandals that back him, such as the honourable member for Barker, continue to parrot empty rhetoric about the need to reduce tariff levels, the conservative parties in this country have never attempted to address this vital issue. It has been only under the present Labor Government that protection levels have been reduced; for instance, in the clothing and textiles industry from 222 per cent to 52 per cent in 1983-84. Of course, there are others.

While Fraser and Howard—and now Hewson—were content to sit on their hands for seven years, this Government has embarked on a systematic program of tariff reductions from the 250 and 220 per cent levels of the Fraser years to target levels of 25, 15 and 5 per cent. In addition to its domestic program of tariff reduction, the Government has been at the forefront of international efforts to reduce trade barriers worldwide through its involvement in the Cairns Group and the Uruguay Round of the GATT trade talks. In contrast to the Fraser Government, which made no effort even to get the issue of the freeing up of trade in agricultural products on the international agenda, this Government has been actively pursuing this issue along with other members of the Cairns Group within the current Uruguay Round of the GATT talks.

Not only was the coalition not supportive of agricultural trade reform; it worked actively to undermine reform, with the then Deputy Prime Minister, Doug Anthony, walking out of the GATT discussion on agricultural protection during the 1970s. The Liberals were absolutely powerless—nothing has changed there—and totally useless in bringing about any real reform to international trade during their last term in office.

In order to cover up their past inadequacies in tariff reform, those opposite are now engaged in a pathetic game of one-upmanship, with the Leader of the Opposition now saying that he will cut back tariffs to zero, without any regard for the huge social costs involved in such a proposal. The amendment moved by the honourable member for Barker is another example of that one-upmanship. I did not wish to take up too much of the House's time, but only to make a few comments on this legislation, because of its importance to the primary producers in my electorate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill proposes some worthwhile amendments to Australia's anti-dumping procedures. It will speed up the process somewhat, tariff concession orders will be easier to get, the term of anti-dumping measures will be extended to five years and inquiries will begin before the expiry of duties. Those measures are welcome but they do not go anywhere near far enough. The coalition is proposing a further speeding up of the anti-dumping procedures as an amendment to this Bill.

PARA.TAB: Speed is an important factor in anti-dumping measures but it is not the only one. No matter how long it takes, it is most important that the correct decision is made and that threatened Australian industries get protection when they are exposed to unfair competition. This Bill has nothing whatsoever to do with fair competition. Australian industries which cannot compete against fair and honest trading from other parts of the world have to look at themselves and cannot expect protection under these sorts of measures. This Bill protects Australian industries which are facing unfair competition from dumping, countervailing measures and the like. It needs to be timely, not after the industries are dead, as occurred with the tomato processors. The assistance must be available on a timely basis to ensure that Australian industries are able to prosper.

Current anti-dumping measures are very costly, they are bureaucratic and they frighten off many affected industries. As the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford) so ably pointed out, the procedures are loaded against the Australian industries so that many Australian industries do not even dare to attempt to get the protection which they ought to be entitled to.

Australians have been calling for improvements to our anti-dumping measures for a long time. The Sunday Mail editorial of 3 May referred particularly to the dumping of birdseed, peanuts and pork. I note the presence of the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) at the table. I am sure that he ought to have been impressed because all of those three industries are relatively close to his own electorate. Unfortunately, nothing has been done to assist those industries and I am not sure that these measures will be sufficient to ensure that they get the kind of protection to which they are entitled.

The problem is that the Customs Service and the Australian Anti-Dumping Authority adopt an attitude towards Australian industry which is unsympathetic and unhelpful and ensures that the benefit of any doubt goes to the dumper—the offender. If confirmation is needed of what the attitude of the Anti-Dumping Authority really is on these questions one only has to look at the Bulletin of 21 January where the Executive Director of the Australian Anti-Dumping Authority, Mr Jock McGuire, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not here to protect anyone . . . When we go to a factory to assess if it is suffering material injury from imports, we want to find a bit of blood on the floor. That's what we want to see.

What sort of an organisation is this? Count Dracula? It wants the blood of workers and the blood of Australian producers before it is prepared to take any action. In other words, its attitude towards the whole question is a fundamental factor in the reason why our dumping procedures have not been working.

PARA.TAB: If ever there was an example of an industry where the whole picture of the effect of anti-dumping is graphically exposed it is the Australian peanut industry. The peanut industry has been suffering the effect of dumped Chinese peanuts for some time. The industry mounted a case and went to the Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority, both of whom acknowledged that dumping was occurring and acknowledged that the Australian industry was adversely affected, but refused to do anything about it.

If my comments are questioned, I will quote precisely from the report of the Anti-Dumping Authority when responding to the appeal lodged by the industry against the Customs Service. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Authority agrees with Customs that peanut kernels have been imported from China at dumped prices. But while Customs found only a few shipments to be dumped the Authority estimates that about 23 per cent of imports in 1991 were dumped at significant dumping margins.
The Authority also agrees that the Australian industry suffered material injury in 1990 . . .

In spite of the fact that the industry proved its case, there were still no anti-dumping duties imposed on the Chinese peanuts. The peanuts that are coming from China are not only dumped but also chemically contaminated and of generally poor quality. The National Health and Medical Research Council actually introduced and set higher permissible levels of organochlorin pesticide residues to accommodate the Chinese imports and, in so doing, helped to damage the good reputation of peanut products.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that since 1987 peanut imports from China have increased from 2,053 tonnes to 8,374 tonnes—a 307 per cent increase—and that now represents over 30 per cent of the Australian market. These peanuts are being brought into Australia at prices up to $800 a tonne below the previous domestic prices in Australia, significantly reducing returns to local peanut farmers. Poor seasons have made it necessary to import some peanuts to make up the shortfall. But some importers want to institutionalise the imports to maximise their personal profits. Those dumped imports have destroyed the confidence of Australian peanut growers. Even when better seasons returned farmers failed to plant the previous acreages. In the past Australian farmers consistently planted between 30,000 and 35,000 hectares of peanuts. The current crop is just 23,000 hectares.

The Minister, who is at the table, has no sympathy for the Australian peanut industry. He has defended the imports through press releases and the like and has heaped ridicule on the Australian industry, accusing it of merely trying to increase its market share. Of course it is trying to increase its market share at the expense of the dumped Chinese imports. I would have thought that it would have been entitled to the support of the Minister rather than his condemnation for its efforts in that regard.

The peanut industry is exposed to every aspect of the current mechanisms in relation to tariff and trade arrangements. It is also suffering the impact of having to pay import duty on a lot of its machinery. Recently I had an opportunity to take up with the Minister the problems of an importer who is bringing peanut pulling equipment into Australia and having to pay 11 per cent duty. He has been unable to get any concessional order even though no similar machinery is made in Australia. I hope that the amendments to the legislation will give new hope to the importers of peanut machinery.

The Minister stated as recently as 31 March this year in his letter to me that there would be no concessional order because there was a possible manufacturer by the name of McIntyre Precision Machinery at Cooran in Queensland which might be able to make these products. The facts are that the company has never made them. It is not located anywhere near the peanut growing areas and there was never any real possibility of its producing this equipment. I might add that it has an international patent protecting it anyway. However, in spite of all that, the Australian peanut producers who cannot get any protection against dumped products affecting their own market also cannot get any relief from the tariff that they are having to pay on much of their imported machinery.

The current improvements to the legislation are welcome but they fall a long way short of what will be needed. What is fundamentally needed is a sea change in the attitude of the people administering Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing legislation. They need to adopt an attitude that is fundamentally sympathetic rather than antagonistic to Australian producers.

In contrast to what the Government has been proposing, the National and Liberal parties will deliver a fairer trading environment for Australian industry upon returning to government. We will slash the amount of time taken to determine anti-dumping and countervailing cases and change the material injury test to ensure that an industry does not have to be decimated before remedial action can be taken. If there is to be any bias in an inquiry, the process should favour the Australian industry rather than the importer.

Australia has become a dumper's paradise under this Government. Products that no other country will take have been welcomed into our land. We must change that style. Assistance must be available to help small industries in particular to meet the massive cost of mounting anti-dumping actions. Where there is any doubt, we should find in favour of the Australian producers.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak only briefly because I know that the Opposition wishes to go to the committee stage. I want to refute some of the points made by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), who perhaps should find out whether he represents the Peanut Marketing Board or the peanut growers. There is a difference between the two. It is good to see the National Party still on the old protection band wagon. Call it a tariff or a dumping policy, the National Party is trying to protect the industry, whether it is warranted or not.

PARA.TAB: Some concerns have been raised with me, although not specifically tonight in the debate on the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill. Those concerns are in relation to the practice of country hopping. After an application for anti-dumping action has been lodged with the Australian Customs Service, it can happen that importers begin to source their supplies from a country not named in the original application. If these imports too are dumped, the practice becomes known as country hopping. Country hopping has the potential to erode the benefits of the anti-dumping action. However, I am certain that such problems can be adequately addressed as they arise under the current provisions of the legislation.

In the near future, I shall be writing to Customs and to the Anti-Dumping Authority asking that they act quickly in such cases where the Australian industry concerned can produce evidence of country hopping. I intend to make that letter public so that it becomes part of the mechanism. I will make sure that the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) gets a copy.

The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) made a valuable contribution, particularly in refuting the five-day rule nonsense which was put forward by the Opposition. I do not wish to reiterate that because I want to make sure that the procedures of the House flow smoothly. I give good grace to the honourable member for Barker.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)Clause 13, page 24, line 43, omit "25 days", substitute "5 days".
(2)Clause 13, page 25, line 19, omit "25 days", substitute "5 days".

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of these amendments is quite obvious: a reduction in the prima facie inquiry stage from 25 days to five days. We moved a second reading amendment which went much further than that. Of course, we are not able to deal with that in this committee stage. Some of the arrangements that we are proposing would run the Customs Service hearings and the ADA hearings concurrently and, therefore, the Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill would need a total revamping; otherwise we would have been disposed to move in that direction.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), who spoke earlier, said that the Opposition, if I remember correctly, had never reduced protection or tariffs—I am not sure which word he used—and in the next breath said that the Opposition is on a one-way path to reducing protection to the point where it is running a scorched earth policy. I have to say to the honourable member that that is an illogical conclusion, on the one hand or the other.

Back in 1978 I had the great privilege of speaking to the ACTU annual conference—I am sure I will never be invited again—and the other day I looked at the speech I made and I found that I gave the ACTU a good round burst on the reduction of tariffs. That was 14 years ago. I hope that some of us at least can get some credit for being consistent on this matter, even in our previous vocations—although I believe the Government will never give that credit to the Opposition.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the results of the board of inquiry into the September 1991 crash of an Army Nomad aircraft near Tenterfield, NSW, be made available; if so, when.
(2) Is the Minister able to say what the basic findings of the board are.

(3) Did a potentially catastrophic in-flight incident involving a RAAF Nomad aircraft occur near Tindal, NT, in September 1991; if so, (a) what were the circumstances and (b) was the aircraft damaged; if so, (i) what was the extent of the damage and (ii) how was the damage caused.
(4) Have the Nomad aircraft in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) been grounded and subjected to an airworthiness survey; if so, (a) when and (b) what were the results.
(5) Does the Nomad aircraft suffer from longitudinal stability problems.
(6) How many Nomad aircraft are held by the (a) Army and (b) RAAF.
(7) Will the numbers referred to in part (6) vary in (a) 1992-93, (b) 1993-94, (c) 1994-95, (d) 1995-96 and (e) 1996-97.
(8) What is the breakdown between N22 and N24 aircraft.
(9) Are any structural modifications planned for the aircraft, in particular to the tailplane assembly; if so, (a) when and (b) under what budgetary provisions.
(10) How has Aerospace Technologies of Australia been involved in the Nomad program and is it still involved.

(11) Has the coroner decided not to proceed with a coronial inquiry into the fatal crash of a RAAF Nomad near Adelaide in March 1990; if so, (a) can the Minister say why and (b) did the Minister state that a coronial inquiry would be held in February 1991; if so, is the Minister able to reconcile that statement with the coroner's decision.
(12) Has the widow of the RAAF officer killed in the crash referred to in part (11) received compensation.
(13) Are there any common links between the crashes and incidents involving the Nomad.

TAB.TAB: (14) How many Nomads remain operational outside Australia.

PARA.TAB: (15) Is there a link between a RAAF board of inquiry and a coronial inquiry where fatalities occur in ADF aircraft.
(16) What fatal crashes of ADF aircraft have occurred in each year since 1985.
(17) Were coronial inquiries held into each of the crashes referred to in part (16); if not, why not.

(18) Further to the Minister's answer to question No. 476 (Hansard, 22 January 1991, page 301), does the Minister still maintain that there is no requirement for re-examination of the Nomad A18-401 matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The results of boards of inquiry are not normally made available for general information. I will release a summary of the Inquiry after the review processes are completed.
(2) The Army Board of Inquiry into the Nomad accident near Tenterfield commenced on 27 April 92 and was completed on 19 May 92. See also answer to (1).

(3) RAAF Nomad experienced a serious incident near Tindal on 17 September 91 (a) When full flap was selected prior to landing, the aircraft experienced pitch oscillations accompanied by violent fore/aft 'pumping' of the control wheel. The phenomenon disappeared when the flaps were retracted, allowing the aircraft to land safely. (b) The aircraft was damaged. (i) The damage consisted of structural deformation of the right aileron, impact damage to the right outboard flap from contact with the aileron mass balance, buckling of the right engine firewall, deformation of an engine access cowl, fractured or deformed right engine mounts and impact damage to the left flap caused by contact with the left aileron mass balance. (ii) The incident is still under investigation. The cause has not yet been determined.

(4) Nomad aircraft of the ADF were temporarily withdrawn from flying operations in early 1990 following the accident involving A18-401. The tailplane structure of all ADF Nomads was subject to inspection prior to the aircraft being returned to flying operations. The inspection revealed all ADF Nomad tailplanes to be airworthy. ADF Nomads were again withdrawn from flying operations following the accident involving A18-303 (Army, near Tenterfield). This was a routine precaution and the aircraft were returned to flying operations without undergoing any specific inspections when it was determined, during the early stages of the investigation, that structural failure was not involved. ADF Nomads were again withdrawn from flying operations following the accident involving A18-403 (RAAF, at Tindal) and currently remain at that status pending the determination of the cause of that event.

(5) Tests conducted by the RAAF Aircraft Research and Development Unit (ARDU) some time ago concluded that the N22 Nomad displayed inherent adverse longitudinal stability and control characteristics and theoretical susceptibility of the horizontal stabiliser to flutter. Studies conducted by Aeronautical Research Laboratories (ARL) showed the aircraft is prone to the development of a limited amplitude pitch instability at a frequency of 2Hz.
(6) Army currently holds 13 Nomads. RAAF holds three.

(7) Numbers referred to in part 6 will vary. Army will receive an additional nine aircraft during the period April 92-May 93. One of the RAAF aircraft is expected to be withdrawn from service in the near future.

(8) Existing Army fleet breakdown is 12 N22s and one N24. The additional aircraft will be five N22s and four N24s. Existing RAAF fleet composition is two N24s and one N22, with the N22 being the aircraft expected to be withdrawn from service.

(9) (a) ASTA presented two structural modifications to all world wide NOMAD operators by Service Bulletin on 17 December 91 for incorporation by 30 April 92 with conditions relevant to modification kit provision and installation cost Debates. RAAF as an independent airworthiness authority, requested via both the NOMAD Joint Committee and independently through HQLC, that ASTA provide a fatigue substantiation plan to justify these modifications and substantiate a fatigue safe life for a modified tailplane. ASTA presented the RAAF with a final fatigue substantiation test plan and schedule on 14 April 1992. The plan and schedule are being reviewed by RAAF HQLC engineering staff to determine if the planned test activity is adequate. Following acceptance of ASTA's fatigue test plan and schedule, RAAF HQLC will consider modification incorporation following review of ASTA's test results and RAAF(ARDU) flight handling trials of a modified tailplane. (b) The Commonwealth, through Defence Outlay, will meet the cost of modification parts and will reimburse the ADF for installation costs providing modification incorporation is completed by the end of FY 93/94. Further, all Nomad aircraft on the Australian Civil Register were modified by 30 April 1992 in accordance with an Airworthiness Directive issued by the Civil Aviation Authority. All required modification kits have been assembled and incorporation in foreign registered aircraft is expected to be completed by the end of June 1992.

(10) The Nomad aircraft was manufactured by the Government Aircraft Factories (GAF). When GAF was corporatised, it became Aerospace Technologies of Australia (ASTA). As part of the change, ASTA undertook to continue GAF's role as the Design Authority and Type Certificate holder for the Nomad but did not assume responsibility for GAF's activity prior to takeover and this remains the Commonwealth's responsibility. As part of the discharge of this obligation, the Commonwealth through Defence Outlay, funds ASTA approximately four million dollars per year to provide support to Nomad operators. One-off costs such as the tailplane modification mentioned in part (9) are also met by the Commonwealth through Defence outlay.

(11) The jurisdiction of the South Australian Coroner is exercised by him under state legislation. Any decision on whether and when an inquest is to be held or whether it will be dispensed with is a matter for him to determine in accordance with his powers. He has consulted the interested parties, including solicitors acting for the widow of the deceased pilot and the Commonwealth. On several occasions the Coroner, in correspondence and discussions has estimated dates when an inquest might have occurred, had he decided to proceed as events then stood, including the February 1991 date; these were estimates only and were not dates set or influenced by Commonwealth authorities. The Commonwealth has supplied the Coroner and other parties with information relating to the accident and will cooperate in the exercise of the State jurisdiction but it is not in a position to influence the Coroner's jurisdiction exercised under State law. The specific matter raised in this question are not ones for the Department of Defence to answer.
(13) No common links have been established between the accidents and incidents involving ADF Nomad aircraft.
(14) Information in respect of the number of Nomads operational outside Australia is not held by Defence.
(15) There is no formal link between RAAF Boards of Inquiry and coronial inquiries, although Board of Inquiry reports are frequently provided to the Coroner to assist him in his deliberations.
(16) Fatal crashes of ADF aircraft since 1985 are as follows:
Chinook—04 February 85
Mirage—20 June 85
Kiowa—28 October 85
F-111—28 January 86
Mirage—02 May 86
F-111—02 April 87
Kiowa—12 October 87
Hornet—18 November 87
Winjeel—24 February 88
Winjeel—28 March 88
Nomad—12 March 90
Hornet—02 August 90
Kiowa—19 November 90
Macchi—19 November 90
Orion—26 April 91
Hornet—02 June 91
PC9/A—05 August 91
Nomad—09 September 91
Boeing—29 October 91

(17) For the reasons set out in answer to Question (11), the decision to hold an inquest into each fatality and the reasons for that decision were matters for the relevant coroner exercising a State jurisdiction.

(18) The accident involving Nomad A18-401 has been thoroughly investigated by both a Board of Inquiry and an independent investigation of the engineering circumstances of the aircraft's introduction into service. The findings and recommendations of both the inquiry and the independent investigation have been thoroughly reviewed by Air Commander Australia and the Chief of the Air Staff and appropriate action has been taken within the RAAF as a result of the review process. There is no requirement for a re-examination of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 25 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What funding has Australia provided to the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) in each year since 1988.
(2) Is the Minister able to say how many staff were employed at FAO headquarters on 1 January (a) 1988, (b) 1989, (c) 1990, (d) 1991 and (e) 1992.
(3) Is the Minister also able to say what is the (a) number, (b) make and (c) type of vehicles (i) owned or operated by FAO in Rome and (ii) provided under privilege to FAO and its employees.
(4) What proportion of FAO budget is spent on (a) administration and (b) direct project funding.
(5) How is the performance of FAO monitored by (a) the UN and (b) Australia.
(6) How does Australia rate FAO's performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia's assessed contributions to FAO fall due on 1 January. Australia makes full payment on a financial year basis ie. as soon as practicable after 1 July of the year in which the contribution falls due.
Australia has provided the following funding to the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) since 1988:
1990/91—payment deferred until 1991/92
(2) FAO staffing numbers are made available as at 30 June each year. Regular Programme staff numbers at FAO headquarters since 1988 were: 2055 (1988), 2055 (1989), 2016 (1990), 2016 (1991).

(3) Information provided to us on an informal basis is that the Director General and Deputy D-G are each entitled to a motor vehicle. A fleet of less than 10 vehicles is operated by FAO for duty travel, deliveries, etc. Under an agreement with the Italian Government, FAO employees, level P5 and above are eligible to tax exemption on their private motor vehicles.

(4) In the biennial Regular Programme Budget for 1990/91, $US140 million or 24.6% of the budget was allocated for administration (defined as general policy and direction, support services, common services and contingencies). The residual $US429 million or 75.4% was allocated to technical, economic, development support and cooperation programs.

In addition, extra-budgetary sources (eg the UN Development Programme and trust funds) provide funding for FAO's Field Programme. From an expenditure on this Programme of $US467 million in 1990 (latest available figures) FAO charged $US61 million or 13% for administrative support costs.

(5) (a) As a sovereign agency within the United Nations system the FAO is not subject to monitoring of its performance by any other part of the UN. The FAO reports to the UN General Assembly through the Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC). The FAO, like other UN agencies, is subject to management audits undertaken by the Joint Inspection Unit (JIU) of the UN Secretariat in New York.

(b) A major review of the FAO was submitted to the Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Trade and Primary Industries and Energy, as Ministers responsible for Australian membership of the FAO in June 1990. Additionally, performance of all UN agencies is reported to Cabinet biennially.

Australia has been able to monitor FAO performance closely through its membership of FAO Council, the Finance Committee (until November 1991), and from November 1991 the Programme Committee from where it will continue its scrutiny of FAO activities. Australia also cooperates with like-minded member countries on issues which affect the administrative and operational performance of the FAO.

(6) The activities of the FAO have considerable significance at the global and regional levels and the Organisation makes a significant contribution to the rural areas of developing countries, to their economies and to the health and welfare of their populations. On all issues of significance in relation to the development, maintenance and utilisation of agricultural, forestry and fisheries resources, the policies and programs of the FAO complement Australian objectives. Similarly, FAO has repeatedly endorsed the achievement of trade liberalisation for agriculture as a guiding principle.

Current assessments of FAO performance have noted an improvement in administrative and operational activities. At the 1991 Council, a zero real growth budget for the 1992/93 biennium was passed, together with an agreed Medium Term Plan which will enable greater scrutiny of and control over FAO programs and expenditure by member countries.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) When will financial arrangements governing the handover to Australia of the naval communications station at North West Cape be finalised.
(2) Is the Minister able to say whether the capital cost to the USA of the station when it was established in the middle to late 1960s was approximately $US80 million.

(3) Will the arrangements referred to in part (1) provide for capital equipment maintenance and replacement; if so, will Australia bear the cost or will the USA; if not, what will be the position regarding capital equipment maintenance and replacement.
(4) What is the age of the (a) towers, (b) ground mat and (c) VLF transmitter at North West Cape.
(5) Will the Defence Budget be (a) required to absorb any costs arising from the handover or (b) supplemented; if so, on what basis will it be supplemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The principles governing the financial aspects of the transition were finalised in 1991. On 28 November 1991 the Minister for Defence announced that the cost of operating the Station during and after the transition will be shared by Australia and the United States on user pays principles (Senate Hansard 28 November 1991 pages 3599-3601).

The United States Government has advised that it will seek no compensation for the buildings and other structures at the Station while it continues to have access to the Station. The new arrangements include a guarantee that the United States will continue to have access after the Station becomes an Australian Naval Communication Station, with the United States continuing to share the operating costs on user pays principles.

In broad terms Australia's share of Station costs will be about 25 per cent of the total VLF costs. The actual amount will depend on the terms of the contract to be signed with the civilian operator and other factors. Total operating costs are expected to be significantly lower than they are at present. Detailed arrangements are expected to be finalised this year.
(2) Yes. This was the amount stated in a Department of Defence publication published in 1968 which estimated that the whole complex cost of the order of $US80 million.
(3) The answer to (1) above also applies to the sharing of ongoing capital equipment maintenance and replacement costs.

(4) The towers and ground mat are over 25 years old, having been constructed between 1963 and 1967. Elements of the VLF transmitter have been upgraded and modernised since it was constructed in 1963-67, and the transmitter's age therefore varies accordingly.
(5) (a) Yes. Provision has been made in the draft Estimates for Australia to begin contributing to Station costs in FY 1992-93.
(b) No.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 5 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many pilots were employed by (a) Ansett Airlines, (b) East West Airlines and (c) IPEC on (i) 1 August 1989 and (ii) 31 December 1991.
(2) How many pilots of (a) Australian and (b) foreign nationality were employed by (i) Ansett Airlines, (ii) East West Airlines and (iii) IPEC on (A) 1 August 1989 and (B) 31 December 1991.

(3) Will the Government permit more foreign pilots to take up employment with (a) the three airlines referred to in part (1) and (b) other Australian domestic airlines; if so, in each case, (i) how many, (ii) over what period and (iii) with which airlines.

(4) Following the 1989 airlines dispute, did foreign pilots taking up employment with (a) the three airlines referred to in part (1) and (b) other Australian domestic airlines receive higher salaries and allowances than Australian pilots; if so, in each case, how much more did they receive (i) in dollars and (ii) as a proportion of total salaries and allowances paid to Australian pilots immediately before the dispute began.
(5) How many pilots ceased their employment with (a) the three airlines referred to in part (1) and (b) other Australian domestic airlines as a result of the 1989 airlines dispute.
(6) How many of the pilots referred to in part (5) have been re-employed.

(7) How many pilots who applied for re-employment on or after 21 March 1990, when the Australian Federation of Air Pilots gave certain undertakings to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, have been re-employed.

(8) Are experienced Australian pilots who resigned from their employment in 1989 being denied re-employment by (a) the three airlines referred to in part (1) and (b) other Australian domestic airlines in favour of less experienced pilots.

(9) Is the Minister able to say whether (a) the three airlines referred to in part (1) and (b) other Australian domestic airlines have adopted a policy of not re-employing pilots involved in the 1989 airlines dispute; if so, (i) which airlines and (ii) what steps will be taken to change that policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The number of pilots employed by Ansett Transport Industries (ATI) and East West Airlines on 1 August 1989 was 1046 and on 31 December 1991 was 613. IPEC employed 34 pilots on 1 August 1989 and 16 pilots on 31 December 1991.

(2) No pilots of foreign nationality were employed by ATI, East West Airlines and IPEC on 1 August 1989. On 31 December 1991, ATI and East West Airlines employed 44 pilots of foreign nationality. IPEC did not employ any foreign pilots on 31 December 1991.

(3) The employment of pilots by the airlines is a matter for their own commercial judgement. Ansett has advised that its policy is that pilots must be domiciled in Australia and meet Australian citizenship requirements.

(4) Foreign pilots taking up employment with the Australian domestic airlines referred to in part (1), following the 1989 airlines dispute, did not receive higher salaries and allowances than Australian pilots. Australian Airlines has confirmed that salaries are determined according to status (i.e. Captain/First Officer) and equipment flown, and that nationality is of no relevance whatsoever in relation to salary.
(5) The airlines have indicated that approximately 1579 pilots resigned from ATI, East West, IPEC and Australian Airlines on 24 August 1989.
(6) ATI, East West, IPEC and Australian Airlines have advised that approximately 455 pilots employed prior to 24 August 1989 have been re-employed.
(7) ATI, East West, IPEC and Australian Airlines have re-employed approximately 59 former pilots since 21 March 199O.

(8) The airlines have advised that experienced pilots who resigned from their employment in 1989 are not being denied re-employment in favour of less experienced pilots. Ansett has advised that once the airlines had rebuilt their pilot establishments, recruiting reverted to the arrangements that applied prior to August 1989. Australian's position is that former pilots who apply for re-employment are considered on a competitive basis along with the applications already held.
(9) The airlines do not have a policy of not employing pilots involved in the 1989 airlines dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the CSIRO researching control of the buffalo fly; if so, (a) what programs are being conducted, (b) in which Divisions and at what locations are they being conducted, (c) what sums derived from the (i) Commonwealth and (ii) cattle industry have been spent on each program since its inception and (d) what stage has each program reached in realising its original objectives.
(2) Have the research findings of any of the programs referred to in part (1) been transferred to the cattle industry; if so, (a) which programs and (b) by which applications in each case.
(3) To what extent has the cattle industry taken up each of the applications referred to in part (2).
(4) How has each application been distributed through the industry.
(5) What is the cost to the individual user of access to each application.
(6) Is any application inherently limited in its effectiveness in controlling the impact of the buffalo fly; if so, how.

(7) Are any research programs being (a) conducted or (b) proposed which would offer more effective control of the buffalo fly than is available through existing applications; if so, (i) what are they, (ii) how would they provide more effective control, (iii) what is the total level of support for the programs, (iv) how long will it take for the results of each program to be applied and (v) which program is expected to produce the best results and why.
(8) Have any buffalo fly research programs been required to (a) reduce their research effort or (b) qualify their original objectives.

(9) Is the CSIRO conducting research programs into biological control of the buffalo fly; if so, (a) what is the status of each program, (b) what sum has been allocated from all sources to each program since its inception and (c) what is the projected funding of each program.
(10) Have any of the programs referred to in part (9) been required to (a) reduce their research effort or (b) qualify their original objectives; if so, why.

(11) Have any of the programs referred to in part (9) suffered a decline in support from any funding source; if so, (a) from which source, (b) to what extent has support declined, (c) why was support reduced and (d) what was the impact of the decline.
(12) What is the estimated annual cost to the beef industry of the impact of the buffalo fly.
(13) Will the impact and cost increase.
(14) Is the buffalo fly endemic in Australia.
(15) In which areas is its impact mostly felt.
(16) Are estimates of the cost of the impact of the buffalo fly on the cattle industry by (a) region and (b) State available.
