(18) What is the incidence of the buffalo fly in other countries.
(19) What efforts do the countries referred to in part (18) make to contain or eliminate the buffalo fly.
(20) Are any countries pursuing research into the buffalo fly along similar lines to that being conducted in Australia.
(21) Is the buffalo fly an introduced species.
(22) What are the traditional methods of controlling the buffalo fly.
(23) What are the limitations and undesirable implications of the traditional methods of control.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, CSIRO is conducting research on the control of buffalo fly.

(a) CSIRO Division of Tropical Animal Production is investigating a vaccine against the flies; CSIRO Division of Entomology has developed a cattle operated trap for milking cows and is proposing to adapt it to dry cattle.
(b) This research is being conducted at the CSIRO Long Pocket Laboratories, Brisbane, Queensland.
(c) Commonwealth funded CSIRO expenditure is estimated as $8.7m. (Tropical Animal Production, $2.2m to June 1992; Entomology, $6.5m to June 1992).
Cattle industry funded CSIRO expenditure is estimated as: Tropical Animal Production: $730 000 to June 1992, Entomology $3.6m to June 1992.

(d) The vaccine being researched by the Division of Tropical Animal Production is at a very early stage in its development, and the trap is operational in commercial dairies in SE Queensland and modifications and tests are underway for use on dry dairy cattle.
(2) Yes. The trap developed by CSIRO Division of Entomology has been available since July 1991.
(3) The traps are in the first stages of adoption by the dairy industry, which is responding enthusiastically. No adoption has been attempted yet in the beef cattle industry.
(4) The traps have been commercialised through an Australian manufacturer, Country Industries Australia Ltd (Brisbane).

(5) The traps for milkers cost $2,250. These traps require minimal maintenance and no labour once established. They have an expected life of 7-10 years. Traps for dry cows should cost significantly less when available.

(6) The cattle need to use the traps daily and hence applications are limited to where cattle managers can either train stock or move cattle through traps to/from water or other attractants (eg feed supplements and mineral blocks). A buffalo fly vaccine when developed, would be limited by the level and duration of protection that the cattle immune systems could provide.
(7) (a) The buffalo fly trap has long term potential for fly control, if and when it becomes available to the beef industry.

(b) An application, by CSIRO Division of Entomology, for support of this research is presently being considered by Meat Research Corporation (MRC) in the current round. CSIRO should know the outcome by the end of May 1992, and if the project is fully funded, will begin research in July 1992. Amounts requested: $71,181 in 1992-93; $131,237 in 1993-94, (total, $202,418).
If research is funded, the traps are expected to be available to the beef industry in 1994.
There are opportunities to increase the impact of biological control agents such as dung beetles and predators but no proposals are current.

Both the traps and biological control agents offer the prospects of sustainable control, with no threat of the development of resistance. Resistance may not develop to the vaccines either but that is not predictable at present. Further importation of biological control agents would be a long term project and their impact would be felt gradually over the next decade if they were imported in the next 2-3 years. In theory, biological control offers the cheapest and most durable approach as it makes little demand on management once it is operational. However, much more needs to be understood about the ecology of the buffalo fly and about the impact of dung fauna in Africa before firm projections can be made on the likely impact.

(8) Yes. CSIRO stopped ecological studies of buffalo fly in 1989 after industry support for this research was withdrawn in 1987 because of industry doubts about the economic impact of buffalo flies. At that time, the project involved fundamental studies and investigations of biological control using dung beetles and introduced predators.
(10) Answer to Q8 refers.
(11) Answer to Q8 refers.

(12) The annual cost to the beef industry caused by the impact of the buffalo fly is estimated by CSIRO staff working on buffalo fly projects as $100m per annum (lost production, costs of chemicals and labour).

(13) The impact of buffalo fly will increase with further development of resistance to insecticides and, in the event of climate change arising from the Greenhouse effect, a spread into southern NSW and perhaps parts of Victoria.

(14) Buffalo fly is now endemic to Australia. It was introduced from SE Asia, probably from Indonesia through Darwin last century. It has spread from there into Queensland and northern NSW. In the past few years there have been sporadic problems at Coffs Harbour, Glen Innes and Tenterfield (this is about the southern limit to the distribution at present).

(15) The coast and hinterland from Grafton north to Darwin and inland to the Great Divide, Mt Isa and similar latitudes in the Northern Territory. Infestations further inland occur following the movement of cattle.
(17) Estimated at $1 billion by CSIRO staff working on buffalo fly projects.
(18) In south east Asia the buffalo fly occurs on buffalo and herded cattle. A subspecies, the horn fly, is a severe pest in the Americas and occurs in Asia and southern Europe.
(19) In the USA and Canada, insecticidal control is used but they have encountered problems with insecticide resistance. No other successful approaches are known to Australian researchers.

(20) Agriculture Canada (Lethbridge) was pursuing immunological studies. USA is trying to revive interest in a 1940's model of the horn fly trap and are reported to be investigating immunological control of the fly by vaccines.
(22) Chemicals are applied by cattle dip, spray, pour-on or back rubber.

(23) Chemical control is expensive and not sustainable due to the selection pressure on the fly populations and the repeated development of resistance. In addition, the use of chemicals generates potential chemical residue problems in the meat. The labour requirements for frequent chemical treatment are often difficult to meet.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 30 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: Did the Pyramid receiver allege that a foreign bank engaged in illegal activities designed to transfer personal liabilities of Mr Farrow and Mr Clarke to Pyramid depositors; if so, will he (a) investigate the allegations and (b) establish whether a breach of Commonwealth law occurred as a result of those transactions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: I understand that the Pyramid receiver has filed a statement of claim on behalf of the building societies in the Farrow group, joining a foreign bank as a defendant in a civil action against Messrs Farrow and Clarke for breaches of their fiduciary duties to the building societies. It is claimed that the bank was knowingly involved in those alleged breaches by providing two loan facilities which were to the benefit of Farrow and Clarke and caused loss to the building societies. The action, therefore, seeks to recover the alleged profits associated with the transactions and to recover compensation for the loss suffered by the societies from not only Farrow and Clarke, but also the relevant bank.

The action appears to be based on general fiduciary duties and participation in breaches of such duties by third parties rather than on any statutory based cause of action. Any breach of criminal law associated with the alleged transactions would be primarily a matter for Victoria. Furthermore, any other alleged breaches of statute law would also be matters for Victorian rather than Commonwealth law, as the activities of building societies and their officers are regulated by the law of that State and any related offences by third parties would also be dealt with under that law.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims that the definition Australia uses for refugee status is too restrictive.
(2) Has he examined proposals that persons from oppressed minorities be treated as refugees.
(3) Has the number of persons who would qualify as refugees under the proposal referred to in part (2) been estimated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) As a signatory to the 1951 United Nations Convention and the 1967 Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees Australia applies the definition of refugee contained in those documents.

The Convention and Protocol define a refugee as a person who, owing to a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality and is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country, or who not having a nationality and being outside the country of his former habitual residence as a result of such events, is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to return to it.
These are internationally agreed criteria which are applied in the determination of refugee status by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

(2) There is no provision for a class determination of refugee status. Persons from oppressed minorities can qualify as refugees on a case by case basis if they are outside the country of claimed persecution, and can demonstrate that the oppression they suffered, as individuals, amounted to persecution.

(3) No. After defining oppression it would be necessary to catalogue all the `oppressed minorities' in the world. This would not be a fixed number of persons but a fluid population that would be impossible to catalogue.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his Department sent two officers and one prosthetic engineer to Cambodia; if so, why.
(2) What are his Department's resources for manufacturing and supplying prostheses.
(3) What potential is there for assistance to Cambodian citizens who have lost limbs as a result of mine explosions or have suffered other war caused disabilities.
(4) Did his Department prepare a report in 1972 following a visit by departmental officers to Bangladesh; if so, has he studied the report.
(5) What assistance was provided in the case referred to in part (4) and how does it compare with the resources available for Cambodia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. At a meeting with my Department, the Director of the Department of Rehabilitation and Adaptation in the Cambodian Ministry of Invalides Social Action, Mr Soeun, explored the general idea of an Australian aid team going to Cambodia to provide assistance and training to local citizens. Because of a lack of knowledge on the extent of aid necessary in the area of artificial limbs, it became clear that any definitive proposal could not be put together before an assessment in the field. This is the reason why the party was despatched.

(2) My Department has artificial limb centres operating with qualified staff in each capital city. In addition, there are smaller centres in Darwin, Townsville, Canberra, Newcastle and Albury. Each centre manufactures a full range of prostheses.

(3) My Department has the potential to provide assistance in several forms e.g. sending staff to Cambodia to produce artificial limbs and train local Cambodian citizens in production; producing parts for, or sections of, limbs in Australia which could then be sent to Cambodia for manufacture of prostheses. However, the type and extent of assistance which could be provided will not be known until a report by the assessment team has been completed.
(4) Yes, a report was prepared in 1972 following a visit by a departmental officer to Bangladesh. I have read the report.

(5) Seven Limbmakers and Fitters from Australia went to Bangladesh on a rotational basis, ensuring that there were two qualified Australian artisans in that country for the entire four years of the project.
At this stage I am unable to make an effective comparison with aid provided to Bangladesh as the data collected from the recent field trip to Cambodia is still being assessed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: As it is not mandatory for officers to provide details of any tertiary qualifications they may have, this Department does not have accurate records of all officers with tertiary qualifications. Based on the information supplied by staff, the following is provided:
(a) 107 officers have studied economics at the ANU which is approximately 28% of professional officers; and
(b) 16 officers are currently studying economics at the ANU which is approximately 4% of professional officers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Following the Prime Minister's pledge at the start of the One Nation strategy to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy he can muster, is the National Board of Employment, Education and Training giving pre-eminence to the goal of growth of employment in Australia in its corporate planning and policy development; if so, (a) how is pre-eminence being given, (b) in what ways is the goal being implemented and (c) are there any organisational activities which are inconsistent with maximising employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)Yes.

(a) The National Board has determined its future directions and work priorities which cover a mixture of short, medium and longer term issues. Employment issues, and the specific need for an improved employment situation in Australia, are a primary theme pervading advice developed by the National Board and its constituent Councils, with greater emphasis given to such issues since the start of increasing unemployment in 1990.

(b) The National Board provides national policy advice on the full range of employment, education and training issues. In relation to education and training issues, the aim is to provide advice that will improve education and training outcomes for Australia's workforce and society generally, thereby improving Australia's economic competitiveness and assisting employment growth.
The National Board and its Employment and Skills Formation Council (ESFC) have also provided substantial advice on labour market programs and services, in particular

Towards an Active Labour Market Policy, in December 1989. This advice was consistent with the Government's pre-election initiatives announced in February 1990, and implemented subsequently, for a more active employment strategy involving employment and income support assistance for unemployed people and major reforms to labour market training.

Assistance for Disadvantaged Jobseekers, in July 1991. This advice welcomed recent improvements in the range and effectiveness of assistance for disadvantaged jobseekers provided by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, and suggested a range of measures to achieve further progress to this end. Particular areas covered in the advice included client service for disadvantaged jobseekers, and the supply and effectiveness of work experience, training and self-employment assistance.
Public support for the range of initiatives announced by the Federal Government in 1991 and early 1992 to increase the supply of labour market program places for unemployed people.
The ESFC has recently established an ongoing working group to address employment and labour market issues, having regard to earlier advice and recent government initiatives.

A number of advices on training and skills formation issues have also been directly relevant to assisting sustained employment growth. For example, the recent report The Australian Vocational Certificate Training System addresses unemployment of young people and the proposed creation of training places; it is aimed at preparing young people for ongoing employment in the mature labour force.
(c) No.
